you have commanded me to build
an altar and a temple,
just like that sacred temple
you made at the beginning.[9]

Wisdom has always been with you.
She knows your mighty deeds,
and she was there
when you created the world.
Wisdom knows what pleases you,
and she knows what is right
according to your commands.

So from your glorious and holy
throne in the heavens,
please send Wisdom
to work beside me and teach me
what is pleasing to you.

Wisdom will guide me
in all that I do,
and her glory will guard me,
because she knows everything.

Then you will approve my actions,
and I will rule your people
with fairness,
which will show that I am worthy
to succeed my father as king.

No one can know what you,
the Lord God,
demand of us humans—

our reasoning is faulty,
and our schemes often fail,

because our mortal bodies
are merely earthly tents
that burden down our souls
and our anxious minds.

We struggle and know so little
about things here on earth.
How could we possibly learn
about things in heaven?

Who has known your thoughts
before you gave them Wisdom
and your Holy Spirit?

Then they found the right path;
they learned what pleased you
and were saved by Wisdom.
<sup>ⓢ</sup> Wisdom protected Adam, the father of the human race. When he was alone on earth, she kept him from sin
and gave him the power to rule everything.
<sup>ⓣ</sup> But Adam's son Cain was evil, and he rejected Wisdom. Then in his anger, he destroyed himself by killing his brother.
<sup>ⓤ</sup> When Cain's sin caused a flood, Wisdom came to the rescue, by guiding the good man Noah in that flimsy wooden boat.

<sup>ⓥ</sup> When nations were frustrated by their own evil plans, Wisdom noticed that Abraham was a good man. So she gave him strength to obey God, though Abraham dearly loved his son Isaac.<sup>[10]</sup>
<sup>ⓦ</sup> Wisdom rescued the good man Lot, when the ungodly people of those five cities died in the flames.

The evidence of their evil can still be seen—the smoke that keeps rising from the desert, those trees with fruit that never ripens, and the pillar of salt that stands as a witness to Lot's wife, who refused to believe.
By rejecting Wisdom, these people became blind to what was right, and so they left a permanent witness to their foolishness.
But she protected those who were obedient to her.

<sup>ⓧ</sup> Wisdom guided that good man Jacob along the right paths when he was running from his angry brother. She showed him your kingdom and helped him understand sacred things. She also made him successful in everything he did.
Wisdom even stood by him and made him rich when he was being mistreated by people who were jealous of him.
She protected him from enemies who were waiting to attack, and when he wrestled with an angel, she let him learn that obeying you, our God, is what makes a person really powerful.
<sup>ⓨ</sup> When that good man Joseph was sold as a slave, Wisdom kept him from committing a terrible sin. She even went down into the dungeon

where he was a prisoner, and she stayed with him until he was given authority over those who had been in charge of him. Wisdom proved that his accusers were wrong and brought him honor that will last forever.
<sup>ⓩ</sup> Wisdom rescued the holy and faultless nation of Israel from those who were oppressing them.
She did this by entering the soul of your servant Moses and opposing cruel kings with her amazing miracles.
Wisdom rewarded those holy people for their hardships and guided them in a wonderful way, providing shade for them during the day and starlight at night.
She brought them safely through the Red Sea,<sup>[11]</sup>
but she drowned their enemies and washed their bodies up on the shore.
So your obedient people took the possessions of those ungodly people. Then they sang praises to your holy name and praised you for protecting them,
because Wisdom healed those who could not talk and helped infants to speak clearly.
<sup>ⓐ</sup> Wisdom made the people of Israel successful by sending them the holy prophet Moses.
They went through a desert where no one lived and camped in places where no one had ever been.
They defeated their enemies,
and when they were thirsty and prayed for your help, you made water flow from a solid rock.
Our Lord, your people were helped by the same disasters that were used to punish their enemies.
You turned the ever-flowing Nile River into filthy blood
to punish the Egyptians for ordering the Hebrew children to be killed, then you surprised everyone by providing your people with more than enough water to satisfy their thirst.
You mercifully let your people go thirsty for a while to show how severely you would punish their ungodly enemies in your anger.
<sup>ⓑ</sup> You corrected your people like parents correcting their children as a warning, but you punished the others like a harsh king condemning a criminal.
All the Egyptians suffered—those who lived near your people and those who lived far away.
In fact, they suffered at the time of these disasters and again whenever they remembered what had happened.
And when the Egyptians learned that your people had benefited from these troubles, they realized that you, Lord, had done it all.
Earlier they had made fun of Moses, who had been placed outside to die when he was a baby, but now they were amazed at him, because they suffered from thirst much more severely than your people.
<sup>ⓒ</sup> The Egyptians were so foolish and evil that they worshiped mindless snakes and worthless animals, and so you sent swarms of senseless creatures to punish them
and to teach them that sin brings its own punishment.
With your own mighty arm, you made the world out of something that had no form, and so you could have sent a lot of bears or ferocious lions.
Or you could have created savage beasts just to punish them—beasts that breathe out fire and smoke and shoot sparks from their eyes,
killing people not only by the injuries they cause but by their very appearance.

In fact, you could have wiped out the Egyptians with a single breath, while you were scattering them with your power and treating them as they deserved. But you do everything fairly and according to the laws of nature that you created.
You always have the strength to do what you want, and no one can oppose you.
In your sight, the universe is merely a grain of sand that tips a balance scale or a drop of dew in the early morning.
You can do anything, and yet you patiently show mercy to everyone, so that they will turn from their sins.
In all creation there is nothing you don't love; otherwise, you would not have created everything.
Nothing would have lasted, unless you had wanted it to.
All living creatures belong to you, and you love them all,
because your eternal spirit is in each of them.
That's why you correct us for our sins a little at a time, as a reminder and a warning for us to turn from sin and have faith in you, our Lord.
<sup>ⓓ</sup> And what about those who lived in your holy land before your people settled there?
You hated them because of their horrible deeds—they practiced magic and did vulgar things when they worshiped their gods;
they mercilessly sacrificed children and ate human flesh and blood. They were members of pagan cults
and murdered their own helpless children. That's why you decided to let our ancestors destroy them,
so that your most precious land would accept a group of people worthy to be your servants.
<sup>ⓔ</sup> But since these people were merely human, you spared many of them and sent hornets ahead of your army to destroy them a little at a time.
You did this, even though you could have let your own people destroy that evil nation, or you could have wiped them out all at once with fierce animals or with one harsh word.
<sup>ⓕ</sup> Although you knew that they were sinful by nature and that they would never give up their evil thoughts, you still punished them little by little, giving them time to turn back to you.
They were under your curse from the beginning, and though you were not afraid of anyone, you let them go unpunished.

All of us are merely human, and we cannot question what you have done, nor can we refuse to let you punish us. No one would dare to blame you for destroying those nations you created or dare to defend the guilty in your court of law.
You alone are God, and you care for all creation.<sup>[12]</sup> So you don't have to prove to any other gods that you do what is right,
and no kings or rulers can accuse you of wrongly punishing anyone.
You are always perfectly fair, and you would never punish innocent people.
You do what is right because you have the strength to do so, and your great power makes you merciful to everyone.
When anyone doubts your strength, you show how strong you are, and you correct anyone who understands and still doubts.
Although you have power to do all things, you are gentle when you judge us, and you rule us with great patience.
Our God, by the things you have done, you have given your people a wonderful hope and have taught them to live right and be kind because you have let them turn from evil.
The enemies of your people deserved death, but you patiently gave them time to give up their sins, before punishing them.
You did severely punish your people, even though you had made wonderful promises and agreements with them.
Yes, we were punished! But our enemies were punished 10,000 times worse, so that when we judge others, we will remember your kindness, and when we are being judged, we can expect mercy.
The Egyptians foolishly lived a sinful life, but you punished them by using those disgusting creatures they worshiped.
In fact, they had gone so far from the truth that they were like senseless children, worshiping the most worthless animals.
And so you made them look like stupid children, when you punished them.
Those who failed to take this warning seriously then received from you the punishment they deserved.

While they were being punished because of the creatures they had worshiped, they became angry with those creatures and finally realized that you are the only true God, even though they had always refused to worship you. All this explains why they were punished so terribly.
You are the living God. And only those who are fools by birth could look at your creation and not learn about you. But instead, some people worshiped the things you created,
such as fire and wind, and storms and stars, and rivers and planets. Those fools believed these things were the gods that ruled the world,
because they were so beautiful. But you are the Lord, as well as the source of all beauty, so let those fools know how much more beautiful you are than any of these things.
And if anyone is amazed at the mighty power of nature, then they should realize that the Creator is even more powerful.
Indeed, the power and beauty of nature should convince us that their Creator is even more powerful and beautiful.
On the other hand, these people are not entirely to blame for taking the wrong path in their desire to know and to find you.
It is to be expected that while searching, they would learn to trust the beautiful things they were seeing.
However, this is no excuse,
because if they possessed the ability to examine the universe, why did it take them so long to find you, the Lord of the universe?
<sup>ⓖ</sup> Some people are miserable because they have set their hopes either on lifeless idols crafted in the shape of animals from gold and silver, or else on some old pieces of worthless stone.
A woodcutter may saw down a small tree, then peel off the bark and skillfully make something worthwhile from the wood.
Some of the leftover wood may be used for a cooking fire,
while a crooked and knotty piece may be carefully carved into the shape of a human
or of some useless animal, before being painted red to cover all its flaws.
A special shelf is made on the wall, and the idol is fastened to the shelf with metal nails
to keep it from falling, because the one who made it realizes that it is merely a helpless idol.
Then—without shame—its maker prays to this lifeless idol for help with finances, marriage, or family.
Its maker asks for good health from something weak, for life from something dead, for guidance from something without experience, for a safe journey from something that cannot walk,
and for wealth and success from something that cannot move its hands.
Sailors preparing to travel across dangerous waters will pray for safety to a flimsy piece of wood, less sturdy than their ship.
Shipmakers use their own wisdom to build a ship that will make them rich.
But, our Father, you are the one who guides it safely through the sea
to show that you alone can protect inexperienced travelers from danger.
By your wisdom you created the laws of nature, and so people trust even the smallest splinter of wood to bring them safely to land.

<sup>ⓗ</sup> When this world was still young, you sent a flood to destroy giants, while at the same time you gave hope for a generation of good people by letting their ancestors find safety in a boat made of wood<sup>[13]</sup> that God had blessed.
Idols are under your curse because those perishable things are called gods, and their makers are under your curse for having made them.
In fact, you hate evil people as much as you hate the evil they produce,
and you will equally punish evildoers together with their deeds.
You will destroy those horrible pagan idols, because they were made from part of your creation and have become a trap for foolish people.
Our God, the idea of making an idol was itself the first step toward being unfaithful to you.
Idols were not here in the beginning, and they won't be around forever.
They resulted from human pride, and so you have plans for them to end quickly.

For example, a father made an idol to look like his child who had suddenly died, and the dead child then became an object of worship by later generations, who followed mysterious and secret ceremonies.
Over the years, such godless ceremonies became customs and then laws, as rulers commanded idols of themselves to be carved and worshiped.
And when people lived far from their rulers, they tried to make idols that looked like their rulers, so that they could honor and flatter those rulers as if they were there with them.
In fact, some people who did not know what their rulers looked like were led to worship them, because of the skill and the tireless efforts of those who made beautiful idols to please their rulers.
Finally, many people started worshiping their earthly rulers as gods.
As a result, idolatry became a hidden trap for those who were suffering or were under the authority of rulers, and they called these idols gods, although you alone are God.
Not only are such people ignorant about you, but this ignorance makes them terrible enemies of each other, even while they think they are living at peace.
They kill their children as sacrifices and conduct secret ceremonies, they follow strange customs and act like wild people,
they are immoral and cause great pain by being unfaithful in marriage, and they are deceitful murderers.
Violence, murder, robbery, deceit, corruption, dishonesty, riots, and lying are everywhere.
No one knows right from wrong or shows gratitude or cares about anyone else; all of them are sexual perverts or share weird marriage unions or are otherwise completely disgusting.
The worship of worthless<sup>[14]</sup> idols is the cause and result of all kinds of evil.
Their worshipers act crazy, or give false messages in the name of God, or live sinful lives. They never speak the truth, and they tell lies in court
because they trust in these lifeless idols and don't expect to be punished.
But they will be punished for worshiping idols instead of you, the Holy God, and for disgracing you with their deceitful lies.
Sinners don't receive help from the idols they worship, but the penalty for their sins follows them in hot pursuit.

You, our God,
are gentle and trustworthy,
patiently ruling the universe
with mercy.

We know your mighty power,
and so we remain your people,
even if we sin.
But knowing we are yours
will keep us from sin.

Nothing is more fitting
than knowing you
and realizing that your power
is the way to endless life.

We have not been misled
by wicked artists,
who made bright-colored idols

to encourage fools to worship
those lifeless images.

Those who make or worship
idols as objects of hope
will get what they deserve
for loving such evil things.
Potters form ordinary dishes and special dishes from the same lump of clay, and only the potters decide which ones will be ordinary or special.

Then—wasting their energy—these potters form a useless idol from the same clay. And not long ago, these potters themselves were made from the soil and will soon turn back into soil, just like all other humans, when it is time to return our borrowed souls.

But these potters don't care that we all must die or that life is short. They consider it a wonderful thing to mold false gods, and all they care about is competing with others, who make idols out of gold or silver or copper.
The heart of such workers is made of ashes, their hope is worth no more than dirt, and their lives are of less value than clay,
because they don't know you, the God who formed their bodies, then filled them with a lively soul and breathed into them a living spirit.
They think of life as a meaningless game or as a festival for making money, because they believe that we should try to get rich in every way possible, even by dishonesty.
More than anyone else, these people realize that they are sinning when they make dishes and idols from the same clay.
Our God, those Egyptians who abused your people were the most foolish of all and were more pitiful than infants.
This is because they believed their pagan idols really were gods—those images that could neither see nor breathe nor hear nor use their hands or feet.
They were made by some human whose soul was borrowed, and none of us can make a god that is our equal.
In fact, we humans are mortal ourselves, and any idol we make with our own evil hands is less than we are and is completely lifeless.
Those Egyptians worshiped snakes, the lowest form of animal life,
a form of life so ugly that you did not even give it your blessing.
You were right to punish the Egyptians by sending snakes to attack those worshipers of snakes.
<sup>ⓘ</sup> But you did not punish your own people. Instead, you treated them with kindness and sent tasty quails for them to eat and enjoy.

You did these things, so that when those Egyptians were hungry, they would feel sick and lose their appetites, because they would have to eat the horrible meat of snakes. However, after suffering for a while, your own people enjoyed the best of foods.
In this way, those who had been oppressed could watch their oppressors suffer cruel punishment.
<sup>ⓙ</sup> When you were angry with your people and were destroying them with poisonous snakes, you stopped before all of them died,
because you did this merely as a warning. Then you told them to make a metal snake, so that they would be rescued and remember to obey your Law.
Everyone who looked at the metal snake was saved, not because of the snake itself, but because of you, the Savior of all people.
By doing this, you proved to our enemies that you alone can protect people from harm,
because many of them got what they deserved, when they died from the bites of locusts and flies.
But you were merciful to your children and healed them from poisonous snake bites,
so that they would remember your teachings and never forget your kindness.<sup>[15]</sup>
Medicine isn't what healed them. Only your word can heal,
because you rule both life and death and possess the power to give life or to take it away.
It's easy enough for us humans to kill another in anger, but we don't have the power to bring back a departed spirit or to set a soul free from the world of the dead.
No one can escape from you, our God.
And when those evil Egyptians rejected you and tried to escape, you punished them with your mighty arm and wiped them out with rainstorms, hailstones, and fiery lightning.
Although water is used to put out a fire, an amazing thing happened—the water made the fire even more destructive, because nature itself protects good people.
One time you kept the fire under control, so that it would not destroy the frogs and flies that were sent to punish those pagans and to let them know you were the one doing all of this.
But at another time, you let it burn out of control—even in water—to wipe out the crops in that evil country.
<sup>ⓚ</sup> You blessed your people with manna,<sup>[16]</sup> that food of angels, the bread you sent down from heaven. It satisfied their hunger and tasted delicious.
Your care for your people was as sweet as this bread that everyone enjoyed so much.
And though the bread was frail as snowflakes, it did not melt in the fiery flames that your enemies saw destroying their crops during the hailstorm.
Contrary to nature, the fire did not spread to the crops of your people.
All of creation serves you, its Creator, and uses its power to punish those who are evil and to show kindness to those who trust in you.
And so on that occasion, the forces of the universe changed the way they work, in order to serve your purpose by answering the prayers
of your precious children. This was also your way of teaching them not to depend upon their crops, but rather to depend upon your word, since it takes care of those who trust you.
Even the manna that survived the fire then melted in the warmth of the sun.
This shows that we must rise before dawn to pray to you,
because if we are ungrateful, our hope will melt like frost and flow away like dirty water.
Your decisions are difficult to explain, and people who have not been taught have followed the wrong path.

For example, those lawless Egyptians thought that your chosen people were under their power. But they themselves became prisoners in their very own homes for a long, dark night, because they were not under the protection of your eternal care.

<sup>ⓛ</sup> They thought that you had forgotten and that their secret sins were hidden behind a curtain of darkness, when gruesome creatures seemed to appear. Nowhere in their homes were they safe from the fear of terrifying noises and the frightening faces of gloomy ghosts.
On that miserable night, the darkness was so thick that neither flaming lamps nor bright stars could be seen.
And when lightning flashed, the fearsome sight was worse than the darkness.<sup>[17]</sup>
The Egyptians had depended on their magical powers and had boasted about their great wisdom, but all of this proved useless.
There were some who said they could cure the fears and worries of sick minds, but they themselves became sick with foolish fear.
Even if nothing else frightened them, they were terrified by the sounds of wild animals outside and by hissing snakes.
They were so frightened that they refused to open their eyes. But keeping them closed did not relieve their fears,
because evil people are cowards condemned by their own consciences, and whatever they fear becomes even more frightening.<sup>[18]</sup>
Fear takes over when people stop reasoning.
They no longer think straight, and their only hope is to deny the real source of their problems.
Night itself is powerless, since it comes from the powerless world of the dead. And yet the Egyptians slept restlessly on that night,
because of the horrible and unexpected nightmares brought on by the surrender of their souls to the forces of evil.
Every one of the Egyptians—including farmers and shepherds—fell prisoner to the fear of a darkness that was more difficult to escape than iron chains.

The slightest noise made them paralyzed with fear—the songs of birds in the trees, the rhythm of rushing water, the surprising crash of a rock, the hoofbeats of animals jumping about, the roar of lions, or even an echo in the mountains.
Everywhere else in the world, everyone went about their own business in broad daylight,

while these Egyptians were covered with a heavy blanket of darkness like the darkness of death that would soon capture them. But the trouble they brought upon themselves was an even heavier burden than the darkness.
<sup>ⓜ</sup> A bright light was shining on your chosen people. And although the Egyptians could not see your people, they could hear them and considered them lucky, because they were not suffering.
The Egyptians were thankful that the people they had abused were not abusing them in return, and so they begged your chosen people for forgiveness.<sup>[19]</sup>
Then, with a flaming fire at night and with the warmth of the sun during the day, you guided your people through places they had never traveled before.
Their enemies deserved to be prisoners of absolute darkness, because they had imprisoned your children, who would bring the light of your Law to the world.

The Egyptians wanted to kill the newborn sons of your chosen people, but Moses was rescued and survived. Then you decided to punish the Egyptians by killing their first-born sons and by drowning their army in the sea.
However, the night before our ancestors left Egypt, you warned them of what would happen. So they were able to celebrate, knowing that you would keep your promise
to rescue your obedient people and to destroy their enemies, just as they knew you would.
By these same events you punished your enemies and rewarded us, your chosen people.

At this time also, the wonderful ancestors of our holy nation secretly offered sacrifices to you, and all of them agreed to obey your Law, so that together they would share in the same blessings and dangers. Already they were singing hymns of praise to you,<sup>[20]</sup>
while their enemies cried bitter tears and made mournful sounds over the death of their children.
Every family suffered the same punishment, whether they were slaves or slave owners, ordinary people or royalty.
In one brief moment, the dearest child in each family died, leaving not even enough people to bury the dead.
<sup>ⓝ</sup> The Egyptians had been deceived by displays of magic. However, after the death of their first-born sons, they realized that we were the children of God.
<sup>ⓞ</sup> In the middle of the night—when all was peaceful and quiet—
your mighty word came down from your royal throne in heaven to attack a doomed land. Your word was like a fierce warrior
carrying a sharp sword and ready to obey your every command by killing people everywhere. When he stood on the earth, his head touched the sky.
Many of the Egyptians died a dreadful death that night, but not before nightmares and terrifying dreams showed them why they were being punished.
<sup>ⓟ</sup> For a while, you were angry with your people in the desert and killed many of them with a terrible disease.

Then a good man by the name of Aaron came to their rescue by using prayer and incense as a shield to protect your people from punishment for their sins, because he was a priest. So he stood up against your anger and ended the disaster.
He did not convince the crowd and end their suffering by his own strength or by weapons—he did it by reminding them of the wonderful agreements you had made with our ancestors.<sup>[21]</sup>
Piles of dead bodies were everywhere when Aaron succeeded in turning away your anger, and in keeping others from being struck down.

<sup>ⓠ</sup> And his long robe symbolized the entire universe, while the four rows of precious stones on his breastpiece stood for our glorious ancestors, and his turban<sup>[22]</sup> represented you, our majestic God.
At the sight of these, the death angel retreated in fear. A little of your anger was enough.
You remained angry with those worthless Egyptians and kept punishing them without mercy, because you already knew
how they would change their minds and chase your people, after hurriedly setting them free.
As a matter of fact, they made this foolish decision even before they had finished mourning for their dead. Then they started pursuing those very people they had begged and even forced to leave.
They were urged on by the destruction they deserved, and it made them forget what had already happened, so that they would be fully punished
by dying an unusual death and so that your people would have an amazing journey.
At your command the laws of nature were changed<sup>[23]</sup> to protect your children from harm.
A cloud guided them, and dry land appeared like a field of grass in the middle of the Red Sea,<sup>[24]</sup>
so that your people could see wonderful miracles and pass safely through under your protection.
They were like horses on an open range or like lambs leaping around, as they praised you for saving them.
And they still remembered what had happened in Egypt—the land was covered with gnats instead of animals, and the rivers were filled with frogs instead of fish.
Later, when they were starving in the desert and begged for something delicious to eat, you provided them with a special kind of bird,
by sending quails from the direction of the Mediterranean Sea.
Those sinful Egyptians had a terrible hatred for strangers, and so you punished them horribly, but not without first warning them with violent thunderstorms.

<sup>ⓡ</sup> Years earlier, the people of Sodom had refused to welcome strangers, and they were punished for what they did. But these Egyptians did much worse. They first welcomed our ancestors with a glorious celebration, and then after we had helped their nation, they made slaves of us, even though we were citizens like everyone else.

Those people of Sodom were struck blind, just as they reached the door of the home of that good man Lot, and they had to feel their way back through the darkness to their own homes. In the same way, these Egyptians were covered with deep darkness.<sup>[25]</sup>
Different tunes can be played on the same harp, though the strings remain the same. And this is similar to what happened in those days, as can be seen from the following examples.
Land animals became sea creatures, and sea creatures became land animals;
fire kept burning, even when it was covered with water,
and yet its flames did not destroy the flesh of humans or melt that delicate and dainty food called manna<sup>[26]</sup> that came down from heaven.

Our Lord, you have always
greatly honored your people.
You have never failed
to help them at any time
or in any place.

books.name: Sirach (Ecclesiasticus)
books.original_language_note: Written in Hebrew by Ben Sira (~180 BC); ~68% of Hebrew recovered from Cairo Genizah (1896) + Dead Sea Scrolls + Masada scroll

verses.text:
Many great and wise teachings have been handed down to us in the Scriptures, that is, in the Law, the Prophets, and the other writings.[1] We should praise earlier generations of Israel for writing and saving these books. And if you really love to study the Scriptures, it is very important for you to be able to explain them to others, whether by talking or by writing. That's why my grandfather Jesus studied the Scriptures until he became an expert, then wrote this book to help others learn about wisdom. So if you love to learn, you should study this book, and you will come closer and closer to living as the Law requires. But I ask you to read with a good attitude and not to be critical of my translation. I worked hard at it, so be understanding in those places where it isn't perfect. The meaning of any Hebrew book changes a little when it is translated, whether it is from the Law or the Prophets or is one of the other books in the Scriptures. I came to Egypt in the thirty-eighth year of King Euergetes, and I stayed there for as long as he was king.[2] While I was there, I studied copies of many books, and that's when I realized I should translate this one. Translating carefully takes a lot of hard work, and I spent many sleepless nights before my translation was completed. And now that it is finished, those who live outside of Judea can read this book to learn how best to obey God's Law in their own lives. ⓐ Only the Lord can give Wisdom,
and his Wisdom lasts forever.

And who but the Lord
can count the raindrops
or the days in eternity
or the sand on the seashore?

And who else can measure
the height of heaven
or the width of the earth
or the depth of the sea?

The Lord created Wisdom
long before anything else.

The Wisdom in God's commands
flows from his word in heaven
like streams from a spring.[3]

Who can understand
the deep thoughts of Wisdom
or how clever she[4] is?

Can anyone be taught
all of her knowledge?
Can anyone understand
how much she has learned?[5]

Only the Lord is that wise;
he is fearsome and majestic
as he rules from his throne.

ⓑ The Lord created Wisdom
and watched her grow,
then he gave her
to his creation—

to every living thing—
but especially to those people
who love him.[6]

If you fear the Lord,
you will be proud
of the honors you receive,
and you will wear happiness
like a crown.

And if you fear him,
your life will be long
and filled with joy.[7]

You will die happy,
blessed by the Lord
on the day of your death.

Respect and obey the Lord—
that's where Wisdom begins,
and she will stay
with faithful people
from the day of their birth.

She has lived among us humans
since the beginning of time,
and she will never desert
our descendants.

Respect and obey the Lord—
this is complete Wisdom.
Be drunk on the wine
of Wisdom,

ⓒ and let her fill your house
and your barns
with the harvest she brings.

Wisdom will give you
respect for the Lord,
to be worn like a crown
woven from the flowers
of peace and good health.[8]

Hold on to Wisdom,
and she will honor you
by sending knowledge
and complete understanding
like showers of rain.

ⓓ Wisdom is like a tree—
at its root is respect
for the Lord,
and its branches represent
a long lifetime.

Fear of the Lord
forces sin and anger
out of your life.[9]

It is never right to be angry
without a good reason,
because anger will start you
down the path to disaster.

Just be patient and stay calm
until your anger fades.

Then when the time is right
you can speak,
and others will tell
of your good sense.

Wisdom collects wise sayings,
but faithfulness to God
is disgusting to a sinner.

If you want lots of Wisdom
from the Lord,
then obey his commands.

Respect and obey the Lord,
and you will learn Wisdom;
be faithful and humble,
and he will be pleased.

Faithfully obey the Lord
and worship him
with all your heart.

Others are watching you,
so be careful—
don't say one thing
and then do something else.

If you boast and then fail,
you will be disgraced.
And if you only pretend
to worship the Lord,
he will bring you down
and show everyone
that you are a fake.

Students, if you decide
to worship and obey the Lord,
be ready to face problems.

Have firm self-control
and don't act too quickly
if trouble strikes.

Don't turn from the Lord,
but be faithful;
that's the way to succeed.

Accept everything that happens.
Be patient if others
humiliate you—

ⓔ humiliation tests people
as a furnace tests gold.[10]

The Lord will give his help,
if you depend only on him
and do right.

If you fear the Lord
and are patient,
he will show you mercy.
But if you turn away,
you will fall.

Put your trust in him,
and he will reward you.

Don't give up hoping
for good things, like mercy
and a life full of joy.

Look at past generations—
did the Lord desert those people
who trusted and feared him?
Or did he fail to answer those
who asked him for help?

The Lord is kind
and shows mercy
by forgiving our sins
and rescuing us from trouble.

But the Lord will send trouble
if you don't have the courage
to be faithful
and to stay away from sin.

If you are too afraid
to put your trust in him,
he will not protect you
when problems come.

And if you give up,
you will be in for trouble
when the Lord decides
to judge your life. *

ⓕ If you love the Lord
and respect him,
you will obey his commands.

You will try to please him
and to be completely faithful
to his Law.

If you fear the Lord,
you will prepare yourself
to worship him
with humility.

We pray, Lord, that you
will decide our future.
You are as merciful
as you are majestic,[11]
so don't leave our fate
in human hands.

Students, I have been
like a father to you,
and you will be safe
if you do what I say.

The Lord has told children
to honor and obey
their parents.

If you honor your father,
your sins will be forgiven;

show respect to your mother,
and you will be truly rich.

Honor your father—
then your own children
will make you happy,
and God will hear them
when they pray.

If you want to live a long time,
then you must obey the Lord
by respecting your parents;

serve them as if you
were their slave.

ⓖ If you speak to your father
with respect
and do what he asks,
he will bless you,

and your own family
will have success.
But if your mother
places a curse on you,
your family will face ruin.

You cannot get respect
by disgracing your parents.

What brings honor to them
also brings honor to you.

Help your father
as he grows old;
try not to upset him.

And when you are strong,
but his mind is fading,
don't make fun—
instead, be patient.

God sees your kindness,
and right away,
some of your sins
will be forgiven.

And if you later have troubles
because of your sins,
they will all melt away
in the warmth of your kindness,
like frost in the sunshine.

But abandoning your father
or making your mother angry
is as bad as cursing the Lord,
and so he will curse you.

Students, be humble
in your work,
and you will be loved
by God's people.

ⓗ The more powerful you are,
the more humble you must be
if you want the Lord
to be kind to you.

Many people are important
and famous,
but God gives his secrets
only to the humble.[12]

God is extremely powerful,
and he will accept praise only
from those who are not proud.

Don't try to learn things
you cannot understand.

ⓘ Instead, think about God's Law
and don't worry about secrets
God keeps to himself.

He has already shown you
matters beyond understanding,
and anything more
is none of your business.

Proud thoughts have led many
to turn from following God,
and evil ideas have ruined
the way they think.

Without eyes, you cannot see,
and without gaining knowledge
you can never get wisdom.

If you are stubborn,
you will end up in trouble,
and if you love danger,
it will kill you someday.

Those who are stubborn
are burdened with suffering,
and sinners carry
a heavy load of sins.

Evil has taken root
inside the arrogant,
and so when disaster strikes,
they cannot be rescued.

The wise always try to listen,
and they will pay attention
to a wise saying.

Money given to the poor
brings forgiveness for sins,
just as water
puts out a fire.

If you think that in the future
you might ever need help,
then repay other people now
when they do favors for you.

Students, if the poor
work for you,
don't cheat on their wages,
but pay them right away.

Don't disappoint the hungry
or upset the needy.

And if they are upset already,
don't make things worse
by being slow in giving them
what they need.

When people ask for help,
don't turn them down;
and if others are in need,
don't turn away.

If you pretend not to notice,
they will have good reason
to curse you.

And if their curses flow
from hearts you made bitter,
God, the Creator, will hear them
and do what they ask.

Be friendly to everyone
in the community
and show proper respect
to the town leaders.

When the poor greet you,
be polite and greet them
in return.

Rescue everyone
who suffers from injustice;
have the courage
to make the right decisions;

provide for orphans and widows,
as if they were your own
children or wife.
Then you will be a true child
of God Most High,
and he will love you more
than your own mother does.

If you study Wisdom,
you will become her child,
and she will help you
be successful.

If you love life
and want to find happiness,
love Wisdom enough
to get up early and study.

Hold tightly to her—
you will receive glory,
and the Lord will bless
everyone around you.

To obey her is to worship
the Holy Lord God,
and if you love Wisdom,
the Lord will love you.

Pay attention and obey Wisdom;
you will live in safety
and even rule nations.

Remain faithful to her,
and she will belong to you
and your descendants.

At first, Wisdom will test you
with her commands,
and you will walk in fear
along twisting pathways.
Her discipline
will bring suffering
until you are truly faithful.

But then she will return
straight to you,
bringing happiness
and telling her secrets.

But if you wander away,
she will let you go off
to your doom.

Be on your guard against evil,
but use every opportunity
for doing good.
And don't be ashamed
of who you are.

To be ashamed of your sins
leads to forgiveness
and honor,
but some other kinds of shame
are sins themselves.

If you play favorites
or let bullies push you around,
you will get hurt.

If you can make things right
by speaking up, then do so.
Don't let the opinions of others
make you hide your wisdom.[13]

If your wisdom and knowledge
are to make any difference,
you will have to speak.

Don't ever try
to make the truth seem false,
but always be humble
about things you don't know.

Don't try to hide your sins
from God—
it would be easier
to stop a river from flowing.

Never promise to obey a fool,
and don't play favorites
while a ruler is watching.

And even if you risk your life
fighting for truth,
the Lord God will be there,
fighting by your side.

Don't be arrogant
in what you say,
or slow and weak
in what you do.

When you are at home,
don't be fierce as a lion
or suspicious of servants.

ⓙ Don't hold out your hand
when it's time to receive,
then close your fist
when it's time to give.

Don't trust your wealth
and say,
“I don't need anyone's help.

I'm strong and smart enough
to get anything I want,

and no one has the power
to make me obey.”
Talk like that,
and God will punish you!

ⓚ And don't reply, “I sinned,
but God didn't punish me.”
God was being patient.

Never be so sure
of his forgiveness
that you keep on sinning

and say, “God is very kind,
and he will forgive me
even though I sin a lot.”
Yes, God is kind,
but he also gets angry
and punishes sinners.

Turn back to the Lord now—
don't wait until tomorrow.
If he gets angry,
he will quickly punish you
with death.

And wealth gained by cheating
won't save you from disaster.

Not every wind is good
for blowing away husks
from threshed grain.
And not every path leads
where you want to go.
But sinners will say anything
to get what they want.[14]

Stand up for what you believe,
and don't change what you say
from one time to the next.

Be willing to listen to anyone,
but think before you answer.

Then speak up, if you know
what to say;
and if not, just keep quiet.

Your words can bring you honor,
but they can also cause
your ruin and disgrace.

When you speak,
don't tear others down
or try to make them say
something wrong.
You would receive
severe punishment,
far worse than the shame
felt by thieves.

So don't make big mistakes,
or even little ones,

that turn you into an enemy
instead of a friend.
A reputation for being dishonest
will bring you nothing
but shame and insults.

Don't fall under the power
of evil desires.
They are burning flames
that will destroy you,[15]

and you will be left to wither,
like a tree with burned leaves
and scorched fruit.

Evil desires will destroy you,
and your enemies will laugh.

If you speak pleasantly
and politely,
you will make friends
and be welcome anywhere.

Be friendly with everyone,
but only listen to advice
from those few you can trust.

Make sure they are true friends
before you trust them,

because some will be friendly
when everything is fine,
but they won't help
when you have trouble.

If you argue with other friends,
they will become enemies
and tell about the argument
so you will look bad.

Still others will come to dinner
but not to help
if you have trouble.

In good times,
they will be so close,
that your servants
will have to obey them.

But if you lose your wealth,
they will disappear.

Keep your distance
from enemies
and don't be fooled
by false friends.
*

Loyal friends will protect you
with all their strength

and are worth more
than any other treasure.
*

They are even like medicine
that can save your life.
And here's how you can have
such loyal friends:

obey the Lord and choose friends
who also obey him.

Students, be disciplined
and learn Wisdom
when you are young,
and as your hair turns gray,
she will never desert you.

ⓛ Learning Wisdom isn't so hard.
It's like plowing a little
and planting a few seeds—
then a short time later
eating food from the harvest.

But to those who are fools
or have no discipline,
the job will seem too great,
and they will give up.

When Wisdom tests them,
they will toss her aside,
as if she were a stone
too heavy to carry.

Wisdom is hidden
from most people,
just as her name suggests.[16]

Pay attention, students—
don't reject my advice.

Become a slave to Wisdom,
with her chains fastened
around your neck and feet.

Carry her on your shoulders
and don't let those chains
make you angry.

Make up your mind to follow
and stay close to Wisdom
wherever she goes.

Search, and you will find her;
once she is yours,
hold her tightly.

Then she will give you
a peaceful and happy life.

Her chains on your feet
will become your protection,
and those on your neck
will turn into a royal robe,

decorated with gold jewelry
and tied with a purple cord.

You will wear Wisdom
like a beautiful robe
or like a crown
at a victory celebration.

Students, you are able
to discipline yourself
and learn Wisdom—
just put your mind to it!

Do you love to listen?
That's all it really takes
to gain Wisdom.

Spend time with older people
and stay close to those
who are wise.

When godly people speak,
pay attention, and memorize
every wise saying you hear.

If you know smart people,
visit them whenever you can,
until their welcome mat
wears thin from your feet.

ⓜ Never stop considering
God's laws and commands,
and he will strengthen your mind
with the Wisdom you want.

If you don't do evil,
then evil cannot harm you.

Always be fair with others,
and injustice will stay
away from you.

But those who farm
the fields of injustice,
will harvest seven times more
than they plant.

Don't ask the Lord
to make you a leader,
and don't ask the king
to give you honor.

Don't try to impress the Lord
with your goodness,
or to show off your wisdom
in front of the king.

Don't seek to be a judge
unless you have the strength
to do away with injustice.
And if you don't have courage
to stand up to the powerful,
you will ruin your good name.

Don't disgrace yourself
by sinning
against your community.

You won't escape punishment
if you commit a sin even once,
much less twice.

And do not think
that God Most High
will pardon you,
just because you have offered
a lot of sacrifices.

Don't let anything
discourage you from praying
or giving to the poor.

God can take away your success
as easily as he gave it,
so do not make fun of anyone
who is bitter from suffering.

Do not tell lies to a relative
or a friend

or anyone else.
No good ever comes
from telling lies.

In a town council meeting,
don't talk too much.
And in your prayers,
don't repeat the same things
over and over again.

Enjoy all kinds of hard work,
especially farming, because
God Most High created it.

Do not join others in sinning—
just think of how quickly
God can punish.

So be as humble as you can,
because those who are ungodly
will be eaten by worms
and burned by fire.

Don't betray a friend for money
or a relative for pure gold.[17]

If your wife is wise and good
and gracious,
she is more valuable than gold,
so do not divorce her.

If your workers or slaves
work hard and well,
don't mistreat them.

ⓝ If you have wise slaves,
love them as much
as you love yourself
and set them free
when you are supposed to.[18]

If you have cattle,
give them good care
and keep them as long
as they bring you a profit.

While your children are young,
teach them to obey you.

Do not let a daughter
always have her own way,
but protect her from men.

Finding a husband for her
is important, but be certain
to find one who is wise.

Don't divorce your wife
if she pleases you,
but if you can't stand her,
then don't trust her.

ⓞ Honor your father
with all your heart
and remember that your birth
gave your mother great pain.

How can you ever repay them
for the gift of life?

Fear the Lord
with all that you are,
and respect his priests.

Put all your strength
into loving your Creator
and be sure that his servants
make a good living.

Fear the Lord
and honor his priests
with what he has commanded.
Bring them the first part
of your harvest
and the sacrifice
to make things right.
Give them the shoulders
from other sacrifices
and all offerings and holy food
dedicated to the Lord.

The Lord will give you
complete success,
if you give to the poor.

So be generous to everyone,
especially to those
whose loved ones have died.[19]

Go to see them
and weep as they mourn.

If you visit the sick,
everyone will love you.

You can keep from sinning
by always reminding yourself
that you will someday die.

Don't fight those in power
if you have no chance to win.

Don't argue with those
who have plenty of gold—
they will drag you down
by bribing others
or by persuading the king
to see things their way.

And arguing with those
who talk too much
is like piling more wood
on a fire.

Don't laugh at those
who are crude,
unless you want to hear them
insult your ancestors.

If people are trying
to stop committing sins,
don't make them feel guilty;
remember that we all deserve
to be punished for our sins.

Don't dishonor old people—
the rest of us
are getting older too.

Never be happy
when someone dies.
Remember, all of us
must die someday.

When wise people speak,
pay attention, then study
what they have said.
You will learn discipline
and how to serve
those in power.

Listen when old people tell you
what they learned
from their ancestors.
Then you will understand
how to give the best answer
when one is needed.

Don't encourage sinners to sin;
they might blaze up like a fire
and you would get burned.

Don't argue with the arrogant—
they will try to turn
your own words against you.

Never lend to someone
who is stronger than you;
if you make such a loan,
don't count on being repaid.

Don't ever guarantee a loan
for more than you can afford,
and don't be surprised
if you have to repay
a loan you guaranteed.

Never sue judges—
their influence is so great
that they will always win.

Don't travel with those
who like danger.
They will do what they please
and cause you problems,
and their foolishness
might get you killed.

Don't start a fight
with hot-tempered people.
They don't care who they kill,
so don't travel with them
along deserted roads,
where you would be helpless
if they attacked.

Fools can't keep a secret,
so don't ask them for advice.

And when strangers are around
don't do anything
that you want kept secret—
you never know
who they might tell.

Do not discuss with just anyone
what you really think,
and don't let others
do favors for you.

ⓟ Love your wife,
but don't act jealous—
that will only invite her
to hurt you.

If you let yourself fall
under the spell of a woman,
she will walk all over you.

You had best stay away
from an immoral woman,
or you will be caught
in her traps.

Do not spend too much time
with a woman who sings
to entertain men—
she can use many tricks
to take control of you.

ⓠ Do not gaze too long
at a virgin—
if you talk her into having sex,
you will have to pay a fine
and marry her.

Don't let yourself be controlled
by a desire for prostitutes,
or you will lose everything
that you inherited.

So don't look for them;
stay off the lonely streets
where they are found.

Don't stare at a married woman
with a beautiful figure.
A woman's beauty
can set men on fire
and has led many astray.

Never have dinner or drinks
with someone else's wife.
To fall in love with her
is to fall to your death.

Don't desert old friends—
like bottles of aged wine,
they bring cheer
more than new ones.

Don't be jealous of sinners
who receive praise;
you never can tell
how their life will end.

Don't look for happiness
where ungodly people do.
You know they won't always
get away with their sins.

Stay away from those
who are able to kill you,
and you won't live in fear
of death.
To be near them is to walk
through a field full of traps
or across a ledge
high on the city walls—
make one false step
and your life is over.

Do your best to know
your close neighbors,
but only ask the wise ones
for advice.

Speak with the wise
about the Law
of God Most High.

Ask godly people over for dinner
and be proud
that you fear the Lord.

Craftsmen receive praise
if their work shows skill,
and the leaders of a nation
will be honored
for wise words.

But loud, reckless leaders
are hated and feared.

A wise judge teaches the laws
to the people,
and a smart ruler
gets things organized.

The people of a town
and its lower officials
usually follow the example
set by the judges and rulers.

A stupid king
destroys his nation,
but a city grows
if its leaders can rule well.

The Lord controls
all authorities on earth,
and he appoints the best rulers
for each situation and time.

God alone gives the success
that brings honor to those
who write the laws.

When neighbors harm you,
don't be angry or proud.

The Lord and all people
hate pride and become angry
with injustice.

A wealthy and arrogant nation
that fails to show justice
will soon be conquered.

Why are we humans so proud?
We are only dust and ashes,
and we easily lose
our health and strength.[20]

A long illness mocks the skill
of physicians,[21]
and even a king
can die without warning.

Then after our death,
our bodies are eaten
by wild animals and maggots
and worms.

We humans start to be arrogant
when our hearts turn away
from the Lord our Creator.

Sins are the source of pride,
and if we hold on to it,
our lives will be flooded
with more disgusting sins.
So the Lord destroys[22] the proud
by punishing them with disasters
they never dreamed possible.

ⓡ He removes powerful rulers,
replacing them with
the humble.

When God decides to give land
to a humble nation,
he pulls up others by the roots

and plows through their fields
until nothing remains.

The Lord destroys some of them
so completely, that no one
remembers they ever lived.

When the Lord created humans,
he did not intend for us
to be proud and angry.

We deserve honor
only when we fear the Lord,
but we should not be honored
if we break his laws.

A family should give honor
to its leader,
but God honors all
who fear him.

He accepts them,
but he rejects those
who are proud and stubborn.[23]

Fearing the Lord is something
to be proud of—
whether you are poor,
or rich and famous,
a Jew, or a Gentile.

Don't look down on those
who are wise but poor,
and don't honor sinners.

Honor always comes to judges
and people in power,
but anyone who fears the Lord
is even more deserving.

So if you are smart,
you will understand
when you see a master
serving a wise servant.

Don't spend your time thinking
of ways to avoid work,
and don't pretend to be well off
if you are short of money.

It's better to work
and have more than enough
than to boast and go hungry.

Students, be humble
but remember to have
proper self-esteem.

Who will think you are innocent
if you call yourself guilty?
And who will give you honor
if you refuse
to respect yourself?

The poor receive honor
if they are educated,
while the wealthy are praised
because they have money.

So when the poor become rich
they will be praised more,
but the disgrace of the wealthy
will become much worse
if they lose their money.

Those in power
always make room
for someone wise and humble.

Do not praise or despise anyone
on the basis of their looks.

The honeybee is very small,
but it makes
the sweetest food.

Don't boast about your clothes
or act important
when you are honored.
Only the Lord does things
truly worthy of praise,
but he keeps them hidden
from our sight.

Kings often lose their power
to those who had seemed
to be nobodies,

while honored rulers
are captured and disgraced.

Find out the truth
before you criticize.

Don't interrupt others—
hear them out,
then give your answer.

If it's none of your business,
then don't argue with them,
and stay away from sinners
when they discuss what to do.

Students, don't let yourself
become too busy.
If you do, you will sin
and not find success
or escape trouble.

Some people work all day long
as hard as they can,
but they keep getting poorer.

Others are poor and weak;
they work slowly
and always need help.
But the Lord shows kindness

and to everyone's surprise,
he lifts them from poverty
and gives them honor.

All things, whether good or bad,
come from the Lord.
He gives life and riches
or takes them away.

The Lord gives wisdom
by teaching us
to understand his Law.
He helps us love each other
and do right.

Sinners are dishonest
and live in darkness,
proud of their evil
from the day they are born,
and so evil will stay with them
until the day they die.[24]

But the Lord gives success
to his faithful people
and blesses them with gifts
that last forever.

ⓢ You can become rich,
if you work hard
and never spend any money.
But then what?

When you finally retire
to enjoy what you own,
you soon may die,
and then your wealth
will belong to others.

When you agree to do work,
stay busy and don't quit.

Don't be surprised
at what sinners do;
trust the Lord and keep working,
because he can make you rich
in a moment's time.

Suddenly, he will reward you
and bless you with prosperity,
if you are faithful to him.
*

So don't say, “I already have
everything I need—
what more could the Lord
do for me?
Nothing can harm me now!”

When people are well off,
they never mention
how needy they once were,
and when they have trouble,
the good times are forgotten.

But at the end of life,
the Lord will pay us back
for what we have done.

Pleasant memories fade
after an hour of pain,
but the way that you lived
is made clear by how you die

and by what kind of children
you leave behind.
So don't praise anyone
until they are dead.

Don't let just anyone
come to your house.
Dishonest people will trick you,

as bird hunters use decoys
to trap quails.
They watch you like spies,
waiting for some mistake

or for a chance
to make your good deeds
seem evil.

One spark can start a fire,
and one sinner's evil plan
can end in murder.

Watch out for the schemes
of those who do evil,
or they may ruin
your good name.

And if you let foreigners
come to live in your home,
they will cause trouble
and persuade you to accept
their customs and gods.[25]

ⓣ Do good to those
who deserve it,
and they will thank you.

Be kind to the godly,
and they—or God Most High—
will reward you.

But you will have no success
if you keep doing evil
and refuse to give
to the poor.
*

Help those who are humble
and faithful to God,

but don't help the ungodly.
If you give food to sinners,
they will become strong
and overpower you.
Do a good deed for them,
and they will reward you
by wronging you twice.

But God Most High
hates ungodly sinners
and will punish them.

Yes, give to good people,
not to sinners.

In hard times you will discover
your true friends
and your real enemies.

Even your enemies act friendly
when you are well off,
but only true friends stay
when trouble strikes.

Never trust your enemies—
their evil will attack you
like rust

eating away
at an unpolished mirror.[26]
So be on guard against them,
even if they bow down
and act humble.

Don't make them your partners,
or they will push you aside
and take over.
Then you will know I was right,
and you will feel the sting
of my words.

If you try to charm snakes
or to tame wild animals,
who will take pity
when you get bitten?

In the same way,
no one will take pity
if you are friendly with sinners
and start sinning yourself.

Enemies act loyal for a while,
but they won't stand by you
when you need help.

They tell you how much
they want to be your friends,
all the while plotting
to put you in your grave.
They weep when you are sad,
but they will try to kill you
the first chance they get.

If you are struck by disaster,
they pretend to help
but pull you down instead.

Then they laugh and sneer,
making vulgar hand signs,
showing what kind of friends
they really are.

Can you stay humble
if your friends are proud?
Only if you can handle tar
and stay clean!

And watch out if your friends
are rich and powerful.
You cannot match their strength,
and you might be crushed,
just like a clay jar
struck by an iron pan.

The rich oppress
and insult the poor,
then demand an apology!

The rich will try to use you,
but if you need help,
don't bother to ask.

When they come to visit you,
they will soak up
what little you have.

If they need your help,
they smile and act kind
and even ask how they
can be of service.
But don't be fooled—
it's all lies!

They will invite you to dinner,
but in the long run you'll pay
three times what it cost.
And when you have nothing left,
they will laugh and sneer
and keep their distance.

So be smart and careful,
not deceived and humiliated.

Important people
will want you around,
if you don't try too hard
to be their friend.

Push yourself on them,
and you will face rejection;
act cold, and they will forget
that you are alive.

Don't try to be their equal
or trust them when they
have long talks with you.
They are smiling,
but you are being tested.

Those who tell secrets are cruel
and would just as soon hurt you
or send you to prison.

Be careful! Don't risk disaster
by sharing your secrets.

Wake up and pay attention!
Every day of your life,
love the Lord and pray
that he will protect you.[27] *
Animals and people
love their own kind.

Wolves and lambs
have about as much in common
as sinners and God's people.

Hyenas and dogs
are natural enemies,
just like the poor
and the rich.

Desert lions will always feast
on wild donkeys,
and the rich will gobble up
the needy.

The rich and proud
consider the poor and humble
to be disgusting.

When the rich start to stumble
their friends lend a hand,
but let the poor fall down,
and their friends pretend
not to know them.

When the rich are in trouble,
many will offer to help
and will even make excuses
when the rich insult them.
But let the poor get in trouble,
and all they get is criticism,
even if they speak wisely.

When the rich speak,
everyone listens
with great respect.
But if the poor speak,
everyone asks, “Just who
do they think they are?”
And if the poor start to trip,
people give them a push.

It's good to have wealth
if you got it honestly,
but don't be ungodly and claim
that being poor is evil.

With one look at your face
anyone can see
if you are happy or sad.

A smile shows you are happy,
and a tired look may mean
you have been trying too hard
to think up a proverb.

You will be happiest
if you keep from sinning
and saying stupid things,

and if you have no reason
to feel guilty
and have not given up hope. *

What's the use of being rich
if you don't enjoy
spending money on yourself?

Are you just saving it
so others can live in luxury
after you are dead and gone?

Those who refuse to enjoy
a few things money can buy,
probably won't give much
to someone in need.

They spend nothing,
and punish themselves
with the greatest misery. *

If they do a good deed,
it is only by accident,
and the end of their life
shows how evil they were:

they pretended not to notice
others in need;

they were never happy
with their own fair share;
and by taking
what belonged to others,
their souls shriveled away.

They wouldn't even give
their families enough to eat!

Be good to yourself
according to what you have
and be generous in your giving
to the Lord.

You cannot know the time
for you to die,
and when it arrives,
death will not wait,

so now is the time
to help your friends
with generous gifts.

Every day, you should enjoy
the good things you want,

because after you are gone,
others will divide up everything
you worked so hard to get.

Give and accept gifts,
and treat yourself well,
because there is nothing good
in the world of the dead.

Every living creature wears out
like old clothes
and obeys the ancient law
that says, “You will die.”

Generations pass away,
and others are born
to take their place,
just as new leaves
on a tall tree
replace those that fall.

Everything you ever made
will someday turn to dust,
then even the memory of you
will disappear.

ⓤ Wisdom always blesses those
who learn how to reason
by thinking about her.

They consider
what Wisdom has done
and the secrets she knows.

They wait for her
like hunters along a path,
then they follow her

home,
where they peek
through the windows
and listen at the door.
*

They set up camp
so close to her house,
that their tent pegs
are hammered into its walls.

There is no better place to live
than in her home—

like a shade tree, she protects
the children of her followers

from the heat,
and they live in a place
of great beauty.

If you fear the Lord
and obey his Law,
you will find Wisdom
when you search.

She will care for you
like your own mother
and welcome you, as a bride
welcomes her husband.

And instead of something
to eat and drink,
she will give you wisdom
and understanding.

You can depend on her
to keep you from disgrace.

She will tell you what to say,
and you will be honored
because of your wise speeches
in town meetings.

Your life will be happy,
and you will be remembered
for all time.

But fools and sinners
will never find Wisdom.

She won't come near the proud
or enter the mind of a liar.

That's why the Lord
refuses to accept praise
from sinners.

Only the wise can offer
acceptable praise.

ⓥ The Lord hates it when you say
that he forced you to sin.

And he doesn't like sinners,
so don't claim he tempted you
to become one.

The Lord and all who fear him
hate disgusting sins.

The Lord created us humans,
and from the very beginning,
he gave us the ability
to choose how we will live.

You are able to obey his Law
if you really want to,
and you can please him
by being faithful.
*

Life and death are as different
as fire and water,

and the Lord will give you
whichever you choose.

The Lord is extremely wise
and tremendously powerful.
He can see all things—

every deed that we do—
and if we fear him,
he will watch over us.

He has neither commanded
nor given permission for anyone
to be evil or to sin.

Ungodly children are worthless
and are nothing to desire
or to celebrate.

You can have lots of children,
but they will bring joy
only if they fear the Lord.

Having lots of ungodly children
won't help you in old age—
you will outlive them all.
One good child,
or even no children at all,
is better than a thousand
who are ungodly.

A family that disobeys the law
can make a city a ghost town,
but one smart person can fill
an empty city with people.

Here are but a few
of the important things
I have seen and heard:

If a small group of sinners
sets the Lord's anger ablaze,
then it will be worse by far
if a whole nation is sinful.

ⓦ Long ago, the Lord refused
to forgive the mighty giants
who rebelled against him.

And he so hated the arrogance
of the people of Sodom,[28]
that he destroyed them.

They were doomed
because of their sins,
and the Lord showed no mercy
as he swept them away.

Nor did he have pity
on six hundred thousand
stubborn Assyrian soldiers
who attacked his people.

Even if only one person
refused to obey the Lord,
I would be surprised if he
did not punish that one.
The Lord loves to show mercy
and to use his mighty power
to forgive his people,
but when his anger overflows
against sinners,

he uses that same power
to punish them.
Everyone will receive
either mercy or punishment
as each deserves.

The Lord refuses to let sinners
profit from their crimes,
and he will reward his people
if they patiently wait.

He remembers every good deed
and gives everyone
what they deserve.

The Lord wanted everyone
to know his mighty power,
so he put a stubborn heart
in the king of Egypt.

But the Lord also wants everyone
to know about his mercy,
so he separated those
who have his light
from those who remain
in darkness.[29]

Never say to yourself,
“The Lord cannot see me.
He doesn't even know my name.
There are just too many people
for him to keep me in mind.

One glance from him
causes quaking and shaking
in the earth and the sky,
in the highest heaven
and the deepest sea,

in the mountains
and the foundations
of the earth.

But no human can understand
how his mighty power works.

Most of what God does
cannot be seen,
just like the wind
in a violent storm.

So who will tell him
when I do what is right?
And who has the patience
to wait for him
to keep his promises?”

That is how fools speak—
they cannot think straight
and have no understanding.

Listen, students;
pay attention,
and you will learn.

I will train you and tell you
exactly what I know.

In the beginning, when the Lord
created the world,
he gave each thing
its proper place.

He designed the forces of nature
to last for all time—
they never tire or get hungry
or stop working.

They don't get in the way
of each other,
and they will never
disobey him.

After God created the earth,
he looked it over
and filled it with creatures
that were good;

animals of all kinds
covered the ground,
and when they die,
they return to it.

ⓧ The Lord created us humans
from the soil,
and he makes us return there
when we die.

Our lives are short,
but the Lord has given us
power to rule the earth.

We were made to be like him
and were given power
much like his own.

He let us rule all animals
and made them afraid of us.

We were given the five senses
of sight and hearing,
taste, touch, and smell;
and we were also given
the ability to think
and to interpret
what our senses tell us.[30]

He gave us tongues for speaking,
eyes for seeing,
and minds for thinking
and for making choices.

ⓨ Our minds are filled
with knowledge and Wisdom
that come from the Lord,
and we understand the difference
between right and wrong.

The Lord made us fear him
so that we would know
his mighty power.

Now we will tell others
about his powerful deeds

and praise his holy name.[31]
*

The Lord gave to our ancestors
laws that bring knowledge
and life,

and his agreement with them
will last forever.

Our ancestors saw
the glorious power of the Lord
and heard his mighty voice

warning them about injustice
and commanding them how
to treat each other.

The Lord watches us and knows
our every deed.

Most people do wrong
from an early age
and have a cruel heart
that they cannot change.[32]

The Lord placed rulers
over all the nations,
but he himself rules Israel.

He raised our people Israel
as his own first-born child,
with loving care,
but also with discipline.

He can see our actions
as easily as we see the sun.

That's the reason
we can't hide our sins—
he can see them all.

But he knows what we are like,
and so he shows mercy
and never deserts us.[33]

The Lord values
our gifts to the poor
as much as we value fine jewelry
or a most prized possession.

Later, he will punish the wicked
as they deserve,

but he accepts all those
who turn from sinning,
and he encourages everyone
whose hope is slipping away.

ⓩ Stop sinning and return
to the Lord;
your punishment will be less
if you pray to him.

So turn back to the Lord
and hate what he hates.

ⓐ Only the living
can thank the Lord—
no one in the world of the dead
can praise him;

they no longer exist
and cannot offer thanks.
But those who are alive
and healthy
can still sing praises to him.

The Lord will show great mercy
and forgive all of your sins
if you turn back to him.

But we cannot live forever;
we are human and find it hard
to turn to God.

If a thick dark cloud can hide
the bright rays of the sun,
then evil can just as easily
darken our minds.

We are merely dust and ashes,
but God commands the armies
of the highest heaven.

The Lord, who lives forever,
created all things,

and he alone
is always faithful.
He is the only true God;

one signal from his hand
and the universe obeys.
The Lord, its mighty King,
decides what we
are allowed to use,
and what he will keep
for himself alone.[34]

We cannot understand
or tell other people
what God's power has done,

because we cannot measure it
or count the times
he has shown us mercy.

Nor can we make that number
larger or smaller.
We just stand in amazement
at the things he has done,

and at the end of a lifetime
of studying them,
we are still confused.

As for us humans, what are we?
Do we have any purpose?
What is good for us
and what is bad?
Few of us live a hundred years,

which is a very short time
when compared to forever,
like a drop of ocean water
or a grain of sand
along a beach.

That's why the Lord
patiently shows us mercy,
time after time.

He is eager to forgive,
because he knows that we
are condemned to die.

We show mercy to our friends,
but the Lord has mercy
on everyone.
He corrects and disciplines
and teaches us,
and leads us back to him
like a shepherd
leading a flock of sheep.

If we pay attention
when he corrects us,
and if we study his laws,
he will be merciful.

Students, be careful
not to ruin a gift
by criticizing the person
you give it to.

Like a refreshing dew
in the heat of summer,
saying the right thing
can mean more than giving

even a generous gift.
But a truly gracious person
will be ready with both.

So don't be a fool.
People's eyes will sparkle,
if your generosity is sincere
and you speak with kindness.

Know what you're talking about
before you start speaking
and look after your health
before it fails.

If you turn from sin now—
before you are judged—
you will find forgiveness.

Be humble and show that you
have turned from sin,
and you won't be punished
with illness.

If you promise the Lord a gift,
give it now.
Don't wait until you are dying
to keep your promise,

and don't make promises to him
unless you are ready
to keep them.
Don't test the Lord's patience.

When your time comes to die
and face him as judge,
if he is angry, he will refuse
to even look at you.

If you have grown wealthy
and have plenty of food,
remember when you yourself
were poor and hungry.

Between sunrise and sunset
is plenty of time for the Lord
to turn everything around.

The wise are always careful,
and they make sure to do right
when others are sinning.

Smart people recognize Wisdom,
and they praise everyone
who finds her.

If you study the writings
of the wise,
you will learn enough Wisdom
to share with others.

[35]Control your desires;
don't let them control you.

If you allow yourself to enjoy
everything you want,
you will look like a fool,
and your enemies will laugh.

Do not live in luxury
that you cannot afford,
or you will become poor.

If you have nothing,
don't borrow money
to give a banquet.

A worker who is always drunk
will never get rich,
and people who are careless
with small things
will gradually slip
into poverty.

Even a wise man can be deceived
by wine and women,
and men who visit prostitutes
are taking terrible risks.

Death will come suddenly,
then their bodies will rot
and be eaten by worms.

If you trust people too quickly,
you aren't very smart.
If you sin, you harm yourself.

And if you are happy about evil,
you will be judged guilty.

Trouble doesn't stay
where gossip is hated.

It doesn't cost you a thing
to forget a rumor.

So don't tell it to your enemies
or even your friends,
unless you would be doing wrong
by not speaking up.

People may be listening
and watching,
and if you repeat gossip,
they might start hating you.

Treat rumors as secrets
to be kept until you die;
they can even make you feel
as though you might explode,
but be brave—you won't.

It's harder for a fool
not to repeat gossip,
than for a woman in labor
not to give birth

or a soldier to ignore an arrow
sticking out of his leg. *

Talk to friends or neighbors
if you hear that they
have wronged you
or said something to harm
your reputation.

If they didn't do it,
you will find out,
and if they did,
they won't do it again.

Talk to them and get the truth,
because you should not believe
everything you hear.

We are all guilty
of saying things
that we didn't really mean.

So don't threaten your friends
before you talk with them,
and always obey the Law
of God Most High.

ⓑ If you fear the Lord,
he will accept you,
and if you are wise,
he will give you his love.

If you learn and follow
the Lord's commands,
you will please him,
and he will allow you to eat
fruit from the tree
that lets you live forever.[36]

Fearing the Lord
and obeying his Law
are really the same
as having wisdom.

If slaves refuse to do
what they are told,
their master will be angry
even if they later obey.

Sin isn't the source of Wisdom,
and so sinners cannot give
good advice.

Some people are clever
in doing disgusting things;
others are fools only because
they never learned wisdom.

It is better to fear the Lord
and not be so intelligent,
than to be very smart
and to break his Law.

Some people are highly skilled
at being unfair
and can even twist your kindness
to help them win
their case in court.

Some dishonest people
act like they are mourning,

hiding their faces from you
and pretending not to listen.
But they will use your words
to take advantage of you
when no one is looking.

They may not be able
to do so now,
but they will wrong you
the first chance they get.

Merely by looking at people
you know what they are like.
And the first time you meet,
you can tell if someone
has good sense

by what they wear
and how they walk or laugh.

If you are smart,
you will know
when to keep quiet
and when to criticize.

It is better to speak up
than to let anger
eat away at you.

When you are wrong, admit it,
and you will save yourself
a lot of trouble.

If a man is unable to have sex,
he can't be forced to do so;
but it seems harder to force
some people to do right.

People who talk too much
are not well liked,
but people who keep quiet
are often considered wise.

Their silence may just mean
they have nothing to say.
Or it may mean they are waiting
for the right time to speak,

and that is true wisdom.
But fools who always talk
about themselves
are never quiet.

They are disgusting,
and others who grab for power
also earn our hatred.

Sometimes our troubles
end up helping us,
and other times, good luck
turns out to be bad.

Often a gift
isn't really helpful,
and when some people give,
they expect to be repaid
twice what the gift is worth.

If you search for glory
you may lose what you have,
but success can come to those
who had humble beginnings.

What seems to be a bargain
may cost you seven times
what it is worth.

People love to hear
wise people speak.
But fools, though polite,
are still fools,

and you would be better off
without gifts from them,
because they will expect you
to give even more in return.

A small gift, they think,
gives them the right
to criticize—loudly.
Today, they make a loan;
tomorrow, they ask
for their money back.
I cannot stand people like this!

Fools think they have no friends
and that no one appreciates
their good deeds.
They invite you over for a meal
but believe that you will later
say bad things about them.

They deserve to be mocked,
and few people
will pass up the chance.

It is better to slip and fall
than to suffer a slip
of the tongue.
And something that small
can bring sudden disaster
to those who are evil.

A rude person is disgusting,
just like the dirty stories
ignorant people tell.

Everyone ignores a proverb
repeated by a fool,
because fools never choose
the right one.

You may be too poor
to commit some sins,
but you can sleep at night
with a clear conscience.

Have a little self-respect
and don't act like a fool,
or you may risk disaster.

Broken promises turn friends
into enemies,
