so do not make promises
that you cannot keep.

The ignorant are always lying,
not knowing that telling a lie
leaves an ugly scar.

Liars are worse than thieves,
but both are on the road
to destruction.

Telling lies brings disgrace
and shame that never ends.

[37]If you are wise
and want to succeed,
you will try to please
those in power.

If you plow and plant,
you will harvest a crop,
and if you please the powerful,
they will overlook
your mistakes.

Favors and gifts keep the wise
from seeing the truth
and muzzle the mouths of those
who criticize.
*

Wisdom kept secret
and wealth never used
do not help anybody,

but a fool does best
to keep foolishness hidden.

Students, if you
are sinning, stop.
Ask God to forgive you.

Sin is a deadly snake
with lion's fangs.
Stay away! If you come close
you will be bitten.

Lawlessness kills
like a sword with two edges
swung this way and that.

If you are too shy
or proud and arrogant,
you can lose your wealth
and even your home.

ⓒ The prayers of the poor
go straight to God's ear,
and he quickly answers.

If you hate correction,
you will become a sinner,
but if you take it to heart,
you will obey the Lord.

Good speakers can be famous,
but people with common sense
will catch every mistake.

Borrowing to build your house
is like gathering stones
to mark your own grave.

A meeting of evil people
is a bundle of straw,
where a small flame
ends in a blazing fire.

For a sinner, the road of life
is smooth, but it slopes down
to the world of the dead.

Fear the Lord in every way,
and you will become wise;
Control your thoughts,
and you can obey his Law.

You have to be smart to learn,
but some kinds of smartness
only make other people bitter.

The knowledge of the wise
is an overflowing river,
and their advice
is a life-giving spring.

The mind of a fool
is a leaking jar
that holds nothing for long.

When the wise hear a proverb,
they give it praise
and add more to it;
but fools merely laugh
and forget it.

Listening to a fool is tiring,
like carrying a heavy backpack
on a journey,
but listening to someone smart
is refreshing.

In a town meeting, people look
for some common sense,
and when they hear it,
they will think about
what was said.

Knowledge means nothing
to ignorant fools,
and wisdom is useless
as a burned-down house.

Fools think learning puts chains
on their hands and feet,

and they laugh at it loudly.
But smart people just smile,

because they know that learning
is a golden bracelet.

Fools will push past you
into your home,
but the wise will wait
at your door.
*

They are polite and will not try
to see inside
or to hear what is going on,

because that would be rude
and shameful.

Some people won't stop talking
about things that are none
of their business.
But sensible people
weigh each word
before it is spoken.

In a fool, the mind thinks
only after the mouth speaks,
but in a wise person,
the mind controls the mouth.

The ungodly fall under any curse
that they try to place
on their enemies.

If you spread gossip,
your character will be ruined
and your neighbors
will hate you.

Lazy people
are like stones
that everyone spits on,

or a pile of manure
that you have to walk around.
If you touch them,
you want to wash your hands.

A father is ashamed if his son
isn't well behaved,
and a disobedient daughter
is even worse.

If a daughter is sensible
she will get a good husband,
but a shameless girl
only brings her father pain.

If a woman insults her father
and her husband,
they will be disgraced
and in return
will humiliate her.

Picking the wrong time
to criticize your children
is like playing happy music
at a funeral,
but punishment and correction
are always wise.

Bring up your children well
and no one will guess
you were poor as a child.

But rude and arrogant children
are a disgrace
to a good family.[38]

Just try to wake someone
from deep sleep,
to fix shattered pottery,
or to teach fools!

Tell them a story,
and they will doze off;
and afterwards, they will ask,
“So what's your point?”

Mourn for the dead,
who rest in darkness,
but weep even more for fools,
doomed to live
in the darkness of stupidity.

ⓓ After a death,
you mourn seven days,
but you mourn for ungodly fools
until the day they die.

To avoid lots of problems
and have a peaceful life,
stay away from stupid people
and do not talk to them.
When a wet dog shakes itself,
water flies everywhere,
but humans who have no sense
splatter everyone nearby
with troubles.

A fool is a heavier burden
than a load of lead,

or a bag of sand or salt,
or a lump of iron ore.

An earthquake cannot loosen
a wooden beam set firmly
in the walls of a building,
and no crisis can shake you up
if you have prepared your mind
and decided what you must do.

A mind that thinks
and reasons well
is like a smooth wall
decorated with carvings.[39]

But foolish cowards
will not stand firm
when fearsome disaster hits,
just as small rocks are blown
from the top of a vineyard wall[40]
by the wind.

Poke someone in the eye
and they will shed tears;
but wound their heart
and they will show deep pain.

You can throw stones
to frighten birds away,
and you can end a friendship
by tossing insults.

Threaten a friend with a sword,
and you can still hope
the friendship will heal.

And you can argue with friends
and later, win them back.
But if you are arrogant
and insult them,
if you tell their secrets
or harm them
when they trusted you,
they will be gone for good.

Earn the trust of your neighbors
when they are poor,
and if they become wealthy
you can celebrate with them.
Be a true friend
when they have troubles,
and later they will share
their inheritance with you.

When you smell smoke
you will soon see flames,
and when you hear insults,
you will soon see murder.

I will never be ashamed
to protect my friends,
and I will always be there
when I am needed.

But if they turn and harm me,
all who find out
will be on their guard
against them.

Our Lord, help me to be careful
in everything I say,
so that my mouth
will not be my downfall.

You are my Father
and rule my life—
don't let my mouth
control my destiny
and bring me down.

Please send wisdom
to whip my thoughts
and train my mind,
to tell me when I have sinned,
and to correct me
when I am wrong.

Otherwise, I will sin more often
and make more mistakes,
allowing my enemies
to destroy me and celebrate.

Our Lord, you are God;
you gave me life.
Don't let me look with arrogance
at other people.

Help me not to want things
that are not rightfully mine.

And don't let me be controlled
by shameless desires
for food or sex
or anything else.

[41]Students, if you listen to me
and control what you say,
your words cannot trap you.

Sinners are caught
when they talk too much,
and the arrogant are tripped up
because they insult others.

ⓔ Don't get in the habit
of using God's name
when you make promises.

Every time you do this,
God starts watching you closely
as a master watches a slave,
and he will notice all your sins
and punish you for them.

The wicked make promises
with God as their witness,
but when a promise is broken,
they just explain
that it was made by mistake.
Or they forget it on purpose,
which means that they
are twice as guilty.
And if they lied in God's name,
they will not be forgiven
and their family is doomed. *

Vulgar talk is sinful
and deadly.
Godly people do not enjoy sin,
so they don't use evil words,
and I pray that none
will ever be heard in Israel.

Avoid sin
by training your mouth
not to use bad language,

and always remember
your parents will be honored
if you behave properly.
Then when you meet
with important people,
you won't get excited
and start talking like a fool
and end up wishing
you had never been born.

As long as you are in the habit
of insulting others,
you will always be a fool.

Three kinds of sinners
bring down God's anger:
first are those who always burn
with desire for sex.
Their desire is a flame
that must burn itself out.
Next are those
who won't stop having sex
with a near relative.
God will send fire
to destroy them!

Last are those who have sex
with anyone they can
and will do so
until they die.

A man unfaithful to his wife
says to himself,
“It's dark outside,
and no one can see me here
inside the house.
Why worry, anyway?
God will forgive me.”

People like that are only afraid
of being seen by others
and forget that God's eyes shine
ten thousand times brighter
than the sun.
He can see every hidden place
in our lives.

He knew all things
before he created them,
just as he knows them now.

So unfaithful husbands
will be caught
when they suspect nothing
and will be punished
in the city streets.

If an unfaithful wife
has a child by another man,
she will be punished.

She has broken God's Law
and sinned against her husband
by having sex with another man
and giving birth to his child.

She will be put on trial
in a town meeting,
and she will be punished.
Even her children will suffer,

because they will be rejected
by the people of the town.

Her shame will never be erased,
and people will curse
when they remember her.

But they will be reminded
that it is always best
to fear the Lord
and obey his commands.

* Wisdom sings her own praise
and tells her greatness

to those who worship the Lord
and to the Lord's armies
in heaven.

And this is what she says:
I came from the mouth
of God Most High
and like a mist I moved
over the earth.[42]

ⓕ Highest heaven was my home,
and my throne was a cloud.

Only I could travel
around the horizon
and walk in ocean depths.

I ruled every nation,
the land, and the sea.

But where could I find
a place to settle down?
In what nation should I live?

Then the Creator of the world
gave me a command
telling me to set up my tent
among the descendants of Jacob,
the people of Israel.

He created me ages ago,
before time began,
and I will never die.

I served in his sacred tent,
and later in the temple
in Zion.[43]

He gave me a resting place
in Jerusalem, the city he loves,
and this is where I rule.

Here, I put down roots
among the glorious people
who belong to the Lord.

I grew tall, like a cedar tree
in Lebanon
or a cypress on Mount Hermon;

like a palm tree at En-Gedi,
or the roses in Jericho;
like a beautiful olive tree
in a field,
or like an evergreen.

My perfume smelled sweet
like the spices cinnamon and cane
mixed with fine myrrh,[44]
or like smoke in the sacred tent
from the incense of galbanum,
onycha, and stacte.[45]

I spread out my branches,
beautiful and graceful,
like a giant oak,

and like a grapevine,
they grew buds and blossoms,
and finally clusters of rich,
sweet fruit.

Beautiful love is my child,
and so are fear and knowledge
and hope that trusts God,
and he gives me and my children
to his own people.[46]

So come, if you want,
and enjoy my fruit
until you are full.

I am sweeter than honey
straight from the honeycomb,
and the sweet taste will remain
even when you have finished.

But the more of me
that you eat and drink,
the more you will want.

Obey me and let me work
in your life,
and you will never sin
or be disgraced.

The wisdom of God Most High
is the Book of the Law
of Moses,
the agreement God made
with our ancestors
and gives to each new generation
as an inheritance.

Always stay close
to the Lord All-Powerful, and he
will give you strength.
The Lord is the only true God—
he alone can rescue.[47] *

God's wisdom and understanding
overflow from his Law
just as in early springtime,[48]
the Tigris and Pishon Rivers,

the Euphrates and the Jordan,
overflow their banks.

God's teachings flood the land[49]
like the Nile River[50]
in early fall.[51]

The first human did not know
Wisdom very well,
nor will the last one,

because her thoughts
are wider than the ocean,
and her advice is deeper
than the sea.

I thought of myself
as a small canal
from the river of God's Wisdom
to my garden,

bringing water for my flowers
and fruit trees.
But soon this canal
became wide as a river
and then as the sea.

And so, I will teach wisdom
and make it shine like sunrise,
clearly seen from far away.

My words flow quickly,
and like a prophet
I will leave them
for generations not yet born.

You see, my work hasn't been
for myself alone,
but for everyone who desires
to find Wisdom.

Three things
make me happy
and are beautiful to the Lord
and to humans:
a family that agrees,
neighbors who are friends,
and a happy marriage.

But I hate three kinds of people
and the way they live:
the poor that brag,
the rich that tell lies,
and the old that are foolish
and unfaithful in marriage.

If you don't start learning
when you are young,
you will have no wisdom
when you grow old.

Good sense and sound advice
are beautiful in those
whose hair is now gray.

Wisdom and understanding
are just right for the old
and honorable.

They have seen so many things,
but they only boast
that they fear the Lord.

Ten kinds of people
can be called truly happy:
those who enjoy their children,
and those who live long enough
to see their enemies fall;

men who have sensible wives,
farmers that do not hitch
a donkey and an ox
to one plow,[52]
people who don't sin
by what they say,
and servants whose masters
have as much ability
as the servants do;

people with common sense,
and those who speak to others
who are really listening.
*

The person who finds wisdom
finds great happiness,
but happiest of all is the one
who fears the Lord,

because fearing him
is more important
than anything else.

And it is the first step
in loving him,
just as having faith
is the first step in becoming
one of his followers.[53]

The breaking of your heart
by an evil woman
is the most painful
of all injuries.

No suffering seems worse
than when an enemy hates you
and takes revenge,

but a woman's anger is strongest,
just as snakes have
the strongest poison.

I would be happier to live
with a lion and a dragon
than to be married
to an evil woman.

An evil woman's face is changed
into something dark,
like the face of a bear.

Her husband is depressed,
sighing bitterly
even among his friends.

The sins of men are small
compared to those of women,
and I pray that women who sin
will be severely punished.

It is easier for an old person
to climb a hill of sand
than for a quiet man to live
with a chattering wife.

Do not be taken captive
by the beauty of a woman,
and don't desire her wealth.[54]

When the wife's possessions
support the family,
their home will be filled
with anger, insults,
and shame.

An evil wife brings no happiness
to her husband;
instead, she makes him sad
and depressed;
she breaks his heart,
and he is afraid
to make any decisions.

Sin began with the first woman,
and because of her
we all must die.

Do not let water leak
from your storage jars,
and if your wife is evil,
don't let her talk in public.

If she will not obey you,
then get a divorce.

A man who is married
to a good woman
is happy, and he will live
twice as long.

If a wife has courage,
her husband will find happiness
and live a peaceful life.

A good wife is the best gift
given by the Lord
to those men who fear him,

and whether such a man
is rich or poor,
the smile on his face
comes from a happy heart.

I am always extra careful
when I hear ugly gossip
being repeated in the city,
or when a mob comes together,
or when the innocent
are falsely accused.
I would rather die than be part
of those three things.
But a fourth is even worse:

to have two wives,
with one of them being jealous
of the other.
She can only bring heartache
and sorrow,
as her words cut the family
to pieces.

To marry an evil woman
is to hold a scorpion
in your hand,
or to wear an ox-yoke[55]
that rubs your shoulders raw.

When a wife gets drunk
she can be unfaithful,
and then her husband's anger
will explode.

You know a wife is unfaithful
if her eyes have a look
of invitation. *

If your daughter is rebellious
and wants her own way,
watch her closely

and don't be surprised
if she sins against you
the first chance she gets.

She will try to have sex
with every man she sees,
just as thirsty travelers
will drink any water
they can find.

A gracious wife is pleasing
to her husband,
and her cooking skills
keep him fat.[56]

Her silence is a gift
from the Lord,
and her self-control
is without price.

Her modesty is the crown
on all her graces;
her faithfulness to her husband
has value beyond measure.

She has organized her home,
and her beauty there
is like the sun as it rises
in the Lord's heaven.

A lovely face on a good figure
shines like the lamps
on the sacred lampstand,

and shapely legs with firm feet
are like golden columns
resting on silver bases.

Students, when you come of age,
stay away from immoral women
and stay healthy.[57]

To find a good wife
is to find a good field
where you can plant
your own seed,
knowing that it will produce
a good harvest.

And as your children grow,
they will have confidence
in your family line
and will become successful.

A prostitute is worth
less than spit,
and affairs with married women
are deadly.

Reject God's Law,
and he will give you
a godless wife.
But if you fear the Lord,
your wife will be
faithful to him.

A shameless wife is vulgar
in public,
but a good woman is modest,
even alone with her husband.

If a wife does what she pleases,
she is no better than a dog,
but if she is ashamed
to do wrong,
she will fear the Lord.

Everyone can tell
that a wife is wise
if she honors her husband,
but if she is proud and refuses,
they will see she is ungodly.
Yes, a man who is married
to a good woman
is happy, and he will live
twice as long.

But the constant talking
of a loud wife
is a trumpet signal
for a battle to begin,
and her family will live
in the chaos of war.[58]

It makes me terribly sad
when the rich become poor
or the wise are insulted.
But I get angry
if those who do right
start doing wrong.
The Lord will punish them
with a violent death.

It is almost impossible
to succeed in business
and still be honest.

People sin
when they try to get rich,
and they convince themselves
they are not being dishonest.

But sin is stuck tightly
between buying and selling,
just like a wooden peg
hammered between two stones
in a wall.

And if you disobey the Lord,
your home[59]
will soon be destroyed.

Impurities can easily be seen
after flour is sifted
and after someone speaks.

The quality of a clay dish
is seen in the heat
of the pottery furnace,
just as our true character
is seen in what we say.

ⓖ Fruit shows how much care
a tree has received,
and our words show the care
we have given to our minds.

So don't start praising people,
until you hear what they say.

Make fairness your goal;
you will reach it
and receive great honor.

Just as birds of the same kind
come together in a flock,
people will be honest with you,
if you are honest with them.

But sin is watching like a lion
and is ready to gobble you up
if you do evil.

Good people always speak wisely,
but you never can tell
what a fool will say next.

Don't waste your time
listening to stupid people;
spend it with those
who know how to think.

It is disgusting to listen to fools
laughing about their sins.
*

Their cursing and arguing
makes your hair stand on end
and your ears ache.

But fools are too proud
to stop sinning,
until someone gets hurt.

ⓗ Your friends won't trust you
or like you anymore
if you can't keep a secret.

If you don't tell their secrets,
your friends will know
that you really like them.
But if you tell their secrets,
they won't want you around,

and your friendship is as dead
as a soldier
killed by the enemy.

It is gone for good,
like a captive bird
that has been set free

or a deer that has escaped
from a trap.
So don't bother trying
to get back that friendship.

Wounds can be bandaged
and insults forgiven,
but nothing can heal the harm
of telling someone's secret.

Stay away from those who wink
and plan to deceive others.

They tell you how great you are
and how well you speak,
but later, they twist your words
to make you look bad.

I hate people like them
more than anything else,
and even the Lord hates them.

Striking a friend is the same
as throwing a stone
straight up in the air—
you will be the one
who gets hurt.

And you will get caught
in traps that you set
to cheat others.

No one seems to realize
that evil always returns
to the one who does it.

Proud people insult others,
but revenge will follow them
like a lion stalking a victim.

When God's people
are in trouble,
those who make fun of them
will die in terrible pain,
like an animal in a trap.

Taking revenge in anger
is disgusting—yet sinners
just won't give it up.

The Lord keeps a record
of those who take revenge
and he will punish them
for their sins.

ⓘ So forgive those who harm you,
and when you pray,
God will forgive you.

But don't expect
the Lord to forgive you
if you hold a grudge
or refuse to show mercy.

God won't accept sacrifices
for your sins
if you stay angry with others.

Life is too short
to waste it by being angry,
so obey God
and forgive your enemies.

Remember his commands
and his agreement with us.
Don't let the faults of others
make you angry with them.

If you control your temper,
you won't start arguments
or sin as much.

And remember, it is sinful
to start an argument
that destroys a friendship.

Stubbornness heats up
an argument,
just as adding wood
heats up a fire.
If you are rich and powerful,
you can afford
to lose your temper.

A quick temper can blaze up
and lead to murder.

Blow on a spark
and it bursts into flames;
spit on a spark
and it dies out.
In the same way, your words
can either heat up an argument
or make it cool down.

ⓙ Those who gossip and tell lies
are under God's curse,
because they have brought ruin
to innocent people

and forced many others
to leave home and country.
Such talk has been the downfall
of strong cities
and powerful leaders.

Because of lies others told,
faithful, hard-working wives
have been divorced
and have lost everything[60]

So if you want peace of mind,
don't listen to gossip!

Whips leave painful stripes
on the skin,
but cruel words break bones
deep down inside

and can be more deadly
than a sword.
*

You should be happy
if you have never been attacked
with lies and gossip,
or felt them wrap around you

like heavy bronze chains
or a collar[61] made of iron.

Cruel words cause suffering[62]
worse than death itself.

Although they are fiery flames,
they cannot harm
God's faithful people,

but those who reject him
will be burned to ashes.
And these cruel words
are like lions and leopards,
hunting down their victims
and tearing them apart.

You protect your land
with a hedge of thornbushes
and you keep your money
locked away safely.

Be just as careful
to guard what you say.
Always think before you speak,
and know when to be silent,

so that others cannot attack you
for what you have said.

ⓚ Obey God's Law
about helping
your neighbors;
have mercy and lend them money
when they truly need it.

If others lend you money,
pay them back,
and don't be late!

If you keep your promises
to pay what you owe,
others will be glad
to lend you what you need.

Many think what they borrow
is theirs to keep,
and this causes trouble
when others try to help them.

Those who lend money
are treated with great respect
until the time comes
for loans to be repaid.
Then all they get are excuses
and stories of hard times.

Sometimes they feel lucky
to get back half
of the money they lent.
And instead of respect,
a lender often gets nothing
but curses and angry words
from a borrower
who is robbing the lender
by not paying back the loan.

That's why many refuse to lend;
they do care about others,
but they have no desire
to be cheated.

However, give to the poor;
be quick and generous.

Obey the Lord's command—
don't refuse to help
when people are in need.

Give away your silver
to a brother or a friend;
don't hide it under a rock,
where it will rust.

Give your gold to the needy
as God Most High commands,
and you will be better off
than if you had kept it.

Your gifts to the poor
are a treasure
that will rescue you
when trouble comes,

and they give better protection
than the strongest shields
and spears.

When a friend needs a loan,
a good person will guarantee
that the loan will be repaid.
To refuse to help this friend
would be a disgrace.

And remember—if friends
have helped you this way,
they have risked all they own
to be kind *

and rescue you.
So if they are forced to repay
what you borrowed,

you are not only ungrateful,
you are a sinner.

People of wealth and power
have often become poor
and homeless,
drifting from place to place
in foreign countries,
their wealth taken in payment
for loans they guaranteed.

Sinners want to make big profits
from guaranteed loans,
but they may get only trouble
and lawsuits in court.

Be careful! There is danger
when you guarantee a loan,
but you have to help a friend
as much as you can.

Life's most important things
are water, food, clothing,
and a home that gives you
some privacy.

It is better to be poor
in your own home,
than to live with others
and be treated to banquets.

Be content with what you have,
because you will be insulted
if you live off others.[63]

You will always be miserable
and will not dare say a word,
if you have to depend on others
for food and a place to sleep.

You will become their servant,
and instead of thanking you,
they will say,

“Stranger, set the table!”
Or, “I'm still hungry—
give me your food.”

Finally they will tell you to leave
so they can give your room
to a relative
or some important guest.

Such comments are insulting
to a sensitive person,
just like those of a lender
demanding payment of a loan.

Parents show love
for their children
by spanking them
whenever they do wrong.
Later those parents will be glad
to see their children
grow into fine adults.

If parents correct a child,
they will someday boast
about how much help
that child has been to them.

Parents who give their children
an education
make their enemies jealous
and can boast to friends.
*

These parents have no regrets
when they die,
and they live on
in their children,
who brought them such joy.

Then it is up to the children
to take revenge
on their parents' enemies,
and to be kind
to their parents' friends.

If you spoil your children,
you will have to put bandages
on the wounds they will get,
and you will shake with fear
every time you hear shouting.

That's why you
must correct them,
so they will not be as stubborn
as unbroken horses.
*

If you give children
everything they desire
and laugh when they sin,

they will end up giving you
sadness, terror, and pain.

Don't let them do
just anything they want,
but correct their mistakes.

Break their stubbornness
by whipping them
while they are young,
or else they will disobey you
and bring you deep sorrow.

Take care to discipline them,
so they will not disgrace you
when they are older.

I would rather be poor,
yet healthy and strong,
than to be rich and sickly.

To have your health
and a good attitude[64]
is better than gold
and infinite riches.

No amount of money
can compare with health
or bring happiness
deep inside your heart.

Death is better
than a life of constant pain
and sickness.

If a fine dinner is served,
but the guests
are too sick to eat,
the dinner will go to waste,
like food placed on a grave[65]

or like a sacrifice to an idol,
which cannot eat or smell.
If the Lord punishes people
by making them sick,

they can only stare at food
and groan like a young man
unable to have sex
who holds a virgin
in his arms.

ⓛ Don't stay sad for too long
or look for reasons
to be upset.

Joy and happiness will help you
to live longer.

So enjoy life and forget sorrow,
because sorrow never helps,
and it has destroyed many.

Jealousy and anger
will cut your life short,
and worrying makes you old
before your time.

If you are cheerful at meals,
the food you eat
will do you more good.

The rich lie awake at night
worrying about their money,
and they waste away
from lack of rest.

It is hard to fall asleep
when you are very sick
or worried about money.

The rich work hard
and get richer,
then they rest in luxury.

But the poor work hard
and barely earn a living,
and if they rest,
they become even poorer.

Some people love gold
and aim to make big profits,
and they will be led to do wrong
instead of right.

Because of gold,
many lives have been ruined
or have ended in destruction.

Money controls those fools
who worship it.

God will bless those rich people
who do only what is right
and don't try to get richer.

If you ever find such people,
you should honor them
for doing the impossible.

When tested by money,
who can always do right?
When people could cheat
to get more money
but instead are honest,
they have something
to boast about.

The community will honor them
for the kind things they do,
and their wealth will grow.

When you go to a banquet,
don't stuff yourself
just because so much food
is on the table.

Some people's eyes
want everything they see.
Is anything more evil?
Such eyes will have plenty
of tears.

Don't reach out and grab
the food you want
or push others aside.

Be thoughtful of others—
they have feelings too.

Eat what is served,
but you won't be welcome
if you gobble it up
like an animal.

Show good manners;
stop eating before others do.
If you keep on eating,
they will be offended.

And in a large group of people,
don't be the first one
to reach for the serving dish.

Train yourself to be satisfied
with a little food,
and later, in bed,
you will not be in pain
when you try to breathe.

You will sleep well
and wake up early,
feeling good.
But overeating causes cramps,
as well as an upset stomach
and sleepless nights.

If your host makes you overeat,
leave the table and vomit—
you will feel much better.

Listen to me! Pay attention,
and later on,
you will thank me.
Don't try to eat[66] too much,[67]
and you will stay healthy.

It is right to honor those
who are generous with food
at their dinner parties.

But the whole town is right
to complain about a host
who gives only a snack.

Wine has destroyed many lives,
and heavy drinking is no way
to prove you are strong.

The strength of iron is seen
when it is heated,
then dipped in water.
And people show their arrogance
when they argue
after drinking wine.

A little wine is refreshing,
and to live without wine
is hardly living at all.
God created wine
to make us happy.

A little wine at the right time
helps us celebrate.

But drinking too much wine
leads us to hate others
and to take revenge.[68]

When fools are drunk,
they become angry and fight,
but their strength is gone,
and so they get hurt.

Don't scold your friends
or be disgusted
when they drink and celebrate
at a party.
And don't make them feel bad
or upset them with a reminder
that they owe you money.

* If you are placed in charge
of a dinner party,
don't try to act important.
Just make sure all the guests
have what they need

before you are seated.
Then enjoy the dinner
with everyone else,
and they will honor you
for a job well done.

If you are an older guest,
it is right for you to talk.
But be sure what you say is true,
and don't talk during the music

or other entertainment.
That is not the right time
for clever remarks.
*

Good wine and good music
at a banquet

are like rubies and emeralds
in settings of gold.

If you are a younger guest,
don't talk unless someone
asks you a question.
Don't speak more than twice,

and say as much as you can
in as few words as possible.
This will show your knowledge
and also your self-control.

Treat important people
with proper respect,
and don't chatter on and on
if someone older is talking.

Lightning goes ahead of thunder,
and if you are humble,
you will be liked and accepted
before you even arrive.

Then later, at the proper time,
just say goodbye and go home.
Don't wait around
to be the last to leave.

At home, you can have fun
doing whatever you want—
but be careful not to sin
by speaking with arrogance.

And give thanks to your Creator,
who lets you enjoy
all the good things he made.

If you obey the Lord,
expect him to correct you,
but do your best,
and you will be accepted.

Sincerely studying God's Law
will bring contentment,
but if you are not sincere
that Law will condemn you.

If you obey the Lord,
you will be well known
for justice and fairness.

But sinners refuse
to be corrected,
and they twist the Law
so they can do
whatever they please.

A wise person can take a hint,
but even fear of great danger
won't stop an arrogant fool.[69]

Give plenty of thought
to what you will do,
and afterwards, don't worry
about how well you did.

Don't look for trouble,
but learn from your mistakes.[70]

It's easy to be careless
on a smooth road,

so always pay attention
to the path ahead.[71]

Think your actions through,[72]
and you will be able
to obey the Lord's commands.

If you believe in God's Law,
then do what it says.
Trust the Lord,
and you will have success.

If you obey him,
you will be protected
and rescued from danger.

You are wise to love God's Law,
but if you are not sincere,
you will be tossed around
like a boat in a storm.

ⓜ Be sensible and trust
what God has said in his Law.

If you want others to listen,
then think about what you know
and how to say it best.

Fools talk in circles
like a wheel going around.

To make fun of a friend
is to act like a horse
that snorts at anyone
who tries to ride.

Each day of the year
depends on the sun for light,
so why are some days
more important than others?

The Lord used his wisdom
and made them different.
Some have a special meaning,
others are festivals,

and some are sacred days—
but most are ordinary.

ⓝ We humans were made
from the soil,

and the Lord used great wisdom
to make each of us different,
with different destinies.

He blessed our ancestors
and made them great,
and he even let some
be his holy priests.
But he put a curse
on the nations of Canaan—
they were defeated
and forced to leave the land.

Humans become
what the Creator chooses,
just as clay is shaped
by the hands of the potter.

There are many opposites—
good and evil, life and death,
sinners and God's people.

You can see that God Most High
made everything the opposite
of something else.

I am the last in the line
of the teachers of wisdom,
like a poor man picking grapes
after the main harvest.[73]

But the Lord blessed me,
and I gathered enough grapes
to fill a wine-pit.

I wasn't working
just for my own good,
but to help all those
who want to learn wisdom.

So pay attention to what I say,
all you officials and leaders.

Never give anyone else power
to make decisions for you—
not your husband or wife,[74]
and not your children,
relatives, or friends.
And don't give away property—
if you later want it returned,
you will have to beg for it.

As long as you are alive,
don't let others run your life.

It is better that your children
ask you for money
than for you to ask them.

Be the best at whatever you do,
and do only what brings honor
and not shame.

Wait until you are about to die
before giving your children
their inheritance.

If you feed your donkeys
and beat them with a stick,
they will carry their loads.
Slaves are like that—
feed and discipline them,
and they will do their work.

If you don't want trouble,
keep your slaves busy;
otherwise, they will have time
to think about becoming free.

Use collars and leather straps
to keep slaves at their work,
and punish the rebellious ones
by torturing them.
*

Keep your slaves busy
or they will have time to think
of ways to cause trouble.

Slaves are supposed to work,
so give them something to do,
and if they refuse to obey,
put them in chains.
But always be fair,
not arrogant.

If one slave is all you have,
treat him like a family member
or even as you treat yourself.
You worked a long time
to buy that slave,
and you need his help
to survive.

If you are mean,
and that slave runs away,
where will you look for him?

ⓞ Empty hopes deceive
ignorant people,
and dreams lead fools
to be even more foolish.

Believing in dreams
is like holding on to shadows
or chasing the wind.

Just as a mirror
reflects your face,
your dreams reflect
your concerns.

Something clean cannot come
from something dirty,
and truth cannot come
from a lie.

Dreams are meaningless,
like something said
by a fortuneteller,[75]
because they can mean anything
you want them to.[76]

So unless a dream has been sent
by God Most High,
ignore it.

Dreams have fooled many—
first giving them hope,
then disappointing them.

You can obey God's Law
and learn from wise people,
without paying attention
to deceitful dreams.

A person who has traveled
has learned many things,
and knows about them
from experience.

If you have few experiences,
you won't learn much,

but the more you travel,
the smarter you will become.

I saw many things
when I traveled,
and I learned more
than I can tell you.

My life was often in danger,
but what I had learned
always helped me escape.
*

If you fear the Lord
and put your trust in him,
he will keep you safe,

and so you can be brave
and face any danger.

The Lord will bless you
if you fear him
and ask for his help.

And if you love the Lord,
he will give you strength
and keep you from falling.
He will be your shield,
protecting you and giving shade
from the burning heat
of the summer sun at noon.

Your eyes will sparkle
with the happiness he gives,
and he will bless you
with health and a long life.

A stolen animal isn't fit
as a sacrifice for the Lord,

and he won't accept gifts
from those who reject his Law.

Sinners cannot please
God Most High,
and he will not forgive them,
even if they offer
sacrifice after sacrifice.

Stealing food from the poor
to offer as a sacrifice
is like murdering children
while their parents watch.

The poor have so little food,
that taking it is the same
as committing murder.

Stealing what someone needs
to earn a living
is the same as murder,

and refusing to pay the wages
of someone who works for you
is just as evil.

So, if you steal possessions
that others worked for,[77]
you will cause trouble
for yourself and for them.

When they are asking God
to put a curse on you,
will he listen to your prayer?

ⓟ If you are unclean
from touching a dead body,
what's the point of washing
if you touch the body again?

Suppose you go without eating
to show sorrow for your sins
and then commit
the same sins again.
Will God forgive you?
No, it was all for nothing.

Obeying the Law
of the Lord
is the same
as bringing him many gifts,

and obeying his commands
is like offering a sacrifice
to ask his blessing.[78]

Showing kindness to someone
who has been kind to you
is like offering a sacrifice
to give thanks to the Lord.[79]

And giving to the poor
is offering a sacrifice
that gives the Lord praise.

So please the Lord
and seek his forgiveness,
by staying away from evil.

However, do not come
to worship the Lord
without bringing him a gift
as his Law commands.

When one of God's people
burns the fat of a sacrifice,
God Most High is pleased
with the smell of the smoke
rising from the altar.

ⓠ Such sacrifices
are acceptable to God
and will not be forgotten.

When you offer to the Lord
the first part of the harvest
or a sacrifice to give thanks,
be generous—not stingy.

Be happy and cheerful
when you give him a gift
or a tenth of your harvest.

Be as generous with the Lord
as he has been with you.

Remember! The Lord is the one
who repays seven times more
than you give him.

You cannot bribe the Lord
by offering a sacrifice,

and he won't accept as a gift
what you get by cheating.
The Lord is a judge
who doesn't take sides,

especially against the poor,
but he answers the prayers
of all who suffer injustice.

God listens when an orphan
begs for his help.
He hears the complaints
of a mistreated widow
as she cries out
with tears in her eyes

and tells him about the one
who has abused her.

If you obey the Lord,
he will accept you
and answer when you pray.

Be humble, and your prayers
will go up beyond the clouds
and be heard
by God Most High.

He will quickly punish those
who have wronged his people
and completely crush those
who have shown no mercy.

God will take revenge
on evil, arrogant Gentiles,[80]
breaking their power
and destroying them.

And someday, all humans
will be repaid, as their thoughts
and deeds deserve.

Then God will judge
in favor of his people,
and they will celebrate
because he showed mercy.

We welcome God's mercy
when we are in trouble,
just as we welcome rain
in hot, dry weather.

Our God, you rule all things;
have mercy on us

and show all nations
that they should fear you.

Let them see your power
as you attack them.

They have seen that you are holy
in the way you treat us.
Now show us that you are great
as you deal with them!

Teach them, our Lord,
as you taught us,
that you alone are God.
Perform new miracles,

so that everyone will know
how powerful you are.
Get really angry
and destroy our enemies.

You have set a time to do this—
please let it come quickly,
then everyone will be talking
about your mighty power.

And if any survive of those
who had harmed your people,
destroy those enemies
with your fiery anger.

Crush the heads of their rulers
who say, “All that matters
is what we want to do.”

Gather together
the tribes of Israel,[81]

and[82] once again give them
control of their land.

Have pity on us, our Lord.
We are known as your nation,
your first-born child.

Show mercy to Jerusalem,
your holy city, your home.

Then everyone in Zion
will celebrate as they tell
of your mighty deeds.

Prove that you chose us
as your people.
You told your prophets
to make promises to us;
now keep these promises

so your prophets
will not have lied.
Please reward us
for waiting patiently.

Our Lord, we are your servants.
If you are pleased with us,
answer our prayer,
and then the whole world
will know that you
are the Eternal Lord God.

There are many different foods,
but you like some
better than others.

And just as your taste tells you
what you are eating,
a smart mind will know
when it hears a lie.

People with twisted minds
cause a lot of trouble,
but if you learn from experience
you can send the trouble
back on them.

A woman cannot choose
the man she will marry,
but a man can choose his wife,
and some women
make better wives than others.

Beauty is important to men,
and most men would be happy
to marry a beautiful woman.

But a man is really lucky
if his wife speaks
with humility and kindness.

The most important thing
a man can have
is a wife who helps him
and is a suitable partner.

Without a fence around a home,
robbers can steal
whatever they want.
And without a wife,
a man wanders aimlessly,

homeless, spending the night
wherever he can,
trusted no more than a thief
who is always on the run.

Someone who claims
to be your friend
may not be telling the truth.

The sorrow when a close friend
becomes an enemy
is almost like mourning
for a friend who has died.

Why do people's thoughts
lead them to do wrong
and spread deceit everywhere?

Some friends are happy for you
when everything is fine,
but when you have trouble
they turn against you.

Another friend seems to help
only for a free meal,
but when you both go off to war,
he gives you protection.[83]

Never forget your friends,
and if you are successful,
share your wealth with them.

When people claim to offer
advice that is good for you,
it may really be good
for them.

Before you do what they say,
see if they are looking out
for themselves
and putting you at risk

with their advice,
while they can safely watch
what happens to you.

If someone is jealous
or suspicious of you,
don't ask them for advice
or tell them your plans.

If a man has two wives,
don't ask one about the other.
Take care who you ask
for advice.
A coward can't tell you
how to fight in battle,
and a store owner won't tell
how much something
is really worth. Can someone with a grudge
show you how to be grateful,
or someone mean
tell you how to be kind?
Don't bother asking
a lazy person
if work needs to be done.
And don't ask someone
who gets paid by the hour
how long a job should take.

If you need advice, ask someone
who obeys God's commands
and thinks like you—
someone who will be sad
if you fail.

And trust your own judgment—
you care more about yourself
than anyone else does.

Thinking for yourself
will often tell you more
than if you had seven lookouts
in a high tower.

But the most important thing
is to pray that God Most High
will show you what to do.

Before you begin a project,
talk with others
and get their advice.
Everything starts as an idea,[84]

whether it helps or harms,
or brings life or death,
and how people talk
determines what they do.

Some people can give
excellent advice to others
but show no wisdom
in their own lives.

And some who can speak well
will be hated and starve,

because they speak
without wisdom from the Lord,
and they offend others.

If you see that certain people
make wise choices themselves,
you can depend on the advice
they give to you.[85]

The wise teach their wisdom
to God's people
so their wisdom will live on.

The wise are admired and praised
by everyone they meet.

Life is short for each of us,
but Israel will last forever,

honoring the memory of those
who shared their wisdom.

Take notice, students,
what foods make you feel sick,
and stay away from them.

After all, no one likes
every kind of food.

Control any desire to overeat
or to have lots of fancy food
at every meal.

You will get sick
if you eat too much.

Be careful!
Many have died young
from overeating.

The Lord chose some people
to be doctors, so honor them
for helping others get well.

God Most High gave them
the ability to heal,
and they are rewarded
by the king.

Their skills
make them important,
and they are admired
by powerful people.

Medicines are part
of the Lord's creation,
and if you are sensible,
you will use them.

ⓡ One time even a piece of wood
made water fit to drink,
and this showed God's power.

He gives knowledge to humans
so that we will praise him
for his amazing creations.
*

Doctors relieve pain
and bring healing
by mixing medicines
from things that God created.

God will always be at work
bringing health
to everyone on earth.

Students, if you get sick,
quickly pray to the Lord,
and you will be healed.

Give up all your sins
and decide to do right.

Offer a sacrifice of fine flour
and as much olive oil
as you can afford,[86]
and the smell of the smoke
will be pleasing to God.

But God also created doctors,
and you need their help,
so don't reject them.

Someday your life
will be in their hands,

and they will ask the Lord
how to make you well
and relieve your pain.

Those who sin against God,
their Creator,
will also reject doctors.[87]

ⓢ When someone dies,
you should mourn and weep
as though you were in pain.
Prepare the body to be buried,
and attend the funeral.

Weep bitterly to show respect
for the dead.
If you don't grieve at all,
you will be criticized,
but don't mourn for longer
than a day or two.

If you don't stop grieving,
you will grow weak
and die.

After a funeral, sorrow remains,
but don't let it drag you down
into poverty.[88]

Put away your grief
and enjoy what is left
of your own life.

You cannot bring back
those who have died.
Grieving won't help them,
and it can harm you.

Just remember that in the past,
death caught up with them,
and in the future,
it will catch up with you.

The dead are at rest,
so be strong
and stop thinking about them
all the time.

If teachers are to become wise,
they need lots of time to study
and freedom from other work. *

Who has time to study wisdom?
Not farmers!
All day long they guide oxen
to plow

in straight lines.
Then they work at night
feeding their livestock.
Farmers talk about cattle,
not wisdom.

Who has time to study wisdom?
Not artists who carve designs
on rings and other jewelry.
These artists work with care
night and day, making sure
each design is different
and leaves a perfect pattern
when pressed in soft wax.[89]

Who has time to study wisdom?
Not the blacksmith,
soaked in sweat from the heat
of the furnace,
going deaf from the noise
as he hammers the red-hot iron,
shaping it on his anvil.
He wants to finish this piece,
and will work late to see
all its decorations completed.

Who has time to study wisdom?
A potter doesn't.
His feet must always move
to spin the pottery wheel.
He keeps his mind on his work—
so many pieces to make,

and so much to do.
He works the clay with his feet
to make it soft,
then shapes it with his hands
before baking it.
And then at night,
he cleans out the furnace.

All these are skilled people
who work with their hands.

Without them in a town,
no one would live there
or even visit.
But they are not asked to serve
on public committees,

and they don't become leaders
in the town council.
They are not judges
and cannot explain
the decisions of the court.
They cannot even tell stories
that teach lessons.

But they do pray
about their work,
and they keep life going
for everyone else. Teachers who study the Law
of God Most High
are different.

In their search for wisdom,
they study the old writings,
especially those
of the prophets.[90]

These teachers learn the sayings
of famous people
and understand the meaning
of stories,

even those parts
that are difficult.
And they look for the meaning
hidden in a proverb.

They give advice to leaders,
and they travel
in other countries
to see the good and the bad
done there.

These teachers get up early
to pray to the Lord Most High,
their Creator—
they tell him what they need
and ask that their sins
be forgiven.

The great Lord may choose
to give special understanding
to a teacher's mind.
Such teachers will pray
and thank the Lord
for the wise advice
that they now can give.

They will study those things
the Lord has kept secret.
He will help them learn
and tell them what to say,

and they will teach
what they have learned.
They will be proud
of the Lord's Law
and agreement with Israel.

Their understanding
will be praised by many,
and their names remembered
for all time.

Israel will honor them,
and other nations will admire
their wisdom.

If they live to old age,
they will be famous,
and if not, they will be content
to be at rest.[91]

I have hardly begun to tell you
all the things I want to say.

You, my students,
are faithful to God,
so listen, and you will blossom
like rose bushes
planted beside a stream.

You will grow faster than lilies,
and your songs praising the Lord
for what he has done
will be a pleasant smell,
spreading like incense.

So play your harps
and sing praises to the Lord.
Give honor to him
with this song:

“Everything the Lord does
is very good,
and his commands
will be obeyed
at the right moment.

ⓣ For now, we must not question
what God has done,
but he has set a time
to explain everything.
He created places
for all the water,
and when he commanded the sea,
it piled up like a wall.

When he gives an order,
it is obeyed,
and no one can stop him
when he decides to rescue.

“We can't hide from God;
he has watched everything
that each human has done.

He sees the past and the future;
there is nothing
he cannot do.

So don't question
what God has done;
he had a purpose in mind
for each thing he created.

“God will bless us greatly,
like a river that overflows
and soaks the dry ground.

But the Gentiles
will feel his anger,
as he makes their fresh water
too salty to drink.

God lets his people walk
on a straight pathway,
but those who reject his laws
will find that their path
is lined with hidden traps.

From the very beginning
God prepared good things
for good people,
and horrible things for sinners.

“What do we need for daily life?
Iron tools, water, and fire;
flour, milk, and honey,
wine, olive oil, and salt;
and, of course, clothing.

All of these are good
for God's loyal people
but become evil in the hands
of sinners.

“The Lord created furious winds
to take revenge for him.
And on the day of judgment,
they will punish his enemies,
then his anger will be calmed.
*

God also created other things
to take revenge for him—
fire and hail, along with famine
and deadly diseases,

wild animals and scorpions,
and poisonous snakes,
not to mention war.

They are ready to serve him,
and at his command,
they gladly and quickly obey.”

I have believed all these things
since my childhood,
but I thought deeply about them
before I wrote them down
in that song.

The Lord made only good things,
and at the right time
he will give us what we need.

Everything he created
has its own purpose,
and so, you cannot say,
“This is better than that.”

Sing praises to the Lord
with all your heart,
and give him thanks!

ⓤ God plans for us humans
to work hard
from the day of our birth
until we are buried in the soil
from which we were made.[92]

We don't understand life,
so we worry and dread the day
that it will end.
*

And each of us is bothered
by troubling feelings—
from the king,
seated on his glorious throne
and wearing his crown
and royal robes,
*

to the homeless in the street,
sitting in dirt and grime
and wearing worn-out clothes.

We are angry, jealous,
or hateful;
or maybe we feel guilty
or are afraid of death.
Sometimes we are confused
by a dream,

or lie awake
worrying about our work,
and so we get little rest.[93]
We see ourselves
running for our lives,

and almost reaching safety,
then we wake up, amazed—
it was all a dream.

The troubles that sinners have
will be seven times worse
than those of other people.
Any living creature

can suffer a violent death
when there is war or fighting,
or they can die from disaster,
horrible disease, or famine.

ⓥ But God created these troubles
to punish those who do wrong,
as when he sent the flood.

ⓦ Animals and humans
were created from the soil,
and will return to it,
just as water
returns to the sea.

What you gain by being honest
will last forever,
but wealth you get
by bribery and cheating
will disappear.

It will dry up like a stream
in the summer heat,
or quickly fade, like thunder
from a passing storm.

And while generous people
can celebrate success,
those who disobey God
will be failures.

Their children will be like trees
growing out of a rocky cliff
and having rotten roots
and few branches.

They are like the tall grass
that grows beside a stream—
when the stream runs dry,
the grass quickly withers.

But those who show kindness,
especially to the poor,
are gardens that always bloom
with blessing after blessing.

It is good to have a job
and earn your own money,
but it is even better
to discover hidden treasure.

Having wisdom is better
than giving your name
to your children or to a city
that you have built.
Cattle and fruit trees
can bring you wealth,[94]
but a happy marriage[95]
is better than riches.

Wine and music bring happiness,
but if you love wisdom,
you will be even happier.

A pleasant voice is sweeter
than the music
of flutes and harps.

Our eyes like beauty
and graceful movement,
but most of all, we want to see
our fields becoming green
with sprouting wheat.

Having friends and neighbors
is important,
but being married
is even better.

Relatives and friends can help
when you are in trouble,
but the best help comes
from giving to the poor.

Gold and silver
may give security,
but they don't compare
with good advice.

Many trust wealth and power,
but if you obey the Lord,
he will give you
whatever you need
if you will just ask.

If you obey the Lord,
he will protect you
and make your life a garden
where blessings grow.

You would be better off dead
than to be a beggar.

If you have to beg for food,
your life isn't your own,
and you won't have
any respect for yourself.
If you are smart
and have learned anything,
you won't beg.

No matter what beggars say,
they really are ashamed
of what they do.

Death is a bitter thought
for those who are prosperous
and without a worry.
They have everything
and are healthy enough
to enjoy good food.

But others would rather die
because they are poor and sick,
old and worn out.
They are grumpy and impatient,
always finding something
to worry about.

When it's your time to die,
don't be afraid—
you are merely following those
who have gone on before.
And everyone else
will soon follow you,

because the Lord has commanded
that life ends with death,
and we all must obey.
No one in the world of the dead
will ask how long you lived,
whether it was ten, a hundred,
or a thousand years.

The children of sinners
are disgusting,
because they are raised
in godless homes.

They will lose everything
they inherited,
and their own children
will live in disgrace.

If parents reject God,
their children are disgraced
and blame them.

The godless are in for trouble,
because they refuse to obey
the Law of God Most High.

They will groan as disaster
strikes their children,[96]
and at the death of the godless,
God's people will celebrate[97]
and will curse them.

All living creatures
will return to the soil
from which they were made,
but sinners are under a curse
and will be destroyed.

When someone dies,
we usually mourn,
but everyone tries to forget
those who were evil.

So be careful! Your reputation
won't die with you—
it will outlast the gold
in a thousand treasure chests.

Every one of us must die,
but our reputations won't.

Students, you have learned well.
So don't worry; just do
what you have been taught.
Your wisdom is a treasure—
bring it out and use it,
don't bury it!

Fools who hide their stupidity
will be better off than you,
if you hide your wisdom.

Certain deeds are shameful,
although not everyone agrees
what these are.
So listen carefully,
and I will tell you.

You should be ashamed
if you are immoral
and your parents find out;
if a leader discovers
that you have lied;

if you commit a crime
and everyone in town
comes to watch your trial;
if you cheat your friends

or steal from neighbors;
if you break promises
that you made in God's name;
if you have bad manners
when eating dinner,
or when giving a gift
or receiving one;

if you don't reply
when someone greets you;
if you men look at a prostitute
*

or if you desire the wife
of another man
or if you try to have sex
with one of his slave girls;
if you refuse to help a relative
or if you take what was given
to someone else;

if you insult your friends,
even though you have given
a gift to them;

if you repeat rumors
or tell someone's secret.
If someone catches you
doing any of these things,
show how ashamed you are,
then others will forgive you.
Don't ever be ashamed
to do what is right,
even if others don't approve.

For example, don't be ashamed
if you obey the Law
of God Most High;
or if a godless person
is on trial,
and you vote “innocent”
because you believe it's true;

if you pay your fair share
of the expenses for business
or travel;
if you divide up an inheritance
among all those
who deserve a share;

if you have accurate scales
for weighing what you buy
and sell;
if you buy much or little,

or if you make a profit
on what you sell;
if you punish your children
when they need it;
if your slaves do wrong,
and you whip them
until they bleed.

Husbands, if your wife
cannot be trusted,
or if a lot of visitors
will be in your home,
lock up everything of value.

If you leave valuable items
with someone for safekeeping,
be sure to get a receipt,
and keep records of everything
you give or receive.

Do not be embarrassed
to correct stupid fools
or even an older person
who is being immoral. If you follow my advice,
others will honor you
for the lessons of wisdom
you have learned.

ⓧ I know that secretly you fathers
worry about your daughters
and lose sleep, while questions
trouble your minds.
Will she find a husband?
Will he love her,

and will she
be faithful to him?
Will she get pregnant
before she gets married
and leaves your home?
Or will she be able
to have children?

If your daughter
always wants her own way,
watch her closely,
or she may embarrass you.
Your enemies will laugh,
and everyone in town
will talk about it.
Don't let her bedroom window
look down on the front door,
and a room without a window
is even better.[98]

Don't let men see her beauty,
and keep her away
from married women,

because evil comes from women
as fast as moths that fly
from wool clothing.

Women are the cause
of so much disgrace,
that the wrong things men do
are better than the good
done by women.

Now let me tell you
what the Lord has done;
this is what I have seen.
When he gives a command,
things begin to happen,
and his creatures obey.[99]

When the sun starts shining,
God's glory can be seen
in all the earth.

Even his angels cannot explain
everything he has done,
because he wants all creation
to show how great he is.

God knows everything—
from the unseen world
of the ocean floor,
to the secret thoughts
deep in our hearts,
to those things that change
from one age to the next.

God explains the past to us
and tells what lies ahead;
he even shows us clues
to the mysteries of creation.

Each thought and word
are known to him.

The laws of nature
show his great wisdom.
God has never changed
and never will;
he has no need of advice.

Look at his creation—
it sparkles with beauty,

and year after year, each part
fulfills its purpose.

Every part has an opposite,
and together,
they make creation complete,

each one contributing
something good to the other.
Who could ever see enough
of such majestic beauty?

Nothing can compare
with the glorious sight
of the clear, blue sky.

And you can almost hear
the rising sun say,
“I am a wonderful creation
of the Most High God.”

By noon its fiery heat
has dried out the soil.
It forces people into the shade,

and scorches mountain slopes.
The sun's blinding light
is three times hotter
than any fire we can build.

Our great Lord created the sun,
and when he commands,
it hurries to obey.

The moon also has its turn
in the sky
serving as a sign
of the changing months,

and setting the times
for sacred festivals.
When its light has become dark,
a new month begins—

the word “month”
even comes from “moon”—
then we watch in amazement,
as the moon gradually grows
until it is full,
giving light to God's armies
in the heavens above.

Heaven, the Lord's home,
is decorated at night
with beautiful, twinkling stars.

They never rest but stand guard
where he has placed them.

Look at the rainbow,
bright and beautiful,
and praise its Creator,

who bent it with his hands
and placed it around the sky.

At the Lord's command,
snow begins to fall,
and lightning quickly obeys.

And like birds, the clouds fly
from his storehouse.

He gives them his great power,
and he crushes hailstones.
*

His voice thunders at the earth,
and at the sight of him,
mountains tremble.

The whirlwind obeys him,
as do winds from the south
and storms from the north.
God sends the snow,
and it settles on the ground
like a flock of birds
or a swarm of locusts.

We watch amazed
as it floats down,
white and lovely.

He sprinkles frost
as though it were salt,
and icicles form.

A freezing north wind
makes the surface of every pond
hard as armor.

God sends the fiery heat,
and deserted mountain pastures
are scorched and withered.

But soon the early morning mist
and the refreshing dew
will heal the damage.

The Lord calmed the oceans
and placed the islands,
all according to his plan.

And when sailors tell stories
of danger at sea,
we are amazed.

The oceans are home
to strange creatures
and huge monsters.

God tells each of these things
what to do,
and because of his power,
they never fail.
All creation is held together
by his command.

We could never finish telling
what God has done,
so we should say,
“The Lord can be seen
in all his creation.”[100]

But he is far greater
than what he created,
so where can we look
for strength to praise him?

The Lord is fearsome
and powerful,

so always praise him
with all your strength.
Don't let yourself grow tired—
he deserves more praise
than you can give.

Since no one has seen the Lord
and described him to us,
we really don't know
how to praise him.

We have seen so little
of God's creation,
and we do not understand
so many things.

Still, the Lord created it all,
and he has given wisdom
to those who worship him.

Sing the praises of our ancestors,
those famous men
who lived long ago.

The Lord gave them honor
and showed them his power
from the very first.

Some of them were kings
or were famous
for their courage.
Some gave wise advice
or spoke messages from God.

There were leaders
who made good decisions,
who learned the wisdom
passed down by our people,
and who taught it to others.

Some of our ancestors
wrote poetry or music;

others were rich and powerful,
but lived in peace.

All these men
were highly honored
in their own time;

their reputations live on,
and even today
they still are praised.

Others of our people
are best[101] forgotten,
as if they and their descendants
had never been born.

But the ancestors we praise
were faithful to God,
and so we will remember
their good deeds.

Their good name
has been handed down,
generation by generation,[102]

to those who follow them
in being faithful
to their agreement with God.
*

Their families will live on,
and each new generation
will honor these ancestors,

even though their bodies
were long ago laid to rest.

Israel praises them,
and other nations still tell
about their wisdom.

ⓨ Enoch turned to the Lord
and became an example
for all time,
and the Lord was so pleased
that he took Enoch to heaven.

ⓩ Noah was perfectly loyal to God.
And so when God in his anger
sent the flood
to sweep humans from the earth,
he spared Noah's life.

And God made an agreement
with him—
never again will such a flood
destroy all living creatures.

ⓐ No one is more famous
than Abraham, the great ancestor
of many nations.

He obeyed the Law
of God Most High
and made an agreement with God
that left a mark on his body.
And when tested by the Lord,
Abraham remained faithful.

And so, the Lord promised
that Abraham's descendants
would be more numerous
than the stars in the sky
or specks of dust on earth.
All nations would be blessed
by his descendants,
and they would be given land
from sea to sea,
and from the Euphrates River
to the end of the earth.
*

ⓑ God later made the same promise
to Isaac, the son of Abraham.
God's agreement and promise
then came to Jacob—
all people would be blessed
by his descendants,

and God would bless him
and give him land to be divided
among the twelve tribes.[103]
One of Jacob's descendants
was faithful to the Lord
and pleasing to everyone;

ⓒ he was well loved
by Israel and God.
The man was Moses,
and we still give thanks
whenever we think of him.

The Lord gave Moses glory
equal to the angels
and power that terrified
his enemies.
*

When Moses spoke,
miracles happened,
and even the king of Egypt
was forced to honor him.
The Lord chose Moses
to see his glory
and to receive the Law

because Moses was faithful
and humble.

He heard the Lord's voice
and saw him face to face,
when the Lord told him
to teach Israel the commands
that give knowledge and life.

ⓓ Aaron the brother of Moses
was a holy man
from the tribe of Levi,
and the Lord chose him
*

ⓔ and his descendants
to be Israel's priests
for all time.
The Lord told him to wear
glorious clothing

with beautiful decorations
and jewelry.
Three things truly showed
Aaron's priestly power—
the linen shorts, the robe,
and the sacred vest.

Pomegranates[104] were embroidered
along the hem of the robe,
and gold bells were sewn there,
so others could hear the ringing
as he walked in the temple.
*

The vest was embroidered
with blue and purple yarn
and decorated with gold.

The breastpiece was decorated
with red yarn,
and it held the sacred items
used in getting answers
from God.
On it were precious stones,
set in finely worked gold
and engraved with the names
of Israel's twelve tribes.

On Aaron's turban
was a beautiful strip of gold
made by an expert
and engraved with the words,
“Dedicated to the Lord.”

All these things were made
for Aaron the priest,
and since his time,
only his descendants
have ever worn them.

Twice each day,
these priests offer sacrifices
to please the Lord.

ⓕ Moses ordained Aaron as priest
by pouring sacred olive oil
on his head.
And the Lord promised Aaron
that his descendants would serve
as his priests forever
and bless the people of Israel
in his name.

The Lord chose only him
to burn sacrifices and incense
with a pleasing smell,
reminding the Lord of his people
and asking him
to forgive their sins.

Aaron was made a judge
and was given the Law
with instructions to teach it
to Israel.

ⓖ When Israel was in the desert,
some men who were not priests
became jealous of Aaron,
and they rebelled, led by Dathan,
Abiram, and Korah.

But the Lord wasn't pleased,
and to show he was furious,
he sent down fire
to destroy them.

The Lord honored Aaron
even more
by giving to him
the offerings of the first part
of the harvest.
And so these offerings
are the priests' inheritance,

along with other sacrifices
the Lord gave to them.

ⓗ Their inheritance is the Lord,
not a piece of ground
among the rest of Israel.

ⓘ Phinehas son of Eleazar
is almost as famous
as Moses and Aaron.
Phinehas was brave
and eager to obey the Lord,
when the other Israelites
were unfaithful.
And so, because of what he did,
God spared Israel

and promised to Phinehas
and his descendants
the honor of forever being
leaders of the nation
and priests in the temple.

According to this promise
made by the Lord,
only a descendant of Aaron
can be a priest,
just as Israel's king must be
from the family of David.

Give thanks to the Lord
who has given glory
to you priests.[105]
I pray he will give you wisdom
so you will make fair decisions
when you judge his people.
Then they will be successful
and famous forever.

ⓙ Joshua the son of Nun
was a mighty warrior
and the next prophet
after Moses.
His name means,
“The Lord rescues,”
and Joshua did rescue Israel
by defeating their enemies,
as he led Israel into the land
God had promised them.

Joshua was glorious
as he raised his sword
and gave the signal
to attack a city.

He had more courage
than any warrior before him,
because he was fighting
at the Lord's command.

Joshua even kept the sun
from moving across the sky,
so that one day lasted
as long as two.

His enemies attacked all around,
but he prayed
to our Mighty God,
and the Lord, the Most High,
made deadly hailstones fall
on the enemy army.

As the battle moved down
the mountain slopes
Joshua defeated and destroyed
the enemy army,
so that everyone would know
he fought under the command
of the Mighty Lord of Israel,
and that the Lord himself
fought on their side.

ⓚ Earlier, Caleb son of Jephunneh,
along with Joshua,
proved he was loyal to God
by standing up to the people
who rebelled against Moses.
These two held back the people
from sinning
and put an end
to their complaints.

Six hundred thousand men died,
but Caleb and Joshua
were spared
and led Israel into the land
rich with milk and honey.

The Lord kept Caleb strong,
and although Caleb was old,
he captured the hill country.
Then he handed down his land
to his descendants

to remind Israel of the benefits
of being faithful to the Lord.

ⓛ Some of Israel's special leaders
were the famous judges[106]
who never turned from the Lord
to worship idols.
And we still honor them
because they were faithful.

Though they are now dead,
we pray their good names
will be honored by the way
their descendants live.

ⓜ The Lord loved Samuel,
the prophet who appointed
the first kings of Israel
and other rulers.

Samuel judged the nation
according to the Lord's Law,
and so the Lord
watched over Israel.[107]

The people knew that Samuel
spoke for the Lord,
because Samuel was faithful,
and his words came true.

One time, Israel's enemies
attacked from every side,
but Samuel prayed
to the Mighty Lord
and sacrificed a lamb.

Then the Lord thundered
his answer from heaven

and defeated the leaders
of Tyre and[108] Philistia.

Before Samuel died,
he asked the Lord and the king
to be his witnesses
so that no one could accuse him
of ever taking anything
that wasn't rightfully his—
not even a pair of sandals.

And then, after he had died,
he spoke from the grave
and predicted King Saul's death,
which brought to an end
Saul's disobedience.

ⓝ The next prophet was Nathan,
and while David was king,
Nathan spoke God's message.

ⓞ The Lord set David apart
from Israel, his people,
just as the fat
is taken from sacrifices
and is given to the Lord.

David played with lions and bears
as if they were young goats
or lambs from his flock.

When David was a boy,
he put a stone in his sling
and swung it around.
Then he let the stone fly,
and it brought down Goliath,
the giant whose boasting
had put Israel to shame.

David had prayed
to the Lord Most High,
and the Lord gave David strength
to defeat this mighty soldier
and give victory to Israel.

Israel praised David
for killing enemies
by the thousands
and for being blessed
by the Lord.
And when he became king,

he conquered his enemies
on every side,
especially the Philistines,
who have never recovered.

Whenever David won a victory,
he thanked the Holy God
and sang songs of praise
with all his heart,
expressing love for his Creator,
the Lord Most High.

David also commanded singers
to stand in front of the altar
and sing beautiful songs.

And so, all day long,
at every festival,
Israel hears songs of praise
in the temple courtyard.

The Lord forgave David's sins
and made him a glorious king,
and he also promised
that the kings of Israel
would be David's descendants
for all time.
*

Solomon, the wise son of David,
became the next king,
and for David's sake,

ⓟ the Lord kept enemies
from attacking Israel.
And so, Solomon ruled
in a time of peace,
because he had been chosen
to build the Lord a temple
that would last forever.

When Solomon was young,
his wisdom overflowed
like a river

and spread across the land,
filling it with proverbs
and riddles.

He was famous in faraway islands;
he brought peace,
and so he was loved.

His songs, proverbs, stories,
and answers
amazed many nations.

ⓠ Solomon ruled in the name
of the Lord God of Israel
and gathered silver and gold
as if they were tin or lead.

ⓡ But he married lots of wives,
and they used his desire for sex
to gain control over him.

Solomon ruined his reputation
and that of his descendants.
The Lord punished them
for Solomon's sins,
and they mourned,

ⓢ because the northern kingdom[109]
broke away, dividing Israel.

ⓣ But the Lord will continue
to have mercy;
he will never abandon
those he has chosen
and who love him.
And so, the Lord has kept alive
a few of David's descendants
for the sake of Israel.[110]

ⓤ Solomon died, and the next king
was his son Rehoboam,
the nation's worst fool,
and his senseless decisions
caused the people to rebel.
Then Jeroboam[111] son of Nebat
led the northern kingdom
into sin.
*

Israel sinned so much
and in so many ways,
that the Lord
finally punished them,

and they were led as prisoners
from their land.

ⓥ Earlier, God had sent
the prophet Elijah
to speak messages
that burned like fire.

At Elijah's command,
a famine hit Israel,
and many of the people died.

Elijah performed miracles
by God's power—
he held back rain from Israel
and three times commanded fire
to fall from heaven.

He is worthy of honor,
because who else could do
such amazing miracles?

By the power of God Most High
he brought back life
into a dead body.

But he also destroyed kings
and told famous people
they would die of disease.

God corrected Elijah
at Mount Sinai[112]
and told him to announce
that God's enemies
would be punished.

So Elijah appointed kings
to punish these enemies,
and he appointed prophets
to carry on his own work.

Then God took him to heaven
in a fiery whirlwind—
a chariot and horses
made of fire.

It is written that Elijah
will come at the right time,
to calm God's anger
before it overflows,
and help parents
love their children.
Then Israel will be successful
once again.

Those who live until he comes
will be blessed by the Lord,
and God's people who have died
will live again.[113]

ⓦ When Elijah disappeared
in the whirlwind,
God gave Elisha the same power
he had given to Elijah.
Elisha wasn't afraid of kings
and could not be forced
to do what they wanted.
*

ⓧ No problem was too hard for him,
and he did marvelous things.

Even after his death,
his body caused a miracle.

ⓨ But the northern kingdom
still did not give up sinning
and they did not turn to God.
And so, they were captured
and led away
to foreign countries. The kingdom of Judah
had few people,
but at least they had a king
from David's family.

Sometimes they did right,
but often they sinned
worse than ever.

ⓩ Hezekiah fortified Jerusalem,
and using iron tools
he cut a tunnel through rock
to bring water in,
and dug cisterns to store it.

ⓐ During Hezekiah's rule,
Sennacherib attacked Judah,
and before he left,
he sent his highest officer
to Jerusalem. This arrogant officer boasted,
making threats against Zion.

The people of Jerusalem
trembled with fear,
and they suffered
like a woman giving birth.

ⓑ But they lifted up their hands
and prayed to the Lord,
the merciful and holy God.
He heard their prayers
and sent the prophet Isaiah
to rescue them.

Then the Lord sent an angel,
who killed all the Assyrians
in their own army camp.

Jerusalem was saved
because Hezekiah obeyed Isaiah
and pleased the Lord
by following the example
of his ancestor King David. When this great prophet
had a vision, it came true.

ⓒ One time, Isaiah caused the sun
to move backward,
and he gave a longer life
to the king.

God's Spirit gave him power
to see the future,
and he comforted those in Zion
who were in sorrow,

by telling them the secrets
hidden in the future
as far as the end of time.

ⓓ The memory of Josiah
is pleasant,
like skillfully mixed incense
or the taste of honey,
or like music at a banquet
where wine is served.

He did right and led the nation
to get rid of its idols
and turn back to God.

Many had rejected God's Law,
but Josiah was faithful
and encouraged others
to obey God.

David, Hezekiah, and Josiah
were good kings,
but the other kings of Judah
sinned terribly
and rejected the Law
of God Most High.
So he took away their kingdom

and gave their glorious power
to foreigners

ⓔ who burned down Jerusalem,
the city God had chosen
for his temple.
The city streets lay empty,
just as Jeremiah had said.

He had been chosen as a prophet
before his birth
and was later told to speak
of doom and destruction,
of rising and rebuilding.
But the evil kings of Judah
mistreated him.

ⓕ Ezekiel saw a vision
of the Lord's glory
above the living creatures
that were his chariot.

ⓖ God said that Job
always did what was right.

I pray that the twelve prophets
will live on
in their descendants
because they helped Israel
stand firm during hard times
by giving them hope.

ⓗ What is the best way
to praise Zerubbabel?
He was like a valuable ring
on the Lord's right hand,

ⓘ as was Joshua son of Jozadak.
They built a holy temple
for the Lord,
and it will always be famous.

ⓙ We should honor Nehemiah
because he rebuilt
the homes in Jerusalem;
he repaired the city walls
and put in strong new gates.

No one like Enoch
has ever been born—
he was taken up
from earth to heaven.

And no one like Joseph
has ever been born—
he kept Israel from starving
and ruled his brothers;
then after his death,
the people of Israel
watched over his bones.

Shem and Seth are also honored,
but of all God's creatures,
Adam was the greatest.

High Priest Simon
the son of Onias
repaired and fortified
the temple,

and he laid the foundations
for the high double walls
that went around it.[114]

Simon also dug a cistern[115]
as big as the large bronze bowl
called “the Sea.”[116]

He fortified Jerusalem
and drew up plans
in case it was ever attacked
or surrounded.

When he came out
from the Most Holy Place
and walked among the people,
he looked glorious,

like the morning star
between the clouds
or a full moon
during a festival,

or like sunshine on the temple
of God Most High,
or a brilliant rainbow
set against beautiful clouds.

Seeing him was as pleasant
