as the first roses of spring
or lilies beside a stream,
or green grass on a hot day
in the Lebanon mountains.

He was majestic, like the smoke
from burning incense,
or a golden bowl set with jewels
of every kind,

or like an olive tree
heavy with olives,
or a cypress tree
reaching toward the clouds.

The whole temple courtyard
reflected his glory
when he wore his special robes
and went up to the sacred altar.

Then he stood beside the altar,
and other priests gave him
the sacrifices to be burned.
These priests stood around him
like palm trees near a cedar
in the Lebanon mountains.

They wore beautiful robes
and held the sacrifices
in their hands.
All Israel watched

while Simon placed each offering
on the altar fires.

Then he was handed a cup
of blood-red wine,
which he poured out
at the foot of the altar
as a pleasant-smelling offering
to God Most High,
the King of all creation.

After this, the priests shouted
and blew silver trumpets,
making a loud noise
as a prayer
to the Most High God.

Immediately, everyone bowed
with their face to the ground
to worship the all-powerful
Lord God Most High.

The temple choir began singing,
and sweet songs of praise
echoed through the courtyard.

Meanwhile, the people prayed
to their God,
the merciful Lord Most High,
until the ceremonies of worship
were finished.

ⓚ Then Simon came down
from the altar
and raised his hands
to praise the Lord
and to bless the people
in his name.

They bowed down again
to receive Simon's blessing
and to worship God Most High.

Praise the God of all creation,
because he works miracles
everywhere on earth.
He watches over us as we grow,
and shows mercy to us.

Now we pray for happiness
and peace in Israel,
as it used to be.

May he be merciful
and rescue us before we die.
*

Two nations I hate are Edom[117]
and Philistia,

and I also hate
the people of Shechem—
those fools are unworthy
to even be called a nation.

My name is Jesus son of Eleazar
son of Sirach,[118]
and I wrote this book
to help you learn and understand
the wisdom that overflows
from my heart.

If you read and pay attention
to the wisdom in this book,
you will be happy and wise.

The Lord's wisdom gives light
to the pathway of life.
Follow wisdom,
and you will never fail.

I praise you, Lord God,
because you are my king,
and you rescued me.
I give you thanks

for protection and help
when I was in danger
from enemies
who tried to destroy me
with cruel lies.

My enemies wanted me dead
and were about
to gobble me up,
but you had pity and rescued me
from the trouble they caused.

I was surrounded by fires
they had set,
and I could not breathe
for the smoke.
*

Death was ready to swallow me,
because their filthy lies

had reached the king.
I was standing at the edge
of an open grave.

Enemies surrounded me,
and I called for help—
but no one came.

Then, Lord, I remembered
your mercy and kindness
and how you have always saved
those who trusted you
when they were attacked
by evil people.

So I prayed and cried out,
“Don't let me die!

I am in trouble,
facing arrogant enemies
with no one to help me.
But you are my Lord and Father,
so please don't let me down.
Rescue me,

and I will honor you forever
with songs of praise.” I know you heard my prayer,

because you saved me from death
and rescued me from danger.
That's why I thank you
and give you honor and praise.
*

When I was young
and before I had traveled,

I prayed in the temple courtyard
and openly asked for Wisdom.
And I will look for her[119]
every day of my life.

Now I am old,
but ever since I was a child,
I have loved Wisdom
and always followed her
on the path where she walked.

When I listened even a little
to what she said,
I learned many things.

So I continued to study,
and I praise God,
who gives me Wisdom.

I chose to live by Wisdom
and always do right,
and I have never had a reason
to be ashamed.

Whenever I had to struggle
to follow her completely,
I would lift my hands in prayer
and tell God I was sorry
I knew so little of Wisdom.

But I was set on finding her,
and I did, by removing sin
from my heart.
Now, I grow wiser and wiser,
and she will never leave me.

I made the effort to find Wisdom
because I really wanted her,
and she is worth it all.

The Lord also rewarded me
with a gift for using words,
and so I will use that gift
to offer him praise.

If Wisdom is a subject
you have never studied,
then come to my school.

If your desire for her
is like a great thirst,
why haven't you quenched it?

Here is my advice—
you cannot buy Wisdom,

and you need not travel far.
You just have to be willing
to do what she says.

Studying wisdom has filled
my life with peace,
and you can see it is worth
any effort I have made.

And even if learning Wisdom
costs you a lot of silver,
she will bring you
even more in gold.

Celebrate the mercy of God!
Don't be ashamed to tell others
how great he is.

Work when it is time to work,
and God will reward you
when the time is right.

books.name: Baruch
books.original_language_note: Chapters 1-5 likely composed in Hebrew (ch. 1:1-3:8) and Greek (ch. 3:9-5:9); no Semitic original survives

verses.text: <sup>ⓐ</sup> I am Baruch son of Neriah and grandson of Mahseiah, and my ancestors include Zedekiah, Hasadiah, and Hilkiah. I wrote this book in the city of Babylon
on the seventh day of the month of Ab,<sup>[1]</sup> exactly five years after the Babylonians had captured and burned down Jerusalem.<sup>[2]</sup>
<sup>ⓑ</sup> I read the book to King Jehoiachin<sup>[3]</sup> of Judah, son of Jehoiakim, and to everyone who came to listen:
the government officials and the religious leaders, together with all the people of Israel, both young and old, who lived in Babylon near the Sud River.<sup>[4]</sup>
After they had listened to me read the book, everyone cried and prayed to the Lord, then went without eating to show their sorrow.
They collected as much money as they could
and sent it to Jerusalem for Priest Jehoiakim<sup>[5]</sup> and the other priests, as well as for the people living there.

On the tenth day of the month of Sivan,<sup>[6]</sup> I got together all the sacred things that had been taken from the Lord's temple in Jerusalem and took them back to Judah. These included the silver things that King Zedekiah of Judah<sup>[7]</sup> had made

and that King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia<sup>[8]</sup> had taken from Jerusalem. He brought these to Babylon, along with King Jehoiachin, the important leaders of Judah, the prisoners, and most of the people.

The Jews living in Babylon wrote the following letter for Baruch to take with him to Judah: Please use the money we are sending to buy animals for sacrifices to please the Lord<sup>[9]</sup> and sacrifices for sin, as well as to buy incense and to prepare grain offerings. These sacrifices and offerings must be offered on the altar built to honor the Lord our God.
Pray that King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia and his son Belshazzar will live forever, like the heavens above.

And pray that the Lord will keep our people strong and show us how to be faithful. Then King Nebuchadnezzar and King Belshazzar will be pleased with us and protect us, and in return we will be loyal to them.
Finally, pray for us—we have sinned against the Lord our God, and he is still angry.
When you go to the temple during festivals and other religious celebrations to confess your sins to the Lord, be sure to have this book read aloud.

Pray the following prayer when you confess your sins to the Lord: The Lord our God always does right, but we are deeply ashamed of what we have done. We are the people of Judah and Jerusalem, but all of us,
including our kings and rulers, our priests and prophets, are guilty. Even our ancestors did what was wrong!
We have all sinned against the Lord our God.
We have disobeyed him and have refused to follow the laws he has given.
In fact, ever since the Lord brought our ancestors out of Egypt, we have been unfaithful and have ignored him.

<sup>ⓒ</sup> The Lord rescued our ancestors from Egypt, so that he could give them a land that is rich with milk and honey. He also warned his servant Moses that terrible things would happen, if our ancestors refused to obey the Lord. And so, because they disobeyed him, we are suffering from those curses.
Even when the Lord's prophets came and told us how the Lord our God wanted us to live, we refused to listen.
Instead, we did what we wanted and followed our own evil ways—we worshiped other gods and did what the Lord hated.
That's why the Lord did everything he threatened. He punished our judges, our kings, and our leaders, as well as the people of Israel and Judah.<sup>[10]</sup>
The Lord severely punished the city of Jerusalem, just as he had warned in the Law of Moses. Nothing on earth has ever been as horrible as that destruction.
There was so little food that some of us ate our own children.
The Lord scattered our people all over the world, where foreign nations ruled over us and insulted and made fun of us.
Our country was defeated and humiliated in every way, because we had disobeyed the Lord our God and sinned against him.
Our Lord God, we are filled with shame, just as our ancestors were in the past. You were right
to punish us terribly, just as you had warned us.
Even then we refused to stop our evil ways and turn back to you.
All your commands are completely fair, yet we were unfaithful and rejected the Law you had given us. That's why you punished us in all these painful ways that you had kept ready for us.
Lord God of Israel, you brought your people out of Egypt and worked miracles to show your mighty power. You made a great name for yourself, and you are still famous.
But we have sinned against you, our Lord God. We have been unfaithful and have disobeyed all your commands.
There are only a few of us left here in the nations where you scattered us. Please stop being angry!
Listen to our sincere prayer and rescue us, so that you will bring honor to your name. Let those who led us away as captives have pity on us.
Then everyone in the world will know that you, the Lord God, have chosen the people of Israel to be your very own.
Look down from your home in heaven, Lord, and think about us. Listen when we call out to you.
Open your eyes and see how we are suffering. Those who are in the world of the dead have no life and cannot praise you or tell others how fair and just you are.
But even though we are in terrible pain, and we can hardly see or walk, we are alive. And so we can praise you and tell others how good you are.
Our Lord God, we pray for your mercy, even though our ancestors and our kings refused to do what was right.
You have punished us in your anger, just as your servants the prophets warned.
<sup>ⓓ</sup> Long ago, your prophets gave us your message and told us that if we would obey the king of Babylonia and serve him, we would not be carried away from our homeland.
They told us that if we refused to obey you and serve the king,
<sup>ⓔ</sup> you would make Judah and Jerusalem places of sadness where no joyful sounds are heard, even at wedding feasts. You threatened to make our country an empty wasteland.

<sup>ⓕ</sup> We did not obey your command to serve the king of Babylonia. So you have done everything you threatened to do, just as your prophets warned. The bones of our kings and our ancestors were dug up
and now lie scattered all over, scorched by the sun during the day and covered with frost at night. Our ancestors died horrible deaths from starvation, war, and disease.
And because the people of Israel and Judah did evil, you destroyed the temple that was built in your honor, and it lies in ruins even today.
But you, Lord God, have shown us mercy. You are always patient and kind,
<sup>ⓖ</sup> just as you told your servant Moses on the day you commanded him to write down your Law while our ancestors watched. Then you said:
If you refuse to obey me, I will scatter you among the nations, and this mighty nation of yours will be nothing but a handful of people.
Yet I know you will disobey me, because you people are stubborn! Someday, after you have been taken captive and forced to live in foreign nations, you will realize what you have done.
Then you will know I am the Lord your God. I will give you a new heart, and you will be faithful and will listen to what I say.
There in the nation where you are living, you will praise me and turn back to me.
You will remember what happened to your ancestors when they sinned against me, and you will stop being stubborn and wicked.

Then I will let you return to the land that I promised to your ancestors Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. You will once again rule there and increase in numbers. Never again will you be a small, powerless country.

<sup>ⓗ</sup> I will make a solemn agreement with you, and it will last forever—I will be your God, and you will be my people. I will promise never again to take you out of the land that I have given you as your own.
Lord All-Powerful, God of Israel, we are worn out with trouble and distress, and we pray to you for help.
Though we have sinned against you, won't you answer our prayer and have mercy on us.
You rule as king forever, but when we die, we are gone forever.
So when we cry out to you, please listen. We are almost dead, because we are being punished for the sins of our ancestors.
Forget their sins, and think only of your own power and glory.
You are the Lord our God, and we will praise you.
You have made us fear you, so that we would pray to you. We are here as captives, yet we will praise you and turn from the sinful ways of our ancestors.
They sinned against you, and you have punished us by scattering us here among the nations, where we have been insulted and cursed.
<sup>ⓘ</sup> Listen carefully, people of Israel, so you can learn about wisdom and the commands that lead to life.
You have lived in this enemy land so long that you are now much older. You are unfit to worship the Lord and are unclean, like a dead body.<sup>[11]</sup>
In fact, you are almost dead yourselves! Don't you know why these things are happening to you?
It's because you have turned away from the only source of wisdom.
If you had followed the ways of God, you would have lived in peace forever.
Learn where wisdom, strength, and knowledge come from. Then you will know how to have a long and peaceful life, and you will find light to guide you.
<sup>ⓙ</sup> No one knows where Wisdom<sup>[12]</sup> lives or where she keeps her treasures.
People have tried hard to find her, including rulers of nations, people who tamed wild animals
and raised birds, greedy people who did anything to get more of the silver and gold they believed would protect them,
and selfish people who worried about not having enough money and thought of ways to make more. But all of these people have disappeared—they died
and went to the world below, and others have taken their place.
Neither could any of their descendants find the way to knowledge. They couldn't find out how to gain Wisdom or even how to look for her.
The Canaanites and the Edomites never heard of Wisdom.

The Ishmaelites<sup>[13]</sup> think they have knowledge, but they haven't found Wisdom. They are just like the merchants of Merran and Teman<sup>[14]</sup> or the story-tellers or those who desire intelligence—none of them has learned the way to true Wisdom.
<sup>ⓚ</sup> People of Israel, the universe that God has created is very large! He lives here and controls the entire world.
There is no end to the universe, and no one can measure its width or height.
<sup>ⓛ</sup> Long ago, the famous giants were born here. They were powerful and skilled warriors,
yet God did not choose them to be his own or tell them the way to knowledge.
So they all died because they were fools and lacked Wisdom.
No one has gone up into heaven and brought Wisdom down to earth.
No one has sailed across the ocean and found her or bought her with pure gold.
There's no one who knows how to gain Wisdom or how to find the path that leads to her.
God alone knows Wisdom, because he knows everything. In fact, he discovered Wisdom with his own knowledge. God created the earth to last forever, and then filled it with all kinds of animals.
When he commanded light to shine, it trembled and obeyed, and now goes wherever he sends it.
Even the stars obeyed his voice, and they are happy to shine wherever and whenever he commands.
He is our God, and nothing is as great as he is.
God found the complete way to knowledge, then gave it to his servant Israel, the one he loved.
Since then, Wisdom has lived on earth among human beings.
<sup>ⓜ</sup> Wisdom is found in the book of God's laws and teachings, and they will last forever. Everyone who follows Wisdom will live, but those who ignore her will die.
People of Israel,<sup>[15]</sup> you must turn to Wisdom and keep her with you always. Her light shines brightly, so walk toward it.
Don't give away to any other nation the glorious Wisdom that rightfully belongs to you.
We should celebrate, because we are the people of Israel, the only ones who know what pleases God.
Be brave, my people. Keep Israel's name alive!
You were not sold to enemy nations to be destroyed. Instead, those nations dragged you away as captives because you did things that God hated.
God is your Creator, yet you made him angry by offering sacrifices to demons instead of to him.
You rejected the eternal God who gave you life. And you caused much sadness for Jerusalem, the city that was a mother to you.
When she saw God punish you in anger, she said: Listen to me, you nearby towns. God has made me very sad,
because I have watched my children Israel being dragged away to foreign nations. The eternal God has done this to punish them!
I was very happy raising my children, but now I cry and mourn while they are taken from me.
Please don't be happy about my sadness. I am a widow and a deserted city—all of my children have been forced to leave because they rejected God's Law.
They ignored and refused to obey his teachings. His laws would have helped them live right, yet my children simply refused to obey.
Come and see how the eternal God has punished my children by leading them away as captives!
God brought a cruel and foreign nation here, and it had no pity on anyone, whether young or old.
That nation stole my sons and daughters, and now I am a lonely widow.
As for you, my children Israel, I can do nothing to help you.
God punished you in these terrible ways, and now only God can rescue you from your enemies.
<sup>ⓝ</sup> Go on with your life, my children—I am alone.
I have taken off the clothes I wore during my time of peace, and I have put on the clothes that show I am in mourning. I will cry out to the eternal God until the day I die.
Be brave, my children, and beg God to help you! He is the one who will rescue you from your powerful enemy.
I know without a doubt that the Holy and eternal God will save you. In fact, it makes me happy to think that he will soon show you mercy.
I cried and moaned as I watched you leave, but God will bring you back to me, and I will celebrate and shout forever.
The neighboring cities also watched while you were taken captive. And soon they will see your eternal God save you with his mighty and glorious power.
For now, my children, be patient. God has punished you in anger, and your enemies rule over you. Yet soon they will be destroyed, and you will have power over them.
My dear children, you are suffering now in a foreign nation, like sheep that have been dragged off by an enemy.
Be brave and cry out to God for help. He has not forgotten you, even though he has done all these things to punish you.
Just as you were determined to turn away from God in the past, you should be ten times more determined to obey him now.
The same God who punished you with these disasters will save you and give you never-ending happiness.
City of Jerusalem, be brave! Your God chose you long ago as his own, and he will soon comfort you.
Disaster will come to those nations who mistreated you and celebrated your destruction.
The cities that made your children their slaves will one day be miserable, and the city of Babylon, where your people now live, will suffer pain.
Babylon was glad when you fell and were destroyed; now she will moan at her own destruction.
God will turn her pride into mourning, and she will no longer be proud of her great people.
The eternal God will send down fire, and she will burn for days and days, until nothing can live there except demons.

Jerusalem, look toward the east and be glad, because God is bringing your children home! They were once dragged away as captives, yet at his command they are now gathered together from the east and the west and are praising God's glorious power.
<sup>ⓞ</sup> Jerusalem, take off the clothes that show you are sad and mourning. Put on the beautiful clothes of God's bright glory and never take them off!
Wear the robe of God's justice and the crown of his eternal power.
God will let every nation on earth see your brightness,
and he will give you this new name forever: “Right-Living-Brings-Peace and Faith-in-God-Brings-Honor.”
So stand on top of the mountain and look east. Our Holy God has gathered your children from the east and the west, and they are celebrating because he hasn't forgotten them.
<sup>ⓟ</sup> Their enemies forced them to leave on foot, and now God will bring them back to you with great honor, as if they were kings being carried on beautiful thrones.

He has commanded every high mountain and ancient hill to be made low, and every valley to be filled up, so that the people of Israel can return home safely on level ground. They will show God's glory to the world.
God has commanded every forest and every sweet-smelling tree to shade the Israelites
as he leads them home, and they will celebrate and shout for joy on their way. The brightness of God's own glory will guide them, and his mercy and justice will go with them.

books.name: Epistle of Jeremiah
books.original_language_note: Likely composed in Hebrew or Aramaic; earliest witness is a Greek fragment from Qumran (7Q2, ~100 BC)

verses.text: <sup>ⓐ</sup> This is a copy of the letter that Jeremiah the prophet sent to the people of Judah and Jerusalem, just before the king of Babylonia took them as captives to the city of Babylon. The letter contains the message God sent Jeremiah to tell them.
You have sinned against God! That's why King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylonia<sup>[1]</sup> is taking you as captives to Babylon.
You will be forced to live there a very long time—as long as seven generations. Then God will lead you home in peace.

While you are in Babylon, you will see people carrying around idols made of silver and gold and wood. The people worship these so-called gods out of fear that something terrible might happen if they refuse.
Don't act like these heathens or be frightened into worshiping their idols.
When you see crowds worshiping idols, tell yourselves to worship only the Lord,
and God's angel will help you.
Idols are not really gods—they can't even talk! They are covered with gold and silver, and their tongues were carved out of wood.
People make gold crowns like the ones young women love to wear, and they put these crowns on their idols.
Sometimes the priests steal the gold and silver from these idols and spend it on themselves
or give it to temple prostitutes.<sup>[2]</sup> People dress up their idols as if they were human, even though they are nothing but chunks of silver or gold or wood.
They cannot even protect themselves from rust and decay.<sup>[3]</sup> They are decorated with purple robes,
but someone needs to wipe off their faces when dust from the temple settles on them.
These idols hold a scepter<sup>[4]</sup> in their hands, just like human judges, yet these idols have no power to punish any criminal.
Some of them even hold small swords or axes, but they cannot defend themselves from being destroyed in war or stolen.
All of this proves that idols are not gods. So don't fear them!
A broken dish is useless!

And so are the idols in the temples. They can't see, because their eyes are covered with the dust that people stir up when they walk. These idols are locked up in their temples like prisoners about to be put to death for committing a crime against the king. They can't protect the temples, so the priests must close the heavy doors and lock them with bolts to keep robbers out.
The priests light more lamps in honor of the idols than they do for themselves, yet the idols can't see even one of them.
These idols are nothing but wood, just like the beams in the temple, and their insides and their clothes are eaten by worms and insects. They don't even know
when the smoke in the temple makes their faces black.
Bats, swallows, and other birds perch on their heads and bodies, and cats sleep on them.
All this proves that idols are not gods. So don't fear them!

No matter how much money it took to make these idols, there is no life in them. They didn't feel a thing when they were being made out of melted gold poured into molds—even the gold used to make them beautiful must be polished before it shines.<sup>[5]</sup>
They are so helpless that they must be carried around—they can't walk on their own. People who worship idols are put to shame,

because whenever an idol falls, someone has to pick it up. And after someone sets it back up, the idol cannot move itself anywhere. Even if an idol starts to lean, it cannot straighten itself up. Offering gifts to an idol is no better than giving gifts to a dead body.<sup>[6]</sup>

The priests sell the sacrifices that have been offered to these idols and spend the money on themselves. And their wives use salt to preserve any leftover meat from the sacrifices, then save it for their own use, instead of giving it to the poor.

Women who are having their monthly periods or who have just given birth are even allowed to touch the sacrifices offered to these idols.<sup>[7]</sup> Such things prove that idols are not gods. So don't fear them!
How could these idols of silver and gold and wood ever be gods, when women are allowed to make offerings to them?<sup>[8]</sup>
The priests shave their beards and hair when they mourn, then they go to the temples in torn clothes, where they sit with their heads uncovered.
They moan and shout in the temples of these idols, just as some people do at a funeral.
They even take some of the idols' clothes and give them to their own wives and children.
You see, it doesn't matter how anyone treats these idols—they cannot reward or punish in return. Idols aren't able to help anyone become king or take away a king's power.
They can't make people rich or force them to pay for not keeping a promise.
These idols cannot keep anyone from dying or protect the weak from the strong.
They can't give sight to a blind person or rescue someone from danger
or show mercy to widows and orphans.
These idols are nothing but chunks of wood covered with gold and silver. They are no more powerful than stones dug from a mountain, and all who worship them will be put to shame.

Only a fool would think that these idols should be called gods! The Babylonians dishonor their own gods by deserting them when they are unable to help. For example, when the Babylonians see a person who cannot talk, they ask the god Bel to heal that person, as if Bel can really hear and understand.
<sup>ⓑ</sup> But when the Babylonians realize these gods have no sense, they just leave them.<sup>[9]</sup>
Some Babylonian women wrap cords around their heads as a decoration,<sup>[10]</sup> then they sit along the roads, burning incense and offering themselves as prostitutes.<sup>[11]</sup>
And after one of them returns from sleeping with a stranger, that prostitute makes fun of the one sitting next to her for not being pretty enough to be chosen.
Everything the Babylonians do to serve their idols is useless. How could anyone ever believe that idols are gods?
Idols are made by woodworkers and metalworkers, and so the idols always turn out to be exactly what the workers want.
These workers are humans and die like everyone else.
How could they ever make a god? The only thing they can leave for future generations is deceit and disgrace.
When war or trouble comes, priests must decide where they will go to escape and hide with their so-called gods.
The idols cannot save themselves from war or trouble because they aren't gods.
Idols are nothing more than wood covered with gold and silver. Someday people will finally realize that they are fake.
People from every nation, including kings, will know that these powerless idols were made by human hands.
Everyone will realize that they are not gods.<sup>[12]</sup>
Idols don't have the power to make someone king or to send rain.
They can't make their own decisions or free a person who has been wronged. They are powerless
and as useless as crows flying through the air. If a temple catches on fire, the priests will run to safety. But since the idols are merely wood covered with gold or silver, they will burn like logs.
Since idols cannot oppose an enemy or a king, it's foolish to believe they are gods.
These wooden idols covered with silver and gold cannot even protect themselves from thieves,
who strip off the silver and gold, as well as the clothes. All of it can be easily carried off by robbers because these false gods can do nothing to stop them.
Anything is better than an idol, including a brave king, a household pot, a door that protects things in a house, or a wooden column in a palace. All these are more useful than false gods.
The sun, moon, and stars, as well as the lightning and the wind, all do what they are supposed to do.
And when God tells clouds to cover the earth or commands fire to burn forests, they also obey. But idols cannot do a thing!
No one should ever believe that idols are gods. They can't help anyone or make decisions about justice.
You know they are not gods, so why fear them?
Idols cannot punish or bless kings,
and they can't make strange things happen in the sky. They don't shine like the sun or the moon.
Even wild animals are better off than idols—at least they can run to protect themselves from danger.
Nothing shows that these idols are gods. So don't fear them!
The Babylonian gods are pieces of wood covered with gold and silver, and they are as helpless as a scarecrow guarding a cucumber patch.
They are like a thornbush that birds use as a place to perch or like a dead body thrown out into the darkness.

The purple linen<sup>[13]</sup> robes they wear will rot—this also proves they are not really gods. Someday the idols themselves will waste away to nothing, and they will be a disgrace to their worshipers.
People who do right have no use at all for idols. And these people are better off, because they will never be put to shame.

books.name: Prayer of Azariah & Song of the Three Young Men
books.original_language_note: Likely composed in Hebrew or Aramaic; inserted into Daniel 3:23-24 in Greek/Latin Bibles. Contains Prayer of Azariah + narrative + Song of the Three

verses.text: <sup>ⓐ</sup> Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah<sup>[1]</sup> walked around in the flames, singing praises to the Lord God.
Then Azariah stood still and prayed out loud:

You, Lord God of our ancestors,
are worthy to be praised,
and your name
should be honored forever.

Everything you do is right;
your decisions bring justice.

You were right to punish us
and to destroy holy Jerusalem,
the city of our ancestors.
Our people have sinned;

we have broken all your laws
and turned away from you.

We have disobeyed,
even though your commands
were for our own good.
You were right to punish us

and to let us be conquered
by our hateful enemies.
They refuse to obey your Law,
and the most evil king on earth
is their ruler.

They insult us, your servants.
We are a disgrace
and have no excuse. But we worship and obey you.

Please, Lord, for the sake
of your reputation,
keep your agreement with us,
and someday set us free.

You loved Abraham;
Isaac obeyed you,
and you chose Jacob.[2]
For their sakes, don't take
your mercy from us.

You promised to give them
more descendants
than there are stars in the sky
or grains of sand on a beach.

But we sinned,
and so we have become
the smallest nation.
We are ashamed

because we have no rulers,
no prophets, no leaders.
We have no incense, no altar,
and no sacrifices to please you
or to ask for your mercy.

But if we are humble
and truly sorry for our sins,

you will accept us
as if we had offered
a thousand rams and bulls
and ten thousand fat lambs. You never disappoint those
who trust you, Lord.
We want to be your followers,[3]
so please answer our prayer.

We promise with all our hearts
to worship and obey you
and to continue praying.

So please be patient with us
and show us your mercy.

Work a miracle and rescue us,
so that you, Lord,
will be honored.

We, your servants, pray
that those who have harmed us
will be disgraced;
crush their mighty power
so they will fail.

Show them that you alone
are the glorious Lord God,
the Ruler of all the earth.
<sup>ⓑ</sup> After the king's servants threw Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah into the furnace, the servants kept tossing in oil, tar, dried flax plants, and small pieces of firewood.
The flames blazed up 22 meters above the furnace,
and they also shot out from the furnace and burned the Babylonians who were standing nearby.
<sup>ⓒ</sup> But one of the Lord's angels came down into the furnace to protect Azariah and his two friends. The angel forced the flames out of the furnace,
so that the inside of the furnace felt as if a cool breeze were blowing. The fire didn't touch the three men at all, and it caused them no pain or trouble.
Then Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah praised God together in the furnace, and they sang:

You, Lord God of our ancestors,
are always worthy
to be praised.

Your glorious and holy name
will always deserve
the greatest honor.

So let songs of praise
be sung in your holy temple
for all time.
*

There, from your throne
above the winged creatures,

you watch everything on earth
and rule the world
with glory and majesty.
We pray that your praises
will be sung forever.

And age after age
in the starry skies,
songs will be sung
to honor you.
Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah continued to sing:

All of creation
should sing praises
to the Lord forever. *

ⓓ Everything in the heavens
and the water above the sky
*

should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*

The angels and the rulers
in the heavens

should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*
The sun, the moon,

and the stars
should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*
The wind and the rain

and the dew,
*

as well as the freezing snow,
*
and the fiery heat

should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*

The dark of night
and the light of day

should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*

The frost and snow,
*
the icy cold,

and the thunderstorms
should sing praises
to the Lord forever.[4]

Everything on this earth
should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*
The mountains and hills

and all trees and plants
should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*

The springs and rivers,
*
together with the oceans

and every sea creature,
whether large or small,
should sing praises
to the Lord forever.
*
Each bird in the sky,

and every animal,
wild or tame,
should sing praises
to the Lord forever.

Every human should sing praises
to the Lord forever,
*
especially his priests

and his chosen people.
*

We humans should be humble
*
and obey the Lord

with all our heart and soul,
and we should sing praises
to him forever.

The three of us—
Hananiah, Azariah,
and Mishael—
should sing praises
to the Lord forever,
because if he hadn't rescued us,
we would have died
in a flaming furnace
and gone down
to the world of the dead.

So praise the Lord
for his goodness,
and praise him for his mercy,
because it will never end.

Everyone who worships the Lord,
the Supreme God,
should sing his praises
and thank him for his mercy,
because it will never end.

books.name: Susanna
books.original_language_note: Debated: wordplay in Greek (σχῖνος/σχίσει, πρῖνος/πρίσει) suggests Greek composition, but some scholars argue for a Semitic original. Addition to Daniel (ch. 13 in Catholic Bibles)

verses.text: A man named Joakim lived in the city of Babylon
and was married to a very beautiful woman, Susanna the daughter of Hilkiah. Susanna faithfully worshiped the Lord
and obeyed the Law of Moses, just as she had been taught by her parents, who were very religious.
Joakim was very rich and had a large walled garden<sup>[1]</sup> next to his house. He was the most highly honored Jewish man in Babylon, and all the other Jews would come and talk with him.

One year, two of the older Jewish leaders were appointed to be judges for their community in Babylon. The Lord had said he would punish older leaders who refused to obey his laws and rule the people wisely.<sup>[2]</sup> And that is exactly what these leaders did.
The two judges spent so much time at Joakim's house that people went there to have their cases judged.
Each day, the people left the house at noon, then Susanna would go for a walk in her husband's garden.
The two men watched her every day as she walked in the garden, and soon all they could think about was sleeping with her.
They even stopped praying to God and forgot that they were supposed to be fair when they judged legal cases.
Each of them was so ashamed of his desire for her, that they didn't tell the other how they felt.
Day after day they would wait around, hoping to get a look at her.
One day at noon, they said, “It's lunchtime—let's go home.” They left in different directions,

but before long they both turned around and went back to Joakim's house. They saw one another, and each started asking the other why he had come back. Finally, they both admitted they wanted to sleep with Susanna, so they agreed to find a time when they could catch her alone.
The two men watched for their chance, and one hot day, Susanna went into the garden to take a bath. Two of her servant girls were there with her,
though no one else was in the garden, except the two men, who were watching her from their hiding place.
Susanna told her servants, “Bring me some soap and lotion, then close the gates to the garden so I can bathe.”<sup>[3]</sup>
The servants did what she said. They shut the main gates to the garden, then they went into the house through the side gate and brought her some soap and lotion. But they did not see the two men.
As soon as the servants had gone, the men left their hiding places. They ran over to Susanna
and said, “Look, the gates are shut, and no one can see us here in the garden. We both want you, and so you had better agree to what we want!
If you refuse, we will testify in court that we saw you send your servant girls away so you could make love with a young man.”
<sup>ⓐ</sup> “I'm trapped, and there's no way out,” Susanna moaned. “If I give in to you, I could be put to death.<sup>[4]</sup> If I refuse, you will have me killed.
But it is better to refuse and to suffer what you can do to me, than to sin against God.”
Susanna screamed for help,<sup>[5]</sup> and the two leaders began shouting at her.
One of them ran to the main gates of the garden and opened them.
The household servants heard the noise, and they all rushed in through the side gate to see what had happened to Susanna.
But when they heard the two men accusing her, the servants were ashamed. No one had ever said such things about Susanna before.
The next day, the Jewish people in Babylon came together at Joakim's house. The two men also arrived, ready to go ahead with their terrible plans to have Susanna put to death.
They went to the front of the crowd and said, “Someone bring in Joakim's wife Susanna, the daughter of Hilkiah.”
Susanna came in, along with her parents, her children, and all her relatives.
Susanna was a beautiful woman with a very good figure.
When she came in, her face was covered with a veil. But the two evil men wanted to get one last good look at her, so they ordered her to take off her veil.
Susanna's family was crying, and so was everyone else.
The two men stood in the middle of the group and put their hands on Susanna's head, so they could officially accuse her.<sup>[6]</sup>
But Susanna trusted the Lord to rescue her, and as she cried, she looked up toward heaven.
Then the two men said: While we were walking in the garden, Susanna came in with two servant girls. She shut the gates and told them to leave.
Then a young man came out of hiding and went over to her, and they lay down and started making love.
We were over in the corner of the garden, and we realized they were disobeying God's Law, so we ran over to them.
We saw them making love, but we weren't able to catch the young man, because he was stronger than we were. He opened the gates and ran off.
We grabbed Susanna and asked her who the young man was,
but she refused to tell us. We swear we are telling the truth. Both men were leaders and judges, and so everyone believed them and agreed that Susanna should be put to death.
Susanna cried out, “Eternal God, you know all secrets and everything that will happen in the future.
You know these two men have told evil lies against me in court today. Now I am going to be killed, even though I haven't done anything wrong.”
The Lord heard Susanna's prayer,
and as she was being led away to be executed, he chose a young man named Daniel to help her. Daniel was upset
and shouted, “I will not take part in murdering this woman!”
The crowd turned to him and asked, “What do you mean?”
Daniel went to the center of the crowd and said, “People of Israel, are you fools? You have condemned one of your own women to death, and you haven't even tried to find out what really happened.
Go back to court, and I will prove that the two men who accused Susanna were lying.”
Everyone rushed back to the place where the trial was held, and the group of leaders told Daniel, “So God has chosen you to be a leader, too! Sit down and tell us what you mean.”
Daniel said, “Separate the two men who accused Susanna, and take them far enough away that they can't hear us. Then I will call them over one at a time and question them.”
When the two had been taken to different places, Daniel called the first one over and said: You are an evil old man, and it's clear that you've been sinning for a long time.
<sup>ⓑ</sup> You've been giving unfair decisions in court. You have set the guilty free and condemned innocent people, even though the Lord said not to put an innocent person to death.
Now, you have testified that Susanna was making love with a young man under a tree. So tell us, what kind of a tree was it? “It was a small gum tree,” the man answered.
“Is that so?” Daniel replied. “You will pay for that lie with your head! God has already sent his angel to cut you in half.”<sup>[7]</sup>

Daniel ordered the people to take the first man aside and to bring over the second one. Daniel told him: You're not a Jew; you're a filthy Canaanite! You were under the spell of Susanna's beauty, and your desire for her made you do wrong instead of right.
You two men have been frightening women from Israel into sleeping with you. But this faithful Jewish woman wouldn't stand for your evil ways.
Now tell me, when Susanna and this young man were making love, what tree were they under? “They were under a big oak tree,” the man answered.
“Is that so?” Daniel replied. “You will pay for that lie with your head! The Lord's angel is waiting to chop you in half,<sup>[8]</sup> and then both of you leaders will be dead.”
The crowd shouted praises to God, because he rescues those who trust him.

<sup>ⓒ</sup> Then they condemned the two leaders, since their answers to Daniel's questions proved they had lied in court to have Susanna killed. The Law of Moses says that anyone who does this should be put to death, and that is what quickly happened to the two men. And so an innocent woman's life was saved.
Susanna's father and mother praised God, and so did her husband Joakim and all her relatives, because she had been found innocent of a shameful crime.
And from then on, Daniel was famous.

books.name: Bel and the Dragon
books.original_language_note: Likely composed in Greek or possibly Aramaic/Hebrew; addition to Daniel (ch. 14 in Catholic Bibles). Two Greek versions survive (OG and Theodotion)

verses.text: When King Astyages was buried in the tomb with his ancestors, Cyrus the Persian took his place as king.<sup>[1]</sup>
Daniel was a friend and advisor of King Cyrus, and the king honored him more than anyone else.
<sup>ⓐ</sup> Every day, the Babylonians took food to the idol of their god Bel.<sup>[2]</sup> They brought 272 kilograms of the best wheat flour, 190 liters of wine, and the meat from 40 sheep.
King Cyrus believed that Bel was a powerful god, and he worshiped the idol every day, but Daniel worshiped only his own God. One day, Cyrus asked Daniel, “Why don't you worship Bel?”
Daniel answered, “I refuse to worship idols—they are made by humans. Instead, I worship the living God, because he created heaven and earth, and he rules everyone who lives.”
“But, Daniel,” the king replied, “isn't Bel a living god? Haven't you seen how much he eats and drinks each day?”
Daniel laughed and said, “Don't be fooled, Your Majesty. That idol is merely clay on the inside and bronze on the outside! It never ate or drank anything.”
This made the king angry. So he called in his priests and told them, “Prove to me that Bel<sup>[3]</sup> is eating all this food! If you can't, then you will die.
But if you can prove that Bel really is eating the food, then Daniel will die, because he has insulted the god Bel.” Daniel said, “Your Majesty, that sounds fair enough to me.”
Now there were 70 priests of Bel, and they and their wives had lots of children. The king went with Daniel into the temple of Bel,

and the priests said, “Your Majesty, we will go outside now. Please set out the food and the wine yourself, then shut the door. Drip some hot wax along the edge of the door and press your ring into the wax to leave your special mark. This will show that only you are allowed to open the door.<sup>[4]</sup>

When you come back in the morning, if you find that Bel hasn't eaten everything, then you can put us to death. But if the food is gone, this will prove Daniel has been lying, and you can put him to death.”
The priests were not worried at all. They had a secret trap door under the table, and that was how they sneaked into the temple every night to eat the food.

The priests left, and the king arranged Bel's food on the table. Then Daniel told his servants to scatter ashes over the temple floor. The king was the only other person who saw them do this. They shut the door as they went outside, and the king placed his special mark on some hot wax along the edge of the door so that they could tell if the door had been opened. Then they all left.
Later that night, the priests and their wives and children went to the temple as they always did, and they ate and drank everything.
Early the next morning, the king brought Daniel to the temple
and asked him, “Daniel, has the wax been broken? Has the door been opened?” “No, Your Majesty,” Daniel answered.
As soon as the door was opened,<sup>[5]</sup> the king looked at the empty table and shouted, “Bel, you are a great god, and you always tell the truth!”
Daniel just laughed. He kept the king from entering the temple and said, “Look at the floor—I wonder who left all those footprints?”
The king said, “I can see the footprints of men, women, and children!”

He was furious and told his guards to arrest the priests along with their wives and children. Then the priests showed him the secret door they used when they sneaked into the temple to eat the food that was on Bel's table.
The king told his guards to kill the priests and their families. Then he gave the temple and the idol of Bel to Daniel, who had them destroyed.
The Babylonians also worshiped a huge dragon<sup>[6]</sup> as a god,
and the king of Babylonia said to Daniel, “You can't say this god isn't alive! So you ought to worship it.”
Daniel answered, “I worship the Lord, because he is the living God.
Your Majesty, if you will give me permission, I will kill this dragon, without striking it with a sword or a club.” “I give you permission to try,” the king replied.

Daniel put some tar and animal fat and hair in a pot and boiled them together. Then he shaped the mixture into cakes that looked something like loaves of barley bread and fed them to the dragon. It swelled up and burst open, and Daniel said, “Take a look at what you Babylonians worship.”

But when the Babylonians heard what had happened, they were so upset with the king that they began plotting against him. “Has the king become a Jew?” they asked each other. “First he destroyed our idol Bel and killed its priests. And now he has killed our dragon-god.”
The Babylonians went to the king and said, “Hand Daniel over to us. If you don't, we will kill you and everyone in your family!”
The king saw that he really had no choice, and so he was forced to let them have Daniel.

<sup>ⓑ</sup> The Babylonians kept seven lions in a large pit and fed them two people and two sheep each day. Daniel was thrown into this pit, and for the next six days the lions were given no other food. The Babylonians wanted to make sure the lions would eat Daniel.
Meanwhile, far away in Judea, the prophet Habakkuk had made a pot of stew and put some pieces of bread into a bowl. He was about to take it to the workers who were harvesting wheat in the fields,
when an angel told him, “Take this meal to the lion pit in Babylon, and give it to Daniel.”
Habakkuk replied, “But, sir, I've never been to Babylon, and I don't know where the lion pit is.”
<sup>ⓒ</sup> The angel lifted up Habakkuk by his hair and carried him to Babylon as fast as the wind. He set Habakkuk down at the edge of the lion pit,
and Habakkuk shouted, “Daniel, take this food God has sent you.”
Daniel prayed, “Thank you, God, for remembering me. You always take care of those who love you.”
Daniel got up and ate the food, while God's angel quickly returned Habakkuk to his home.
Seven days later, the king came to the lion pit to mourn for Daniel. But when he looked into the pit, he saw Daniel sitting there, alive.
Then the king shouted out this prayer: “You, the Lord God of Daniel, are powerful! You alone are the true God!”
The king ordered Daniel to be pulled up out of the pit, then he arrested the men who had tried to have Daniel killed. The king had them thrown into the pit, and he watched the lions gobble them up.

books.name: 1 Maccabees
books.original_language_note: Composed in Hebrew (attested by Jerome and Origen); Hebrew original lost, surviving only in Greek

verses.text: Alexander the Great<sup>[1]</sup> led his army from Macedonia to attack Darius, the king of Persia and Media. He conquered Darius and became the first Greek to rule that part of the world.<sup>[2]</sup>
Alexander fought a lot of wars; he captured strong fortresses and put kings to death.
In fact, he went across the whole earth and took the treasures of many countries. Every nation on earth surrendered to Alexander, and he became very famous, but also very arrogant.
He gathered a powerful army and conquered lands, nations, and rulers, forcing them all to pay taxes to him.

Alexander had ruled for twelve years, when he became sick and knew he was going to die. So he called together some of the men who had grown up with him. They were now his most famous generals, and he gave each one a part of his kingdom.
The generals each took control of their countries.
Then after Alexander's death, they crowned themselves kings. Their descendants also ruled as kings<sup>[3]</sup> for many years and caused trouble all over the world.

<sup>ⓐ</sup> Antiochus Epiphanes,<sup>[4]</sup> the evil son of King Antiochus the Third<sup>[5]</sup> of Syria, was a descendant of one of these generals and had been a hostage in Rome.<sup>[6]</sup> Then in the year 137<sup>[7]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, he became its ruler.

About this time, some worthless Jews rejected God's Law and talked many others into following them by saying, “Let's make an agreement with the Gentiles around here. We've had nothing but trouble ever since we stopped cooperating with them.”
Many of the people thought this was a good idea,
and with great enthusiasm they went to King Antiochus, who gave them permission to live like Gentiles.
So these Jews built a place in Jerusalem just like those in Gentile cities where young men exercise in the nude.

<sup>ⓑ</sup> Some of them even had surgery to keep anyone from knowing they had ever been circumcised. And so, they broke their agreement with God by cooperating with Gentiles and doing other evil things.
<sup>ⓒ</sup> When Antiochus had everything under control, he decided to attack Egypt and make it part of his kingdom.
So he got together a powerful army, including chariots and elephants, and he also gathered a large navy. Then he invaded Egypt
and attacked the army of King Ptolemy the Sixth,<sup>[8]</sup> who turned and ran, losing many of his troops.
Antiochus captured the Egyptian towns and fortresses and took everything of value.
<sup>ⓓ</sup> In the year 143<sup>[9]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, as Antiochus was leading his powerful army home, he attacked Jerusalem.
He walked arrogantly right into the Jerusalem temple and took the gold altar, the lampstand, and everything that went with it.

He took the table for the sacred loaves of bread as well as the special bowls, the cups for wine offerings, the curtain, the crowns, and the gold pots for burning incense. Antiochus even stripped off every piece of the gold decoration from the front of the temple.
He also took the silver, the gold, the fine dishes, and the other treasures that he found hidden in the temple.
Then he returned to his own country with the things he had stolen. Antiochus had murdered many people and boasted about what he had done. *

And so, all of Israel's leaders
and everyone else
cried and moaned.

ⓔ Young people became sick,
and women
lost their beauty.

Newlyweds sang about death
and mourned
on their wedding day.

The land itself felt sorrow,
and everyone in Israel
was terribly ashamed.
Two years later, Antiochus sent an officer to collect taxes from the towns in Judea. The officer led a strong army to Jerusalem,
and he lied to the people by promising peace. They believed him, but suddenly he attacked Jerusalem, damaging the city and killing many of its people.
After taking everything he wanted, he set fire to the city, destroying its houses and walls.
His soldiers even dragged away women, children, and livestock.
Antiochus ordered his army to build a fortress in Jerusalem<sup>[10]</sup> and put up high, thick walls and strong towers.
There they stationed some Jewish troops who had rejected God's Law.
They stored in the fortress the weapons, the food, and everything they had stolen from Jerusalem. And they became a great threat.

The soldiers in the fortress
attacked the temple
and never stopped doing
horrible things to Israel.

They killed innocent people
all around the temple,
and they made it unfit
as a place of worship.

Everyone ran from Jerusalem.
Their own city became
a foreign country to them,
and strangers moved in.

The temple was barren
just like a desert,
and its festivals and Sabbaths
became times of sorrow
and of shame.
Jerusalem had lost all respect.

Shame and sorrow replaced
its former glory and pride.
Antiochus wanted everyone in his kingdom to follow the same customs. So he made a law that said, “You must give up the traditions of your ancestors.”
The Gentiles obeyed the king, and many Jews gladly accepted his religion. They offered sacrifices to idols and broke the laws of the Sabbath.
Messengers from Antiochus brought letters, telling everyone in Jerusalem and in all the towns of Judea about this law. They said: You must obey the king's law and accept these new customs.
Don't offer sacrifices in the temple or celebrate the Sabbath and your other festivals.
Make the temple and everything in it unfit for the worship of your God.
Build altars and other special places for worshiping our gods and for sacrificing pigs and other animals that your laws forbid.
Don't circumcise your sons. Forget about what your religion teaches is right or wrong.
Change your laws and forget about those teachings.
Anyone who doesn't obey the king will be put to death.
After Antiochus had sent this law to everyone in his kingdom, his officials went to every town of Judea and tried to make sure the Jews offered sacrifices to foreign gods.
Many of the people obeyed the king and gave up God's Law. They did evil things everywhere
and forced the faithful Jews to go into hiding.

<sup>ⓕ</sup> On the fifteenth day of the month of Chislev<sup>[11]</sup> in the year 145<sup>[12]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Antiochus set up a “Horrible Thing”<sup>[13]</sup> on the temple altar. His followers built altars in towns all around Judea,
and they burned incense in front of their houses and in the streets.
Antiochus' soldiers tore up and burned any copies of the Jewish Scriptures that they found.
They obeyed Antiochus and murdered everyone they caught obeying God's Law. These troops also killed any Jew who owned a copy of the Scriptures.
Month after month and in town after town, his soldiers tortured every faithful Jew they captured.
On the twenty-fifth day of each month, the king's followers offered sacrifices on the altar they had put on top of the temple altar.
<sup>ⓖ</sup> They followed orders and murdered any Jewish mother who let her son be circumcised.
Antiochus even told these troops, “Hang the baby around his mother's neck, and kill the whole family, as well as the man who circumcised the baby.”
Many Jews firmly made up their minds never to eat what their religion said was unclean.
They chose to die rather than to eat forbidden food and break the agreement God had made with them. Many of them died,
and the nation suffered terribly.
About this time, Mattathias,<sup>[14]</sup> a priest from the family of Joarib, moved from Jerusalem to Modein.

Mattathias had five sons, whose names were John, Simon, Judas, Eleazar, and Jonathan. Each son had a nickname. John was called Gaddi, Simon was known as Thassi, and Judas was called Maccabeus.<sup>[15]</sup> Eleazar was nicknamed Avaran, and Jonathan was known as Apphus.
When Mattathias found out that the people of Judea and Jerusalem were rejecting God's Law,

he said: Why have I lived to see
enemies crushing my people
and the holy city?
Foreigners now occupy Jerusalem;
they have taken over the temple,
making it a place of shame.

All of its sacred objects
have been dragged away.
Young people are slaughtered
by enemy swords,
and our streets are covered
with the bodies of children.

Is there any nation
that hasn't robbed us
and stolen our treasures?

Jerusalem—once glorious—
has lost its beauty
and is now a slave.

The holy temple was our pride
and our joy,
until foreigners ruined it
with their filthy idols.
We'd be better off dead!
Mattathias and his five sons cried bitterly; they tore their clothes and put on sackcloth<sup>[16]</sup> to show their sorrow.
The king's officials were trying to force everyone to break the Law of Moses by offering pagan sacrifices. And one day the officials went to the town of Modein,
where many of the people came out to meet them, including Mattathias and his sons.
The officials said to Mattathias: You're an important and honored leader in this town, and your relatives will follow your example.

So why don't you obey the king and accept his religion, just as every Gentile and Jew in Judea and Jerusalem has already done? Then you and your family will be known as “Trusted Friends of the King,”<sup>[17]</sup> and you will be rewarded with gold and silver and other gifts.
Mattathias answered in a loud voice: What do I care if everyone in the king's entire kingdom turns from their own religion and starts obeying his laws?
My family and I will always keep the promises our ancestors made to God.
We will never give up our faith or disobey even one of God's laws. We will not obey Antiochus!
When Mattathias finished speaking, everyone watched as a Jew from Modein stepped forward to obey the king by offering a sacrifice on the altar.
Mattathias was furious, and he was so eager to see justice done that he rushed over to the altar and killed the man.
Then he destroyed the altar and killed the official who ordered the sacrifice.
<sup>ⓗ</sup> Indeed, Mattathias showed that he loved God's Law as much as Phinehas,<sup>[18]</sup> who had killed Zimri the son of Salu many years ago.
Mattathias shouted to everyone in Modein, “Follow me, if you truly love the Law of Moses and want to keep our agreement with God!”
Then Mattathias and his sons ran to the hills, leaving behind everything they owned.
Many of the Jews were now in serious trouble for trying to obey God and live right. So they took their families and livestock and moved to the desert.
But the king's officers and soldiers in the fortress at Jerusalem found out what these Jews had done.
<sup>ⓘ</sup> So a large number of the troops went after them and camped nearby. Then on the Sabbath
they said to the Jews, “This is your last chance! Come out and obey the king's orders, or you will die.”
The Jews answered, “We're not coming out! And we refuse to break the laws of the Sabbath by obeying the king's orders!”
At once the enemy forces attacked.
But the Jews did not try to defend themselves; not one of them threw a rock or even tried to pile up rocks in front of the caves.
They just said, “We've done nothing deserving death! Everyone in heaven and on earth knows that you are wrong to kill us.”
On that Sabbath 1,000 Jewish men, women, and children were slaughtered, together with their sheep and goats.
<sup>ⓙ</sup> When Mattathias and his followers heard what had happened, they mourned a long time.
Then they said to each other, “We can't let that happen to us! We've got to defend ourselves and our way of life, even on the Sabbath. If we don't, the Gentiles will soon wipe us out.”
On that very day they made up their minds not to die like their relatives in the caves, and they decided to fight anyone who attacked them on the Sabbath.
About this time a very devout group of Jews<sup>[19]</sup> joined Mattathias; they were some of the nation's best fighters and were willing to die for God's Law.
In fact, many others had found themselves in trouble with the Gentiles, and they also went to Mattathias, who soon had a large force.
Then those angry troops violently attacked the unfaithful Jews, forcing those who escaped to run to the Gentiles for protection.
Mattathias and his followers tore down every altar they found.
They had the young boys in Israel circumcised,
and they terrorized their arrogant enemies. Everything went well for Mattathias and his troops,
because they defended their laws against the Gentiles and Antiochus. No evil person stood a chance.
Right before Mattathias died, he said to his sons: The Gentiles are proud and violent, and we're going to have a horrible time.
But you, my sons, should be faithful to God's Law and be willing to die for the agreement that our ancestors made with God.
Keep in mind their brave deeds, and you will be famous forever.
<sup>ⓚ</sup> Abraham was faithful when God tested him, and so God accepted him.
<sup>ⓛ</sup> Joseph obeyed God in a time of trouble, and he became ruler of Egypt.
Because our ancestor Phinehas obeyed everything in God's Law, the men of our family have become priests forever.
<sup>ⓜ</sup> Joshua followed God's orders and became a leader of Israel.
Caleb told the people of Israel the truth, and God gave him some of the land.
<sup>ⓝ</sup> David's family will rule as kings forever because David had mercy on others.
<sup>ⓞ</sup> Elijah obeyed God's Law and was taken to heaven.
<sup>ⓟ</sup> Hananiah, Azariah, and Mishael trusted God, so he saved them from the flames.
<sup>ⓠ</sup> Daniel was rescued from the hungry lions because of his loyalty to God.
Think about these past heroes. They trusted God and were strong.
Don't let the threats of that brutal Antiochus frighten you! He may be famous, but he's nothing but food for worms.
He talks big now, but soon you won't hear that loud mouth anymore. Dust is all that will remain of him and his plans.
My sons, you must find courage and strength in God's Law; then everyone will honor you.
Your brother Simon is wise. So always obey him, just as you would obey me.
Judas Maccabeus has been a brave fighter all his life. Now he will command your army and lead you in battle.
Find soldiers who love God's Law and then lead them to punish everyone who has mistreated your people,
including the Gentiles. Always follow God's teaching.

Mattathias blessed his sons, and then he died. His family buried him in their tomb near the town of Modein. This happened in the year 146<sup>[20]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, and everyone in Israel mourned for a long time.
Judas Maccabeus took his father's place as leader.
His four brothers and his father's soldiers eagerly helped him fight for Israel.

Judas was a mighty warrior
and made Israel more glorious
than ever.
When he put on his armor
and took up his sword,
he marched into battle
and protected his troops.

He roared and attacked
like a hungry lion.

He went after those Jews
who disobeyed God's Law,
and he burned to death those
who abused his people.

Judas confused and terrified
everyone who broke God's Law,
but he kept his people safe.

Kings were furious
because of his victories,
but Israel rejoiced.
Judas will be remembered
and praised forever.

After Judas had killed
the unfaithful Jews
in the towns of Judea,
God was no longer angry.

Now the whole world knew
that Judas had rescued those
who were to be slaughtered.
A man by the name of Apollonius<sup>[21]</sup> decided to invade Israel. So he got together an army of Gentiles and many Samaritans.
When Judas learned about this, he attacked, killing Apollonius and a large number of his soldiers. The others ran for their lives.
Then everyone took what they wanted from the dead soldiers. Judas himself took Apollonius' sword and used it from then on.
Seron, the commander of the Syrian forces, heard about Judas and the many loyal troops who were always ready to fight for him.
Seron thought, “Judas and his soldiers are rebels. So I'll destroy them and make a name for myself everywhere in the kingdom!”
Then Seron led his soldiers and a large number of unfaithful Jews out of his camp to attack them.
While Seron and his army were going through the hills toward the town of Beth-Horon,<sup>[22]</sup> Judas and a small force went out to attack.

But when they saw the enemy closing in, they said, “There are only a few of us. How can we fight against such a strong army? And besides, we feel weak, because we haven't had anything to eat all day long.”
Judas said to his soldiers: God doesn't care how many soldiers Seron has or how few we have. Our small army can easily destroy his forces.
It isn't the size of the army, it is the power of God that wins battles.
Seron and his troops are arrogant sinners who want to kill us and our families, so they can steal everything we own.
But we're fighting for our faith as much as for ourselves.
God will let us wipe out Seron's army. So don't be afraid!
Judas and his soldiers struck quickly. They defeated Seron and his army
and chased them to the valley below the hills of Beth-Horon. Eight hundred enemy soldiers were killed, and the rest ran away to the country of the Philistines.
The Gentiles in this whole region were now terrified of Judas and his brothers.
In fact, everyone talked about his victories so much that even King Antiochus<sup>[23]</sup> finally heard about Judas.
Antiochus was furious and brought his troops together from everywhere in his kingdom to build up a powerful army.
He took money from his treasury and gave each soldier a year's pay. Then he told them, “Be ready to fight at a moment's notice!”
Soon Antiochus ran out of money, and it became difficult to collect taxes, because of the hard feelings and trouble he had caused by doing away with the ancient customs of the land.
Once again Antiochus started worrying about how he would pay his bills and outdo the other kings before him who gave expensive gifts.
He was so upset that he decided to take his army and collect all the taxes he could from Persia and the other countries nearby.
A man by the name of Lysias was a respected member of the royal family<sup>[24]</sup> and King Antiochus put him in charge of the land from the Euphrates River to the border of Egypt.
Then Antiochus told him: Look after my son<sup>[25]</sup> until I get back.
I am placing half of my army and all of my elephants under your command. Obey my orders, especially concerning the people of Judea and Jerusalem.
Destroy the army of Judas and kill anyone you find in Jerusalem. Make the whole world forget that those Jews ever lived
and give their land to Gentiles.
In the year 147<sup>[26]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Antiochus and the rest of his army set out from the capital city of Antioch. They crossed the Euphrates River and started through Mesopotamia.
Nicanor, Gorgias, and Ptolemy the son of Dorymenes were three important and trusted friends<sup>[27]</sup> of Antiochus. So Lysias chose them as army commanders.
He told them what the king had commanded and gave them 40,000 soldiers and 7,000 cavalry troops to invade and destroy the land of Judea.
Nicanor, Gorgias, and Ptolemy then led the whole army to Judea and set up camp in the valley near the town of Emmaus.

Local slave traders heard about these three commanders and went to their camp, taking with them chains<sup>[28]</sup> and plenty of silver and gold to buy Israelite prisoners as slaves. Armies from Syria and the land of the Philistines<sup>[29]</sup> also came.
Judas and his brothers realized things were worse now than ever, because their enemies had invaded Judea with orders from the king to wipe out the Jewish people.
But Judas and his brothers were determined to make their nation strong again and to defend their people and temple.
So Judas organized an army, and when his troops were ready, they prayed for God's mercy and kindness.

Jerusalem was a barren desert
that no one could enter
or leave.
The temple was trampled down,
and foreign troops
took over the fortress.
Everyone in Israel was sad;
their flutes and harps
were silent.
Judas led his army a short distance from Jerusalem to the town of Mizpah, which had been a place of worship.
That day Judas and his troops went without eating; they put on sackcloth,<sup>[30]</sup> then rubbed ashes on their heads and tore their clothes.
Instead of praying to idols, as the Gentiles do, they read in their Jewish Law to find what God wanted them to do.

They also brought together a tenth of their crops and the best part of their harvest, as well as the clothes of the priests. Judas also called together those who had completed their time of special service to God<sup>[31]</sup> and now had to offer sacrifices.

Then everyone prayed out loud: Where can we take these people
to offer their sacrifices?

Your temple has been disgraced
and made unfit for worship;
the priests are humiliated
and brokenhearted.

Our God, you know these Gentiles
are here to destroy us,

and there is nothing we can do
without your help.
Then trumpets were blown, and everyone shouted.
Judas divided his army into groups of 1,000, groups of 100, groups of 50, and groups of 10, and he put an officer in charge of each group.
<sup>ⓡ</sup> He obeyed the Law of Moses by sending home any soldier who was either building a house or engaged to get married or who was planting a vineyard or was simply afraid to fight.
Judas and his troops left Mizpah and set up camp south of the town of Emmaus,
where he said to them: Our enemies have come together to destroy us and our temple. So get your weapons ready and be brave! We'll attack early tomorrow morning.
It's better to die in battle than to watch our country and temple crumble.
But God will do whatever he has decided.
During the night, Gorgias<sup>[32]</sup> took 5,000 soldiers and 1,000 of his best cavalry and left Emmaus
to make a surprise attack on Judas. He was led there by some men from the fortress in Jerusalem.
But Judas found out what Gorgias was planning. So he and his soldiers left their camp to attack the troops that Gorgias had left behind at Emmaus.
Late that night, when Gorgias arrived at the camp of Judas, no one was there. He thought Judas and the others were hiding in the hills, and so he led his troops after them.
Meanwhile, Judas and his 3,000 soldiers came to the valley near Emmaus about dawn. They did not have enough swords or armor for the battle,
and they saw expert cavalry patrolling every side of the well-guarded camp.
Judas told his troops: The enemy army is strong, but don't be afraid when they attack.
Years ago our ancestors were attacked at the Red Sea<sup>[33]</sup> by the king of Egypt and his army, but God rescued them.
Let's ask God to be kind and keep the agreement he made with our ancestors. If God helps us defeat Gorgias today,
then every Gentile will know that our God saves and rescues his people.
The Jewish troops started toward the Gentiles, who saw them coming
and went out to fight. Then Judas shouted, “Blow the trumpets
and attack!” The Jews crushed the Gentiles and chased their soldiers to the valley,

killing everyone they caught. Some of the enemy troops ran as far as the towns of Gazara, Azotus, and Jamnia. Others reached the valley near Idumea. Judas went after them, and that day three thousand Gentiles died.
After Judas and his men had stopped chasing the enemy,
he said to everyone: Don't be eager to take anything from the bodies of the dead now. We will still have to fight
Gorgias and his troops when they come out of the nearby hills. Then you can take anything you want.
About this time, an enemy patrol came out of the hills.
They saw smoke and knew that their army and their camp had been wiped out.
Then they looked over at the valley and saw the Jewish army lined up for battle. They were terrified
and ran to the land of the Philistines.<sup>[34]</sup>
Judas now went back and let his soldiers take whatever they wanted from the enemy camp. They found bags of gold and silver, as well as some blue and purple cloth, and many other valuable things.
Then on the way home, they sang hymns of praise to God who had given them a great victory that day. They sang: “Our God, your mercy lasts forever!”
Some enemy soldiers escaped and told Lysias everything that had happened.
Lysias was confused and completely disappointed, because he had failed to wipe out the Jews, as King Antiochus had ordered him to do.
The next year, Lysias got together 60,000 of his best soldiers and 5,000 cavalry to crush the Jews.
He then led this army to Idumea, where he set up camp near the town of Beth-Zur. Judas and 10,000 soldiers marched out to fight Lysias.

<sup>ⓢ</sup> When Judas realized how powerful the enemy force was, he prayed: Our God, we praise you for always rescuing us. When Saul was king, you let your servant David kill a Philistine giant. You also let Saul's son Jonathan and one other soldier capture an entire Philistine camp.
Now help us destroy this enemy camp and make fools of their soldiers and cavalry.
Turn them into cowards who are too weak to fight, and make them tremble while we destroy them.
Our God, we love you. Please let us slaughter our enemies. Then all of your worshipers will praise you with songs.
The two armies moved forward, and in the battle, Lysias lost 5,000 soldiers.<sup>[35]</sup>

As he watched his army falling apart, he said to himself, “Those Jews are brave fighters, who live and die with honor.” Lysias returned to the city of Antioch and hired some foreign soldiers, so he could invade Judea with an even stronger army.
Judas and his brothers said, “Now that we've defeated our enemies, let's make the temple an acceptable place for worship and dedicate it to the Lord once again.”
So the entire army went to Mount Zion.<sup>[36]</sup>

They saw the deserted temple and the unclean altar, where the Gentiles had sacrificed unfit animals. The temple's doors had been burned, and the priests' rooms were damaged. Tall bushes and weeds were growing in the temple courtyard, making it look like a forest or a mountain.
Judas and his soldiers grieved terribly. They tore their clothes, then threw ashes on their heads
and lay face down on the ground. A trumpet was blown, and they began praying out loud to their God.
Judas ordered some of his soldiers to keep the enemy fortress under attack, so that others could clean up the temple.
He chose honest and faithful priests
and put them in charge of cleaning out the temple. The priests hauled away the unclean stones to a garbage heap.

And they wondered what to do about the altar for offering sacrifices, because it had been polluted by the Gentiles who had sacrificed unclean animals on it. Finally, they decided to remove this disgrace by tearing down the altar and hauling away the stones.
They piled them in a special place on the temple hill, believing that God would someday send a prophet who would know what to do with them.
<sup>ⓣ</sup> The priests did just as the Law of Moses commands. They found stones that had never been cut, and they set up a new altar exactly like the old one.
The priests also rebuilt the inside and the outside of the temple, and they cleaned the temple courtyard, making it a proper place for worship once again.
The priests made some new bowls to be used in worship, and they took into the temple the lampstand, the incense altar, and the table for the sacred bread.
They burned incense on the altar and lit the lamps on the stand, filling the temple with light.
Then they set the sacred bread on the table and hung up the temple curtains. Finally, everything was done.

<sup>ⓤ</sup> <sup>ⓥ</sup> It was now the twenty-fifth day of Chislev,<sup>[37]</sup> the ninth month, in the year 148<sup>[38]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom. On this day the priests got up early to sacrifice an animal on the new altar, just as the Law of Moses commands.

Exactly three years earlier, the Gentiles had offered sacrifices to their idols on the altar and had made it unfit for worship. But now the priests were worshiping God at the altar again, while the rest of the people sang and played harps, cymbals, and small stringed instruments.
Then everyone lay face down on the ground to honor and praise the Lord who had given them victory.
<sup>ⓦ</sup> For eight days they celebrated the dedication of the new altar and offered gifts and sacrifices to thank the Lord and to ask his blessing.
The people decorated the front of the temple with gold crowns and small shields, and they repaired the rooms where the priests lived, hanging new doors in them, as well as new gates for the temple.
Everyone was happy because the disgrace that the Gentiles had brought on the temple had been removed.

Judas and his brothers, together with everyone else, decided to celebrate the dedication of the altar<sup>[39]</sup> each year at this same time. This joyous festival would begin on the twenty-fifth day of the month of Chislev<sup>[40]</sup> and last eight days.
Then they built strong walls and high towers around Mount Zion to protect the temple from being destroyed by Gentiles again,
