and Judas stationed soldiers there. He also built a fortress in the town of Beth-Zur to keep Israel safe from attack by the Idumeans.
When the neighboring nations heard that the altar and the temple were again ready to be used in worship, they became furious
and were determined to kill every Jew who lived among them. So they started killing the Jewish people.

Judas fought back by attacking the Idumeans,<sup>[41]</sup> who had often ambushed the people of Israel. Finally, in the region of Akrabattene,<sup>[42]</sup> he wiped out most of them and took everything of value.

Then Judas promised God, “Now I'll destroy the Baeanites, that gang of robbers and murderers who set traps for Jewish travelers.” So he ordered his troops to surround the towers where they were hiding and to burn down the towers with everyone inside.
Judas also invaded the country of Ammon, where someone by the name of Timothy ruled a large number of people. Timothy's army was strong,
and Judas had to attack many times before completely destroying it.
Judas captured the town of Jazer and its villages, then he went back to Judea.
Some of the Israelites in Gilead took shelter in the fortress at Dathema, because an army of Gentiles in that region planned to attack.
Then they sent a letter to Judas and his brothers. It said: An army of Gentiles is about to surround us at Dathema,
and their leader is Timothy.<sup>[43]</sup>
Please send help at once. These Gentiles have not only killed many of us,
but they've robbed and murdered just about every Jew in Tob<sup>[44]</sup> and captured their families. Almost 1,000 have already died.
Before Judas finished reading this letter, messengers arrived from Galilee. They had torn their clothes to show their sorrow,
and they said, “An army is ready to destroy us. It is made up of Gentiles from all over Galilee and of troops from the cities of Ptolemais, Tyre, and Sidon.”
Judas and his troops listened to these reports. Then they called together a large group to decide what should be done to help those who were in danger and under attack.
Judas said to his brother Simon, “Take some soldiers to Galilee and rescue our people. Our brother Jonathan and I will lead an army to Gilead.”
Judas left two officials, Azariah and Joseph,<sup>[45]</sup> in command of his troops in Judea, and he told them, “You're in charge. But don't attack the Gentiles until we return.”
Simon led 3,000 soldiers to Galilee, and Judas took 8,000 to Gilead.
In Galilee, Simon had to attack the Gentiles many times before completely destroying them.
He and his soldiers pushed them back to the city of Ptolemais, where they killed about three thousand Gentiles and took everything they wanted.
Simon brought the Jews of Galilee and Arbatta,<sup>[46]</sup> along with their families and their possessions, to Judea. When they arrived, everyone was shouting and celebrating.
Meanwhile, Judas Maccabeus and his brother Jonathan crossed the Jordan River and traveled through the desert for three days.
Some friendly Nabateans<sup>[47]</sup> told them everything Timothy<sup>[48]</sup> had done to the Jews in Gilead.

They said: Your people are being kept prisoner in the large, walled towns of Gilead, including Bozrah, Bosor, Alema, Chaspho, Maked, and Carnaim. Besides this, the Gentiles are going to attack your fortresses tomorrow, and in one day they can overpower your troops there and kill everyone.

Judas and his army saw that the attack had already begun, so they hurried along the desert road to Bozrah. They captured the town and killed every man and boy in it. Then they took everything of value and set the town on fire.
That night, Judas and his army left Bozrah and went straight to the fortress of Dathema,
where they arrived early the next morning. More Gentiles than could be counted were attacking the fortress with ladders and weapons to break through the walls.
Judas knew that the battle had begun, because shouts to God and trumpet blasts were coming from the fortress.
So he told his army, “Today you must fight for your people!”
Judas divided his army into three groups. Then a signal was blown on the trumpet, and the troops shouted prayers as they attacked the enemy from behind.
When Timothy and his army realized that Judas Maccabeus was leading the attack, they tried to escape. But he attacked them fiercely, and about 8,000 of them were slaughtered that day.
Judas led his army to the town of Maapha,<sup>[49]</sup> which they attacked and captured. Then after killing the men and boys and taking everything of value, they burned the town.
Judas also captured the other towns in Gilead, including Chaspho, Maked, and Bosor.
Timothy then got together another army and camped on the other side of the stream near the town of Raphon.
Meanwhile, Judas had sent out spies who came back and told him, “Timothy has a large army of Gentiles from all around here,
and he has even hired some Arabs to join him. He's camped on the other side of the stream, eager to fight with you.” Judas led his army to meet them,
and they took up their positions near the stream. When Timothy saw them, he said to his officers: If Judas crosses the stream to attack, we won't have a chance, and he will destroy us.
But if he stops and sets up camp on the other side of the stream, that means he's afraid of us. Then we will cross over and destroy him.

Judas ordered his troops to move close to the stream, then he told his officers, “Stand here beside the stream and make sure that no one stays behind to set up camp. Everyone must join in the attack.”
Afterwards, Judas led all the troops across and wiped out Timothy's army. The enemies threw down their weapons and ran for safety to a temple<sup>[50]</sup> in the town of Carnaim.
But the Jewish troops captured Carnaim and burned the temple down with everyone inside. Carnaim was left in ruins, and the Gentiles in Gilead stopped bothering Judas.

Judas brought together the Jews of Gilead, no matter how rich or poor they were. Then they set out for Judea with their families and all of their possessions. On the way, this large crowd came to the walled town of Ephron.<sup>[51]</sup> They had to go through the town, because it was impossible for them to take their families and possessions around it.
But the people of Ephron piled up stones in front of the town gates and refused to let them pass through.
Judas sent a friendly message to the town, saying, “Please let us pass through. We're on our way to Judea, and we won't make any trouble.” But the people of Ephron still refused to let them in.
So Judas ordered his troops to set up camp there,
and they attacked Ephron all day and night. When they broke through the walls,
they killed the men and boys and took everything of value. Then they destroyed Ephron and walked right over the dead bodies on their way through the town.
Judas crossed the Jordan River and came to the great valley near the town of Beth-Shan.
From there, he led the people to Judea, encouraging and helping everyone, especially those who were dragging behind.
After they had arrived safely in Jerusalem, they went to the temple and offered sacrifices.

Joseph<sup>[52]</sup> and Azariah were in command of the Jewish forces in Judea, when they heard about the victories of Judas and Jonathan in Gilead and about Simon's success in attacking the town of Ptolemais in Galilee.
And they said, “Let's attack the Gentiles around here and make ourselves famous!”
So Azariah and Joseph ordered their troops to attack the fortress of Jamnia,
where Gorgias<sup>[53]</sup> and his army were stationed. The enemy came out of the fortress to fight,
and defeated Joseph and Azariah, chasing their troops all the way to Judea and killing about 2,000 of them.
This battle was lost because Azariah and Joseph disobeyed Judas and his brothers by trying to win a victory for themselves.
God had chosen the family of Judas to rescue Israel, and Azariah and Joseph were not from that family.
Judas and his brothers became even more famous among both Jews and Gentiles,
and people traveled to Jerusalem to honor them.

Judas and his brothers left Jerusalem with an army to invade the land south of them where the Idumeans<sup>[54]</sup> lived. Their army surrounded the town of Hebron and its villages; then they destroyed its fortresses and burned its towers.
On their way to invade the land of the Philistines, Judas and his brothers came to the town of Marisa.<sup>[55]</sup>
That same day, some priests foolishly started a battle because they wanted to become heroes. But instead they died in the fighting.

Judas and his troops turned aside into the territory of Azotus,<sup>[56]</sup> where they tore down the altars and burned the wooden idols. Then they attacked and robbed some nearby towns before returning to Judea.
One day, as King Antiochus the Fourth<sup>[57]</sup> was leading his army through Mesopotamia, he heard about the Persian city of Elymais, which was famous for its treasures of silver and gold.
The temple in Elymais was especially rich because of the gold shields, armor, and weapons that had been left there by Alexander the Great,<sup>[58]</sup> the first king to rule the Greeks.

Antiochus tried to capture the city of Elymais and take its treasures. But his attack failed because the people found out about his plans and fought hard against him. Antiochus was terribly frustrated and started back toward Babylonia.
But while he was still in Persia, a messenger came and said: The Jews have crushed the armies you sent to Judea,
including the huge army Lysias<sup>[59]</sup> led there. They are now a powerful force because they have taken a lot of weapons, supplies, and other things from the armies they defeated.

<sup>ⓧ</sup> The Jews have always despised the “Horrible Thing”<sup>[60]</sup> you placed on their altar in Jerusalem. Now they have torn it down and once again built high walls around their temple and turned your town of Beth-Zur into a fortress.
Antiochus was so shocked and discouraged by this report that he got sick and had to stay in bed
for many days. He never got over the shock, and just before he died,
he called together his trusted friends<sup>[61]</sup> and said: I can't close my eyes at night. I'm sick from worry
and keep saying to myself, “How did you ever get into such a mess? Why are you up to your neck in troubles? After all, you're a kind ruler, and everyone likes you.”
My friends, I can't forget about the crimes I committed in Jerusalem. I robbed the city of its silver and gold, and I sent soldiers to murder the innocent people of Judea.
These crimes are the reason I'm dying of sorrow here in a foreign land.

Antiochus told his friend Philip to come near his bed. He put Philip in command of the whole kingdom and gave him his crown, his robe, and his ring.<sup>[62]</sup> Then he said, “Raise my son, so that he will be ready to rule the kingdom.”
Antiochus died in the year 149<sup>[63]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom.

The young son of Antiochus the Fourth had been brought up by Lysias, and when Lysias heard that Antiochus was dead, he crowned the boy Antiochus the Fifth<sup>[64]</sup> and named him Eupator.<sup>[65]</sup>
Meanwhile, some enemies were still in the Jerusalem fortress, where they were trying to keep control of the temple and help the Gentiles by causing trouble for the Jews.
Judas decided to attack the fortress and get rid of those troublemakers.
So he and his troops set up movable towers and other weapons of war and attacked in the year 150<sup>[66]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom.
Some of the troops in the fortress escaped and were joined by a group of unfaithful Jews.
Together they went to Antiochus the Fifth and said: Aren't you ever going to get even with those Jews for what they did to our group?
We gladly obeyed your father's laws, and we liked working for him.
That's why those Jews hate us and are attacking the fortress.<sup>[67]</sup> King Antiochus, they have captured and killed some of our people. They've stolen our property
and attacked all the countries near Judea as well.
Their temple and the town of Beth-Zur are powerful fortresses, and right now those Jews are attacking the fortress in Jerusalem.
Do something fast! Soon there will be no way to stop them.
When Antiochus heard this, he became furious. So he, together with his trusted friends<sup>[68]</sup> and army officers, decided on a plan of attack.
He hired soldiers from other kingdoms and from the Greek islands,
until he had 100,000 soldiers and 20,000 cavalry. He also had 32 elephants trained for war.

He led his army through Idumea, and for a long time, he attacked the town of Beth-Zur with weapons to break through the wall. But the people fought back bravely. They even rushed out of the town and set fire to the weapons of war.
Judas called off his attack on the Jerusalem fortress and led his army to the town of Beth-Zechariah,<sup>[69]</sup> where he camped not far from the army of Antiochus the Fifth.
Early the next morning, Antiochus moved his army toward them at Beth-Zechariah. Then he ordered his troops to line up for battle and to blow their war trumpets.
Some of the soldiers gave the elephants grape juice and mulberry juice to make them eager to fight.
Others then led the elephants to their places among the troops. Five hundred expert cavalry and 1,000 troops with bronze helmets and metal armor worked with each animal.
These men were commanded not to leave the elephants until the battle was over.

A strong wooden platform with four sides and a top was strapped on the back of each elephant. Then four<sup>[70]</sup> well-armed soldiers and someone from India to guide the elephant were stationed on the platform.

Antiochus placed the rest of his cavalry to the right and to the left of the army, because he wanted the cavalry troops to stay close to his army for protection and to attack the Jewish forces whenever they could.
His huge army covered the hills and the valleys. And when the columns of soldiers marched forward, their gold and brass shields caught the rays of the sun and made the hillsides blaze with light.
The loud and clanging sound of this powerful army brought terror to the hearts of all who heard them coming.
But Judas and his troops still attacked, and they killed 600 of the enemy troops.
Eleazar<sup>[71]</sup> noticed that the largest elephant was dressed in the royal armor. So he said to himself, “I'm certain Antiochus must be up there!”

Eleazar killed every enemy soldier around him, and others ran away as he bravely fought his way toward the huge elephant. Then he ran under it and stabbed it to death. But the heavy elephant sank down and crushed him. Eleazar gave up his life to save his people, and he will never be forgotten.
Suddenly the Jews realized how helpless they were against the fierce attack of the king's army, and they started running away.

Antiochus the Fifth surrounded Jerusalem with part of his army, while the rest of his troops set up camp everywhere in Judea. All of this happened during the Seventh Year,<sup>[72]</sup> when the Jews do not plant crops. Antiochus attacked the town of Beth-Zur. Its people soon ran out of food and had to stop fighting, so they surrendered and left their town.
Then Antiochus stationed his own soldiers there.
Meanwhile, his army was still attacking the troops stationed in the temple. They built movable towers and weapons that hurled fire, stones, arrows, and other deadly objects.
The Jews then built the same kinds of weapons and fought back for several days.

But it was the year when they had let the fields rest, and they ran out of supplies, because they had given what little food they had stored in the temple to those who had run away from the Gentiles and had come to Judea.
Most of the people went home, because they were starving. Only a small group was left in the temple.

Before Antiochus the Fourth died, he had made his friend Philip promise that the younger Antiochus<sup>[73]</sup> would take his place as king.<sup>[74]</sup> Philip wanted control of the kingdom, and so he brought back the part of the army that had been in Persia and Media. When Lysias<sup>[75]</sup> found out what Philip was doing,

he said to the young Antiochus the Fifth and to the officers and the soldiers: You must leave Jerusalem at once! Things are getting worse every day. We're short of food, and the enemy fortress is powerful. Besides, we have other problems to solve.
Let's sign a treaty with these Jews and the rest of their nation
to let them follow their own customs again. After all, they got angry and did all these things, because we ordered them to give up the traditions of their ancestors.
Antiochus and his officers liked what Lysias had suggested. So he promised to let the Jews live in peace, and then they left the fortress.
But when Antiochus came to Mount Zion and saw what a powerful fortress it was, he broke his promise and ordered his soldiers to tear down the fortress walls.
Then he rushed off to the city of Antioch where he found Philip in command. He attacked him and recaptured the city.

In the year 151<sup>[76]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Demetrius,<sup>[77]</sup> the son of Seleucus,<sup>[78]</sup> sailed with a few soldiers from Rome to the coastal city of Tripolis,<sup>[79]</sup> where he appointed himself king.

From there, Demetrius went to his ancestors' palace in Antioch,<sup>[80]</sup> and he arrived just as some soldiers were arresting Antiochus and Lysias. The soldiers wanted to hand them over to Demetrius.
But he said, “I don't even want to look at them!”
The soldiers put them to death, and he took command of the whole kingdom.
Alcimus, leader of the unfaithful Jews, wanted Demetrius to appoint him high priest. So one day, he and his followers went to Demetrius
and brought charges against the other Jews. They said: Judas and his brothers have killed all of your trusted friends<sup>[81]</sup> and forced us out of our country.
Please send an officer you can rely on and let him see the damage they have done to our property and to your kingdom. Then punish them and their followers.

Demetrius did as they requested and sent his trusted friend<sup>[82]</sup> Bacchides to Judea. Bacchides was a powerful and loyal official, who was governor of the region between Egypt and the Euphrates River.<sup>[83]</sup>
But Demetrius also appointed that worthless Alcimus to be high priest and sent him along with instructions to punish the people of Judea.
Bacchides and Alcimus led a powerful army to Judea. Then they sent Judas and his brothers some messengers who lied and promised peace.
But no one believed them, because Bacchides and Alcimus had brought such a large army.
Some very devout Jews wanted to make peace with the Gentiles. So they sent some of their experts in the Law of Moses to ask Bacchides and Alcimus to treat their people fairly.
These experts had said to themselves, “Alcimus has come with the army, but he is a priest from the family of Aaron, and he will surely treat us with kindness.”
Alcimus promised to let these devout Jews live in peace,
and they believed him. But he later arrested 60 of them and put them all to death in one day. This is what the Scriptures said would happen:

ⓨ The blood-stained bodies
of God's faithful people
now lie scattered
everywhere in Jerusalem.
And there's no one left
to bury the dead.
Everyone started trembling with fear and said, “Alcimus and Bacchides are deceitful liars who never keep their word.”

Bacchides moved his army out of Jerusalem and set up camp near Beth-Zaith. From there he sent soldiers to arrest some of the Jews and those troops who had deserted his army.<sup>[84]</sup> Then the soldiers murdered them all and dumped their bodies into a deep well.
Bacchides returned to Demetrius and left Alcimus with a large group of troops to control Judea.
Alcimus had a hard time keeping his position as high priest.
But a lot of troublemakers helped him, and together they took control of the nation and did horrible things to the people.
When Judas found out that Alcimus and his followers were causing so much trouble, he said, “They're worse than the Gentiles.”
Then Judas and his soldiers went to the nearby towns of Judea, punishing the unfaithful Jews, without letting any of them escape.
Alcimus realized he could not oppose Judas and his powerful army. So he returned to King Demetrius and accused them of terrible crimes.
King Demetrius had an outstanding officer by the name of Nicanor, who hated the Jews. And the king ordered him to destroy them all.
When Nicanor and his large army arrived in Jerusalem, he sent messengers with false promises of peace to Judas and his brothers.
The messengers said, “Let's not get into a fight! A few of my bodyguards and I just want to have a friendly talk with you here in your camp.”
Nicanor gave orders for his bodyguards to kidnap Judas. So Nicanor went with them to the camp, where Nicanor greeted him like a friend.
But Judas found out what Nicanor had in mind, and he was frightened and refused to meet with him.
When Nicanor realized that he could not trick Judas, he attacked him near the town of Caphar-Salama.<sup>[85]</sup>
Nicanor lost about 500 soldiers in the battle, before the rest of his army retreated to the fortress in Jerusalem.

Sometime later, Nicanor went up to Mount Zion, where he was met by some priests and leaders outside the temple. They welcomed him peacefully and showed him how they offered sacrifices as a way of asking God to bless King Demetrius.
Nicanor laughed and made fun of the priests and leaders. He even spit on them and made them unfit to serve God. He was so arrogant
and angry that he said, “If Judas and his soldiers aren't handed over to me immediately, I'll return here and destroy your temple just as soon as I defeat him.” Nicanor was furious when he left.
The priests returned to the temple courtyard, where they stared at the temple and the altar. Then with tears in their eyes, they prayed:

“You have chosen this temple
as the place where your people
must worship in your name.

Defeat Nicanor and his army!
Destroy them in battle.
Don't ever forget
how they insulted you,
and don't let them live!”
Nicanor led his troops out of Jerusalem, and they camped near the town of Beth-Horon, where they were joined by a force of Syrian soldiers.
After Judas and his army of 3,000 soldiers set up camp near the town of Adasa,<sup>[86]</sup> Judas prayed:
<sup>ⓩ</sup> Our God, a long time ago the king of Assyria sent messengers to insult you. But your angel slaughtered 185,000 of his soldiers.
Destroy Nicanor's army today, and it will show our enemies that Nicanor cannot get away with disgracing your temple.
The battle took place on the thirteenth day of the month of Adar,<sup>[87]</sup> and Nicanor's army was wiped out. He himself was the first to be killed,
and when his troops saw what had happened, they threw down their weapons and ran for their lives.
For the rest of the day, Judas and his soldiers chased the enemy troops from Adasa as far as Gazara. They blew trumpets as they went along,
and their friends rushed out from nearby villages of Judea. They attacked the enemy from the side and forced them to turn back toward Judas and his army. Not one of Nicanor's troops survived.

The Jews took everything of value from the dead enemy soldiers. Then they chopped off Nicanor's head and the right hand he had used to disgrace the temple and took them to Jerusalem, where they displayed them outside the city.
<sup>ⓐ</sup> The Jews held a joyful victory celebration and decided to celebrate on the thirteenth day of Adar each year.
And so, there was peace in Judea for a while.
This is what Judas heard about the Romans: The Romans are a famous and mighty nation. But they are kind and friendly to their allies and to other countries that ask them for help.
Powerful Roman armies have already won great victories in Gaul.<sup>[88]</sup> Not only have they defeated that country, but they have forced it to pay taxes.
The Romans have also captured the gold and silver mines in Spain.

In fact, by patient and careful planning, they have conquered all of Spain, even though it is a great distance from Rome. The Romans have crushed the kings of every nation that attacked them, and they have forced the kings who survived to pay taxes to them each year.
The Roman armies have also destroyed other enemies, including kings Perseus and Philip of Macedonia
and King Antiochus the Great of Asia.<sup>[89]</sup> The Romans even crushed the forces of King Antiochus when he attacked with chariots, cavalry, 120 elephants, and a huge army.
They took him alive and ordered him and his descendants to give them a lot of money and many hostages. Antiochus also had to hand over to them
the countries of India, Media, and Lydia, as well as some of the best areas he controlled. Then the Romans gave all this territory to King Eumenes.

When the Romans found out that the Greeks were plotting against them, they sent a general to attack the Greeks. His army killed and wounded many of them and then captured their families and took everything of value. After the Romans had conquered Greece, they tore down its fortresses, and they still rule that country today.
The Romans destroyed the rest of the kingdoms and islands that opposed them, and they put Roman rulers in charge.

But they are kind to their allies and to other nations who ask for help. If the Romans want to make someone a king, they do it. If they want to get rid of a king, they do that too. The way the Romans treat kings all over the world makes everyone terrified of them. Although Rome is a mighty nation,
its rulers don't show off by wearing crowns or purple robes.
Instead, they have built a meeting house where 320<sup>[90]</sup> senators meet each day to pass good laws for ruling their nation.
Every year, the Romans elect one man to govern them and the countries under their control. Everyone obeys this ruler, and no one is ever jealous of him.

<sup>ⓑ</sup> Judas realized that he needed to make an agreement with the Romans in order to rescue his people from King Demetrius, who wanted to make them his slaves. So Judas sent Eupolemus and Jason<sup>[91]</sup> to work out an agreement with them.
After making the long trip to Rome, they met with the Roman senators and said,
“Judas Maccabeus and his brothers, together with all our people, have sent us, because they want you to make a peace treaty with us Jews and let us be your allies.”
The Romans liked what Eupolemus and Jason said,
<sup>ⓒ</sup> and they replied by writing a letter on sheets of bronze. They sent the letter to Jerusalem, to serve as a reminder that Rome was a friend and ally. The letter said:
We pray that all will go well with the Romans and Jews, both on land and sea, and that we will never have any wars or enemies.
You Jewish people must be ready and willing to do all you can, if enemies attack Rome or any of the nations under our rule.
As it was decided in Rome, you must not send food, weapons, money, or ships to these enemies. So keep your part of this agreement and don't expect anything in return.
In this same way, we Romans will gladly do all we can if you are attacked.
We won't supply your enemies with food, weapons, money, or ships, and we will keep our word, without any tricks.
This is the agreement that we Romans have now made with you Jews,
but it can be changed, if later we both agree to do so. And any changes will be just as binding.

The Romans also told the Jewish messengers: We've written to King Demetrius about the trouble he is causing you, and we told him: “King Demetrius, the Jews are friends and allies of Rome. Why are you so cruel to them?
If we hear of any more trouble, we will defend their rights and attack you with our army and navy.”
King Demetrius found out that Nicanor and all his soldiers had been killed. So he sent Bacchides and Alcimus<sup>[92]</sup> the high priest back to Judea with half of his army.
On the way to Gilgal in Judea, Bacchides and Alcimus captured the town of Mesaloth in Arbela,<sup>[93]</sup> and they killed many of the people.
They reached Jerusalem early in the year 152<sup>[94]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom and set up camp outside the city.
Then they stationed 20,000 soldiers and 2,000 cavalry in the town of Berea.
Three thousand of the Jews' best soldiers were camped at Elasa under the command of Judas.
But when they saw the size of the enemy army, they were terrified and ran. Only about 800 soldiers stayed in camp.
When the fighting was about to start, Judas suddenly realized that most of his troops had deserted, and he was terribly discouraged because there was no time to bring them back.
Judas felt like giving up, but he said to his remaining troops, “Get ready to attack! We've got a good chance to win.”
But they argued with Judas and said, “We will all be killed if we attack with such a small force. Let's wait and come back with a larger army.”
Judas answered, “We will never back down from a fight with the enemy! If it's our time to die for the honor of our nation, then let's die like heroes.”

Bacchides led his army out of camp and placed half of his cavalry to the left of his soldiers and half to the right. His best troops led the way, followed by men who were experts with bows and arrows or rocks and slings. Bacchides himself was on the right side of his army. Both armies gave the signal to attack, and the battle began.
The fighting lasted from daylight until dark, and the ground trembled because of the noise.
At one point in the battle, Judas looked over at the right side of the enemy army and saw Bacchides and many of his best soldiers there. So Judas and his bravest troops attacked
and destroyed most of that part of the enemy army. The few who escaped were chased as far as Mount Azotus.<sup>[95]</sup>
When the soldiers on the left side of Bacchides' army learned that the rest of their army had been wiped out, they swung around and attacked from behind.
The fighting was fierce, and many from both armies were either killed or wounded.
Judas himself died in the battle, and the rest of the Jews ran away.
Jonathan and Simon took the body of their brother Judas back to Modein and buried him in the family tomb.
They cried bitterly, and everyone in Israel mourned for a long time. They said:

“Judas was a mighty warrior
who saved our nation.
Why did he have to die?”
Indeed, Judas was a brave warrior and a great hero, and he did many other important things that are not included in this book.
After the death of Judas, some troublemakers and their worthless friends showed up again everywhere in Judea.
The crops had failed that year, and everyone in the whole country joined these troublemakers.
Bacchides appointed some godless people to rule the country,
and they searched carefully for any followers of Judas. Then they brought them to Bacchides, who laughed as he punished them.
The troubles in Israel were worse now than they had been since the time God had stopped sending prophets.
The followers of Judas got together and said to Jonathan:
Ever since your brother Judas died, we haven't had anyone like him to lead us into battle against enemies like Bacchides or against our own people who hate us.
So today we have chosen you to take the place of Judas. Be our ruler and lead us in battle.
Jonathan agreed.
Bacchides plotted to kill Jonathan as soon as he found out that Jonathan was the new leader.
But his plan failed, because Jonathan and his brother Simon were warned and escaped with their followers to a camp near the water hole at Asphar in the desert around Tekoa.
On a Sabbath, Bacchides learned where the camp was, and he led his army across the Jordan River.<sup>[96]</sup>
Jonathan's brother John was also one of the Jewish leaders. One day, on orders from Jonathan, he asked some friendly Nabateans<sup>[97]</sup> to guard their huge stock of supplies.
But some people of the Jambri tribe from Medeba captured John and the supplies, then rode away.

Later, Jonathan and his brother Simon were told: The Jambri tribe is holding a big wedding celebration, and the bride is being brought here from the town of Nadabath. Many soldiers are guarding her because she's the daughter of a very important man from Canaan.
Meanwhile, Jonathan and Simon had learned that this tribe had murdered their brother John. So they left camp and set an ambush on a hillside overlooking the road.

Soon they saw a noisy group of travelers with a lot of baggage. It was the bride, with her family and friends. The groom and his friends were coming to meet them, playing drums and musical instruments, and all of them were armed.
The Jews attacked from their hiding places, killing and wounding many in the wedding party. Then they took everything of value from the dead, and the others ran off into the hills.

A wedding was turned
into a funeral,
and wedding music
into funeral songs.
After Jonathan and Simon had punished the tribe of Jambri, they returned to their camp in the marshes along the Jordan River.
But Bacchides found out where they were camped, and on the Sabbath he led a large army to the edge of the river.
Jonathan warned his soldiers: Get ready to fight for your lives! We've never been in this much danger before,
and there is no way out. The enemy army is both in front of us and behind us, and the river is on one side, and the marshes covered with thornbushes are on the other.
So pray for God to rescue us.
As soon as the battle began, Jonathan tried to kill Bacchides; however, he escaped to the rear of his army.
Jonathan and his soldiers then jumped into the river and started swimming toward the other side, but the enemy troops did not go after them.
That day Bacchides lost about 1,000 men.

Bacchides returned to Jerusalem and started building high walls and strong gates for some of the towns of Judea, including Emmaus, Beth-Horon, Bethel, Timnath, Pharathon, and Tephon, and the fortress at Jericho.
He stationed soldiers in these towns, and they caused trouble for the Jews.
Bacchides also strengthened the fortress in Jerusalem and the towns of Beth-Zur and Gazara. He put soldiers and food supplies in these strongholds.
Then he took the sons of the Jewish leaders as hostages and locked them up in the Jerusalem fortress.

In the second month of the year 153<sup>[98]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Alcimus the high priest ordered his followers to destroy the wall in the temple courtyard that prophets of earlier times had said should be built.
But no sooner had the work begun, than Alcimus got sick and everything stopped. He couldn't move or even give instructions for making out his will.
He died a very painful death.
After Bacchides learned that Alcimus had died, he returned to King Demetrius, and Judea had peace for two years.

Once again the troublemakers started plotting against Jonathan and his followers by saying, “They feel safe and aren't suspecting a thing, so let's send for Bacchides. He could easily capture them in one night.”
The troublemakers met with Bacchides and planned an attack.

Then Bacchides set out for Judea with a large army. On the way, he sent secret orders for his followers there to capture Jonathan and his troops. But they could not do this, because Jonathan and his followers learned of Bacchides' plan,
and so they arrested about fifty leaders of the plot and put them to death.
Jonathan and Simon led their forces to the desert town of Beth-Basi.<sup>[99]</sup> Part of the town had been destroyed, but they repaired it and built high walls with strong gates.
When Bacchides found out about this, he got together his whole army and sent orders to his followers in Judea.
Then he led his army to Beth-Basi and surrounded the town. His soldiers set up weapons to break through the walls, and they attacked that town for a long time.
At one point in the battle, Jonathan put his brother Simon in command of the town. Then he led a small group into the country,
where he defeated Odomera and his tribe. He also wiped out another tribe called the Phasirites.

Those who were left joined his army and helped him fight against Bacchides.<sup>[100]</sup> Meanwhile, Simon and his soldiers rushed out of Beth-Basi and set fire to the weapons that had been set up for breaking through the walls.
In fact, they destroyed the entire army of Bacchides and ruined all of his plans for war.
Bacchides was so furious at the troublemakers who had told him to invade Judea that he put many of them to death. Then he got ready to return to his own country.
When Jonathan found out Bacchides was about to leave Judea, he sent him some messengers who said, “Let's make peace and set our prisoners free.”
Bacchides agreed. He released the Jews he had captured in Judea and promised not to bother Judas again. Then he went back to his own country and never returned to Judea.
Now there was peace in Israel. Jonathan ruled from the town of Michmash<sup>[101]</sup> and started destroying godless people everywhere in the nation.

Alexander Epiphanes<sup>[102]</sup> was the son of King Antiochus the Fourth.<sup>[103]</sup> He landed on the Phoenician coast and captured the city of Ptolemais in the year 160<sup>[104]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom. The people welcomed Alexander as their king.
When King Demetrius<sup>[105]</sup> found out that Alexander was in Ptolemais, he got together a mighty army and set out to attack him.
Demetrius sent Jonathan a friendly letter that flattered him.

He was thinking, “Jonathan could not have forgotten the terrible things I did to him and his brothers and his nation. If I don't hurry and make peace with him, he will join forces with Alexander and attack.”

In the letter Demetrius said: Jonathan, you have my permission to build a strong army and to be my ally. And I have told my soldiers to release to you the hostages that I'm keeping in the fortress at Jerusalem.
Jonathan took this letter to Jerusalem and read it to everyone, including those in the fortress.
His enemies were terrified by the letter, because it allowed him to build up an army.
The soldiers in the fortress immediately released the hostages to Jonathan, and he let them go home to their parents.
Jonathan moved to Jerusalem and began repairing and rebuilding the city.
He ordered the workers to cut square blocks of stone and to build strong walls around Jerusalem and Mount Zion. The workers followed his orders.
Bacchides had left foreign soldiers in the fortresses he had built, but they quickly returned home.
Only a few Jews who were unfaithful to the Law stayed in Beth-Zur for their own safety.

Someone told King Alexander,<sup>[106]</sup> “Jonathan and his brothers are brave fighters who have fought many wars and who know what it means to suffer. And Demetrius has promised them many things if they will join him.”
Alexander replied, “I'd better make Jonathan my friend and ally. I'll never find anyone else like him.”
Alexander then sent Jonathan a letter, in which he said:
King Alexander sends greetings to his dear friend Jonathan!
I've been told that you are a powerful soldier and the kind of man who deserves to be one of my trusted friends.<sup>[107]</sup>
So I appoint you high priest for your nation and a friend of the king. This means that you must be a very loyal follower. I'm also sending you a purple robe and a gold crown.
During the Festival of Shelters, in the seventh month of the year 160<sup>[108]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Jonathan became high priest; he also built up a strong army.
When King Demetrius heard the news about Alexander and Jonathan, he was deeply distressed and said,
“What have we done? Alexander's agreement with the Jews has made him very powerful.
Now I must write a friendly letter to the Jews and promise them better gifts and more honors. Then they'll come over to my side.”
And so, Demetrius wrote: King Demetrius sends greetings to the Jewish nation.
I was very pleased to learn that you have kept your promises. This means you are still my friends and allies.
If you remain loyal to me, I will reward you for everything you do.
I will give you valuable gifts and not make you pay heavy taxes.
My Jewish friends, you are excused from paying taxes on salt, as well as the other usual taxes, including the special royal tax.

<sup>ⓓ</sup> And from now on, you no longer have to give me a share of your grain and fruit.<sup>[109]</sup> I will never again take anything you grow in Judea or in the three districts added to Judea from Samaria and Galilee.
And I consider Jerusalem and the land that belongs to it so holy that I won't tax the money you receive from these places.
The high priest will take over from me the control of the Jerusalem fortress, and his own soldiers can guard it.
I will free every Jew who has been taken prisoner anywhere in my kingdom. You won't have to pay anything for them, and they won't have to pay taxes, not even on their livestock.<sup>[110]</sup>

On special days such as festivals, Sabbaths, or the first day of a month, my officials will not collect taxes or fees from any Jew in the kingdom. And on the three days before and after festivals, my officials will not collect taxes or fees.
No one will collect taxes from you or bother you for any reason on those special days.
I will let as many as 30,000 Jewish soldiers join my army, and they will be paid the same as the other soldiers.

Some of them will help guard my main fortresses, and others will be given important jobs in the kingdom. I'll let them live by their own laws and choose their own leaders and officers. In fact, this is how things already are in Judea.
The three districts of Judea that belonged to Samaria will become a permanent part of Judea. The high priest will be the only ruler for Judea and these three districts, and everyone must obey him.
I have given the city of Ptolemais and the land around it as a gift to the temple in Jerusalem, in order to supply money to help pay for running the temple.
Every year, I'll send you 15,000 pieces of silver from the treasuries in places under my control.
For the past few years my officials have failed to send you the extra money that they should have sent. Now they will start sending it again to meet the needs of the temple.<sup>[111]</sup>
In the past, you had to pay me 5,000 pieces of silver every year as a tax on the money the temple earned. Now this tax money will go to the priests who serve in the temple.
If anyone is hiding in or around the Jerusalem temple because they owe money to me or someone else, they are free to leave. And any property they own in my kingdom will be returned to them.
I will pay for repairing and rebuilding the temple. I will also pay for fixing the walls and towers in the towns in Judea, including Jerusalem.
Jonathan and the others remembered how cruel King Demetrius had been to them, and they did not believe a word he had written.
Instead, they sided with King Alexander, because he had come with the best offer of peace, and they remained his allies until he died.
Alexander built up a mighty army and led it into battle against the army of Demetrius.
The fighting was fierce and lasted until dark. Finally, the soldiers of Demetrius ran away, but Alexander and his army went after them and killed many, including Demetrius himself.<sup>[112]</sup>
King Alexander sent a message to King Ptolemy the Sixth<sup>[113]</sup> of Egypt. It said:
I've returned to rule the kingdom of my ancestors. But before I could take control, I had to do away with Demetrius.
So I destroyed him and his army, and now I am king.
Ptolemy, I would like for us to become allies. Let me marry your daughter and be your son-in-law. Then I will give each of you gifts that are worthy of a king and his daughter.
Ptolemy wrote back: Alexander, it was a happy day when you came back to rule the kingdom of your ancestors.
I'll let you marry my daughter, just as you asked in your letter. But first, meet me in the city of Ptolemais, so we can get to know each other.
In the year 162<sup>[114]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Ptolemy and his daughter Cleopatra<sup>[115]</sup> left Egypt and went to the city of Ptolemais.
The two kings met each other, and Ptolemy let Alexander marry Cleopatra. They had a very fancy wedding, just as kings always do.
Meanwhile, Jonathan the high priest received a letter from Alexander, inviting him to come to Ptolemais for a visit with him and Ptolemy.
Jonathan accepted the invitation and won their friendship by giving both kings and their trusted friends<sup>[116]</sup> some silver and gold, as well as many other gifts.
One day, a group of troublemakers and rebels came from Judea and brought charges against Jonathan. But Alexander would not listen to them.
Instead, he let Jonathan wear the purple robes of royalty
and sit next to him. The king told his officers, “Take Jonathan to the center of the city and order everyone to stop bothering him with all these charges.”

The troublemakers listened to the officers telling everyone to leave Jonathan alone. And when they saw Jonathan standing there in his purple robes, they realized how important he was. So they all ran away.
Alexander gave Jonathan even more honors. He included him among his most trusted friends and made him governor of Judea and a general in the Syrian army.
After this, Jonathan returned to Jerusalem, safe and sound.
Demetrius the Second was the son of Demetrius, and in the year 165<sup>[117]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, he sailed from Crete to the land of his ancestors.
When Alexander heard about this, he became worried and returned to the city of Antioch.

Demetrius appointed Apollonius ruler of Southwest Syria Province.<sup>[118]</sup> So Apollonius built up a large army and set up camp near the town of Jamnia. Then he sent the following letter to Jonathan the high priest:
Jonathan, you are the only one who is still fighting against us, and you are making others laugh and sneer at me. Why do you keep rebelling against us there in the hill country?
If you're so proud of your army, come down out of the hills and fight. You will find out that the people in the towns are on our side.
Just ask anyone, and they will tell you who I am and who my followers are. You don't stand a chance against us. Your own ancestors were defeated twice right here in their own land.
What makes you think you can win a battle in the valley against my army and cavalry? There are no rocks or stones to crawl behind, and there is no place where you can run away.
Jonathan was furious when he read this letter. He chose 10,000 soldiers, then left Jerusalem to meet his brother Simon, who was coming to help him.
The two brothers surrounded the town of Joppa, because Apollonius had soldiers there. No one would let them in at first.
But they attacked and frightened the people into opening the gates; then they took command of the town.

When Apollonius found out that they had taken Joppa, he brought 3,000 cavalry and a large force of soldiers to the town of Azotus. He wanted the Jews to think he was only passing through the town. So he led his troops out to the nearby valley, where he was sure his cavalry could protect the soldiers.
Jonathan followed Apollonius to Azotus, and a battle broke out
when 1,000 of Apollonius' cavalry suddenly left their hiding places and attacked from behind.
The cavalry surrounded Jonathan's troops and shot arrows at them from early morning until late afternoon.
But Jonathan's forces held their ground, and he told them to keep fighting until the enemy cavalry wore themselves out.
Then Simon led some of his soldiers into the battle and overpowered the enemy army. The enemy foot soldiers ran for their lives,
and the cavalry scattered over the valleys. Some of the enemy soldiers ran back to Azotus and hid in the temple of their god Dagon, thinking they would be safe.
But Jonathan destroyed Azotus and the nearby towns and took everything of value. Then he burned down the temple with everyone inside.
Eight thousand enemy soldiers died in the battle and the fire.
Jonathan left Azotus and ordered his army to set up camp near the town of Askalon, where the people came out to honor him.
Then Jonathan and his soldiers, loaded down with everything they had taken, returned to Jerusalem.
When Alexander heard about Jonathan's victories, he gave him even more honors.
He sent a gold buckle that only the most respected members of the king's family<sup>[119]</sup> were allowed to wear. Alexander also gave Jonathan the town of Ekron and the land around it.
King Ptolemy the Sixth<sup>[120]</sup> of Egypt got together more ships and soldiers than anyone could count. Then he made a secret plan to take over the kingdom of his son-in-law Alexander.
Ptolemy led his forces toward Syria and told each town he came to that he was on a friendly visit. Everyone believed Ptolemy and welcomed him, just as his son-in-law Alexander had ordered them to do.
But he stationed soldiers in their towns.

The people of Azotus met Ptolemy and showed him all that was left of their town, of the nearby villages, and of the temple of Dagon that had been destroyed by fire. They also showed him the piles of dead and burned bodies they had heaped up beside the road after the battle with Jonathan.
Everyone blamed Jonathan for all the damage, but Ptolemy said nothing.
Jonathan met Ptolemy at the town of Joppa, and Jonathan honored him. The two men spent the night there,
then the next day Jonathan rode with him to the Eleutherus River<sup>[121]</sup> before heading back for Jerusalem.
Soon Ptolemy had command of the towns on the coast as far as Seleucia. He kept plotting against Alexander,

and one day he sent a message to Demetrius the king, which said: Let's make an agreement. I will arrange for you to marry my daughter Cleopatra,<sup>[122]</sup> the wife of Alexander. Then you can rule your father's kingdom.
It was a big mistake to let Alexander marry her. He even tried to have me murdered!
Ptolemy said other insulting things about Alexander because he wanted his kingdom.
Then he ordered Cleopatra to leave Alexander, and he told Demetrius to marry her. Now Ptolemy and Alexander hated each other, and everyone knew it.
Ptolemy went to the city of Antioch, where he crowned himself king—both of Syria and of Egypt.
Meanwhile, Alexander had gone to the country of Cilicia because some towns there had rebelled against him.
When Alexander heard what Ptolemy had done, he attacked him, but Ptolemy's large army defeated Alexander and forced him to retreat.
After Ptolemy won this important victory, Alexander found a hiding place in Arabia,
but Zabdiel the Arab chopped off Alexander's head and sent it to Ptolemy.
Three days later, Ptolemy himself died, and the people in his fortresses killed the soldiers he had stationed there.
In the year 167<sup>[123]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Demetrius the Second<sup>[124]</sup> became king.
A little later, Jonathan gathered an army in Judea. He built a lot of weapons to break through city walls and then attacked the fortress in Jerusalem.
King Demetrius the Second found out about the attack from some Jews who really hated the other Jews.

Demetrius became furious, and right away he went to the city of Ptolemais. From there he wrote a letter to Jonathan and said, “Stop attacking the fortress in Jerusalem! Come to Ptolemais as soon as you can. We need to talk.”
After Jonathan read the letter, he ordered his soldiers to keep up the attack. Then he risked his own life by taking some of the priests and leaders
to Ptolemais. He brought silver, gold, some clothing, and many other gifts for Demetrius, which made Demetrius friendly toward him.
Some Jews who were unfaithful to their Law kept bringing charges against Jonathan.
But Demetrius treated him well, just as the rulers before him had done. And one day, when all the trusted friends<sup>[125]</sup> of Demetrius were there, he gave Jonathan an even higher honor
by making him one of his most trusted friends. Demetrius also let Jonathan continue as high priest and keep all the honors he had already been given.
Jonathan asked Demetrius to stop collecting taxes from Judea and the three districts of Samaria,<sup>[126]</sup> and, in return, he promised to give him 300,000 pieces of silver.
Demetrius agreed, then wrote the following letter:
King Demetrius sends greetings to his good friend Jonathan and to the Jewish nation.
I am sending you a copy of the letter I wrote about you to my friend Lasthenes, and here is what I said:
“King Demetrius sends greetings to his dear friend Lasthenes.
“The Jews are our friends, and I have decided to do them a big favor since they are loyal to us and can be trusted to keep their promises.

<sup>ⓔ</sup> The three regions of Aphairema, Lydda, and Ramathaim,<sup>[127]</sup> together with the land around them, used to belong to Samaria. Now they belong to Judea and are an official possession of the Jews. “Those Jews who offer sacrifices in Jerusalem don't have to pay me my share of their grain and fruit each year.<sup>[128]</sup>
And they don't have to pay me a tenth of their crops, the fee on salt, the special royal tax, or any other taxes.
“Lasthenes, no one may ever change even one of these orders.
Make a copy of this letter and send it to Jonathan. He will put it on God's holy mountain where it can be seen by everyone.”

No one opposed King Demetrius the Second, and his kingdom was at peace. So he sent his own soldiers back home and kept only the foreign troops he had hired from the Greek islands. But this made his own soldiers turn against him, because they had fought for many years, first in his father's army and then in his.

Trypho had been a follower of Alexander Epiphanes,<sup>[129]</sup> and when he found out how angry all of Demetrius' troops were, he went to Imalkue the Arab, who was taking care of Antiochus the Sixth,<sup>[130]</sup> the young son of King Alexander.

Trypho stayed with Imalkue a long time and kept begging him to hand over the young boy. He said, “Antiochus should take his father's place as king, because Demetrius has let all of his own soldiers go, and they hate him for it.”
Meanwhile, Jonathan sent the following message to Demetrius: Please take your soldiers out of the fortresses around here, especially the one in Jerusalem. They keep attacking us.
Demetrius wrote back: Jonathan, of course I will do what you and your people have asked. And I will show great honors to you and your people as soon as I can.
For now, please do me a favor and send some troops to help me, because my own soldiers have rebelled.
Jonathan sent a heavily armed force of 3,000 soldiers to the city of Antioch, and Demetrius was very glad to see them.
Not long after this, a mob of about 120,000 people tried to kill Demetrius.
They took over the streets and started rioting. So Demetrius ran away to his palace
and ordered the Jewish soldiers to protect him. They came and made sure Demetrius was safe. Then they went through the entire city, killing almost 100,000 people.
They not only rescued Demetrius that day, but they also set the city on fire and took everything of value.
When the people of Antioch saw that the Jews had taken over their city, they were terrified and begged Demetrius for help. They shouted,
“Please make peace with us! Order the Jews to stop attacking us and our city.”

Demetrius made peace with the people as soon as they had put down their weapons. The Jewish soldiers had earned the respect of everyone in his kingdom, and they returned to Jerusalem with all the things they had captured.
Demetrius was now in complete control of his kingdom again, and there was no more trouble.
Before long, he forgot how much Jonathan had helped him, and he broke his promises to Jonathan by treating him like an enemy and causing him a lot of trouble.
When Trypho came back from his visit to Imalkue the Arab, he brought young Antiochus the Sixth<sup>[131]</sup> with him, and the boy began to rule as king.
The soldiers that King Demetrius the Second had sent home now sided with Antiochus and Trypho. They attacked Demetrius, forcing him to run for his life.
Trypho captured Demetrius' elephants<sup>[132]</sup> as well as the city of Antioch.

Young King Antiochus wrote a letter to Jonathan, in which he said: I will let you continue as high priest. I have also made you one of my trusted friends<sup>[133]</sup> and the ruler of the four regions.<sup>[134]</sup>
I am sending you some gold plates and dishes, and I am giving you permission to drink from a gold cup and to wear royal robes and a gold buckle.<sup>[135]</sup>
Your brother Simon is now the ruler of the land from Phoenicia to the Egyptian border.

Jonathan left Judea and led his army across the Jordan River. They were going from town to town, when the entire Syrian army arrived and offered to help them fight. So Jonathan took his forces to the town of Askalon, where the people welcomed and honored them.

He led his troops to the town of Gaza, but its people refused to let them enter. Then they surrounded the town and took everything of value from the villages nearby. When Jonathan's forces burned down these villages,
the people of Gaza begged him not to destroy their town. He agreed, but he sent the sons of Gaza's rulers as hostages to Jerusalem. After this, Jonathan led his army as far as Damascus.

Someone told Jonathan: King Demetrius the Second has sent a large force under the command of royal officers to the town of Kadesh in Galilee. The officers have orders to make you give up your position as high priest.
Simon stayed behind in Judea while his brother Jonathan set out to attack the army of Demetrius.
Simon attacked the town of Beth-Zur and kept it surrounded for a long time
before it surrendered to him. He took command of Beth-Zur and told its people to leave. Then he stationed his own troops there.
Meanwhile, Jonathan and his soldiers had set up camp near Lake Galilee. And early one morning, he led them to Hazor Valley.
Demetrius' army of foreign troops was waiting for them in the valleys. Some of them attacked immediately, while others waited behind some hills, ready to make a surprise attack.
When the enemy soldiers came out of their hiding places and attacked,
almost all the Jewish troops ran away, except two officers by the names of Mattathias and Judas.<sup>[136]</sup>
Jonathan ripped his clothes and put dirt on his head to show his sorrow. Then he prayed
and returned to the battle. His army defeated their enemies and made them run for their lives.
When the Jewish troops that had deserted saw their enemies trying to escape, they returned and helped chase them as far as the enemy camp at Kadesh. The Jews set up camp there,
and Jonathan went back to Jerusalem. About 3,000 foreign soldiers were killed that day.
Jonathan realized this was a good time to make sure the Romans remained on friendly terms with the Jews. So he sent some messengers to Rome.
He also wrote letters to the city of Sparta and other places for the same reason.

When the messengers arrived in Rome, they met with the Roman senators and said, “Jonathan the high priest and the Jewish people have sent us here to renew our friendship with Rome and to make sure we remain allies.”
After the meeting, the Romans wrote letters to the other nations where the messengers were going. In these letters they said, “Help these men return safely to Judea.”
Jonathan himself wrote a letter to the people of Sparta in which he said:
Jonathan the high priest, the other priests, the Jewish council, and the rest of our people send greetings to our dear friends in Sparta.

Some time ago, your king, Arius, sent a letter to Onias, our high priest. Arius said that Jews and Spartans are related, as you can see from the copy of the king's letter we have sent along with this letter.
When Onias read this, he welcomed your messenger with honors, because your letter clearly stated that Jews and Spartans should become friends and allies.
We Jews don't really need friends and allies, since our Scriptures give us hope and strength.

But we decided to write you anyway to renew our friendship and to make sure that we are still on good terms. After all, it has been a long time since you wrote us, and we don't want to become like strangers to each other.
It is our custom and duty to remember relatives. So during our festivals and other special days, we always think of you as we pray and offer sacrifices.
We are very pleased that you have become so famous.
We have had plenty of troubles and wars of our own. Even the nearby kings have attacked us.
However, there was no reason to bother you or other friends and allies with our problems.
God always helps us, and we defeated our enemies and were rescued from them.
We have sent Numenius and Antipater<sup>[137]</sup> as messengers to Rome to make sure that we and the Romans remain on good terms.
They also have orders to bring this letter to you with our greetings, because we want to be certain that you still consider us your relatives.
Please send a reply.
Here is a copy of the letter King Arius wrote to Onias some time ago:
“King Arius of Sparta sends greetings to Onias the high priest.
“We have found a document that says Spartans and Jews are relatives because both nations descended from Abraham.
Now that I know this, I want you to write and tell me how you are doing.

I am writing to tell you that your livestock together with everything else you own belongs to us. And our livestock together with everything else we own belongs to you. “My messengers have orders to tell you about this.”
Jonathan found out that the officers of King Demetrius the Second<sup>[138]</sup> were now ready to invade his country with a more powerful army than before.
Jonathan did not want the king's army to invade Jerusalem, so he led his troops to the region around Hamath,<sup>[139]</sup> where he saw the enemy camp.
Jonathan sent out spies, who came back and reported, “The king's army is getting ready to attack us tonight.”
At sunset, Jonathan stationed some of his troops on lookout duty around the camp, and he told the others, “Stay awake and be ready to fight at any time.”
But the king's troops lost their nerve and were frightened when someone informed them that the Jews were ready for their attack. So they lit campfires and ran away.<sup>[140]</sup>
The campfires burned all night, and the Jews did not find out until morning that the enemy had left.
Jonathan sent troops after them, but the king's army had already crossed the Eleutherus River.
There was a tribe of Arabs named the Zabadeans, and Jonathan ordered his troops to destroy them. The troops took everything of value,
then Jonathan led them all the way to Damascus.

Meanwhile, Simon took his soldiers as far as Askalon and the nearby fortresses. Someone told him, “The town of Joppa is about to join Demetrius.” Simon made a surprise attack on Joppa; he captured the town and stationed some of his troops there to guard it.
Jonathan returned to Jerusalem and met with the Jewish leaders. They decided to build fortresses in Judea

and to make Jerusalem's walls even higher. They also agreed to construct a strong, high wall between the enemy fortress and the rest of the city, in order to separate the fortress from the city and to keep enemy soldiers from going in and out for supplies.
Everyone worked together to rebuild Jerusalem; they repaired part of the collapsed eastern wall and the section of the city<sup>[141]</sup> called Chaphenatha.
Meanwhile, Simon and his workers rebuilt the town of Adida at the edge of the hill country, and they put a wall around it with strong gates.
Trypho wanted to be king of Asia, and he began plotting against King Antiochus the Sixth.
But Trypho was afraid Jonathan would go to war to protect Antiochus. So he decided to do away with Jonathan, and he led his army to the town of Beth-Shan.
Jonathan and 40,000 of his best soldiers left Jerusalem to attack Trypho at Beth-Shan.
When Trypho saw the large army, he was too frightened to fight.

Instead, he brought Jonathan to his camp and gave him honors and gifts. Trypho bragged about Jonathan to all his trusted friends<sup>[142]</sup> and troops and said, “Obey Jonathan's orders, just as you obey mine.”
Trypho told Jonathan: We're not at war! Why have you caused these people so much trouble?

I've come here to give you the city of Ptolemais and the other fortresses and to put you in charge of all the officers and troops. After I've done this, I'll go home. Choose a few troops to go with you and me to Ptolemais, then send the others back to Judea.
Jonathan believed Trypho and sent all but 3,000 of his soldiers back to Judea. Two thousand of them stayed behind in Galilee, while 1,000 went with Jonathan to Ptolemais.
But as soon as he entered the city, its gates were closed. Then he was captured, and his soldiers were killed.
Trypho's troops and cavalry went to the Great Valley in Galilee<sup>[143]</sup> to kill the rest of Jonathan's soldiers.
However, when Jonathan's troops heard what had happened to him and the others, they encouraged each other and marched away, ready to fight.
Trypho's soldiers and cavalry caught up with them, but they turned back when they realized that the Jews would fight for their lives.
After the Jewish soldiers from Galilee returned safely to Judea, the whole nation mourned for Jonathan and his troops. Everyone was terrified
because the Gentiles around there were saying, “The Jews have no ruler or general. Let's destroy them and make the world forget they ever lived.”
Trypho got together a large army to invade Judea and destroy it. The Jews were terrified when they heard what he was up to. But Simon went to Jerusalem, where he called the people together
and encouraged everyone by saying: You know the wonderful things my family has done for the Law of Moses and our temple. You've heard how my brothers and I suffered in the wars
and how they died fighting for our people. I'm the only one in my family left alive.
But in these troubled times I'm ready to die for our people, just as my brothers did.
I want to get even with the other nations. They hate us and have come together to destroy our people, our temple, and our families.
Simon's speech encouraged everyone,
and they shouted, “Be our leader, just like your brothers Judas and Jonathan.
Take command of our army, and we will obey your orders.”
Simon called the troops together, and they worked quickly to finish the walls and towers that protected Jerusalem on every side.
Simon ordered Jonathan the son of Absalom to take a large force of soldiers to the town of Joppa. Jonathan forced the people to leave, and he took over Joppa.
Trypho was still holding Simon's brother Jonathan as a hostage, and he brought Jonathan along when he led his large army out of Ptolemais to invade Judea.

Someone told Trypho, “Simon is now leader of the Jews, and he's ready to attack.” Then Trypho sent a message to Simon, whose camp was at Adida overlooking the valleys.<sup>[144]</sup> The message said:
Your brother Jonathan was a royal official, but he owed money to the king, and so I arrested him.
I'll set him free as soon as you send me 100,000 pieces of silver and two of his sons as hostages. That way he won't rebel against me anymore.
Simon knew the messengers were lying, but he sent for the money and Jonathan's sons. He knew if he did not, the Jewish people would hate him and say,
“If Simon had given Trypho what he wanted, Jonathan would still be alive!”
Simon sent Jonathan's sons and the money to Trypho. However, Trypho broke his promise and did not release Jonathan.

Trypho and his soldiers now set out to invade and destroy the country. They marched south and came up on the road from Adora. But each time Trypho tried to cross the border, he was blocked by Simon and his forces.
Meanwhile, the enemy troops in the fortress at Jerusalem kept sending messages to Trypho, begging him to go around by way of the desert and bring them food.
Finally, Trypho ordered his cavalry to get ready to leave for Jerusalem. But that night, Trypho was stopped by a heavy snowstorm, and he took his army to the country of Gilead.
When he reached the town of Baskama, he had Jonathan killed and buried.
Then he returned to his own country.
Simon had the body of his brother Jonathan taken back to Modein, the town of his ancestors. He buried him there,
and everyone in Israel cried and mourned for a long time.
Simon had a tall stone monument built over his family grave. It was shiny on the front and back, and could be seen a long way off.
He also built a row of seven pyramids to honor his father, his mother, and his four brothers.

He set up tall stone columns around the pyramids. Then he hung suits of armor on these columns, so that everyone would remember what his family had done. Next to the suits of armor he put carved figures of ships that could be seen by anyone passing by on the sea. This family burial place is a work of art, and even today it can be seen in Modein.
Antiochus the Sixth was still a young boy<sup>[145]</sup> when Trypho had him murdered.
Now Trypho was ruler and made everyone miserable.
During this time, Simon ordered the Jews to build thick walls, high towers, and strong gates for the fortresses in Judea and to supply them with plenty of food.
Simon sent messengers to King Demetrius the Second, and they begged him, “Please make things easier for our country. Trypho is robbing us of everything.”
Demetrius the Second did what Simon wanted and wrote him the following letter:
King Demetrius sends greetings to the Jewish people and their leaders, including Simon, who is high priest and a trusted friend<sup>[146]</sup> of the king.
Thank you for the gold crown and the gold palm branch you sent me. I am ready to make a lasting peace by ordering my officials to stop collecting taxes from you.
I will give you everything I have promised in our treaties. Besides that, you can keep the fortresses you have just built.
I forgive everything you have done wrong in the past. And from now on, I won't collect the special royal tax or any of the other taxes I used to receive from Jerusalem.
I will hire any of your people who are prepared to help me in my kingdom.<sup>[147]</sup> Let's give peace a chance!
So in the year 170<sup>[148]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, the Jews won their freedom from the Gentiles.
And on their documents and contracts they wrote, “The first year of Simon, the great high priest and the commander and ruler of the Jews.”

<sup>ⓕ</sup> About this time, Simon and the Jewish forces surrounded the town of Gazara<sup>[149]</sup> and set up a large weapon to break through the wall. They pushed it up to the town wall, where they broke through and captured one of the towers.
Then the soldiers who were operating the weapon rushed into Gazara, causing a terrible uproar.
Everyone in Gazara tore their clothes to show their sorrow. They climbed to the top of the town wall where they shouted to Simon and begged him for peace,
saying, “We've done wrong and deserve to be punished. But please have mercy on us.”

Simon agreed to stop the fighting. But he ordered everyone to leave the town, and he took the idols out of the houses where they were kept. Then he and his troops entered Gazara, singing hymns of praise.
Simon removed everything that made the town unclean according to their religion, and he made the fortresses of Gazara stronger. He built a house for himself and let faithful Jews live in the town.
The enemy troops in the Jerusalem fortress still could not go into the country to buy food, and many of them starved to death.
Finally, the survivors begged Simon for peace. He agreed, then ordered them to leave the fortress, so he could remove everything that made it unclean according to their religion.

On the twenty-third day of the second month in the year 171<sup>[150]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, Simon led his soldiers into the fortress. They carried palm branches and praised God with all kinds of songs and musical instruments. God had completely crushed their powerful enemy!

<sup>ⓖ</sup> Simon decided that a joyous festival should be held on this same day every year. He strengthened the wall on the side of the temple hill that faced the fortress. Then he and his troops made the fortress their headquarters.
John the son of Simon was now a grown man. So Simon put him in command of the whole army, and John lived in the town of Gazara.
In the year 172<sup>[151]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom, King Demetrius the Second<sup>[152]</sup> led an army to the country of Media, where he hoped to hire soldiers to help him fight Trypho.
When King Arsaces of Persia and Media learned that Demetrius had invaded his country, he sent one of his generals
to capture him alive. This general defeated the army of Demetrius and took Demetrius to King Arsaces, who put him in prison.

The country was at peace
while Simon ruled,
because he worked
for the good of the nation.
Everyone was glad that he ruled,
and they honored him
for as long as he lived.

Simon became a true hero
by capturing
the seaport of Joppa.
Now ships can sail
to faraway islands.

Simon made the country larger
and ruled the entire region.

He took many prisoners
and also captured the towns
of Gazara and Beth-Zur.
And when he took control
of the Jerusalem fortress,
he removed all the idols
that had made it unclean.
No one could oppose him!

Life was peaceful on the farms;
the earth produced grain,
and fruit grew on the trees.

In towns the old folks
talked about the good things
that had happened,
while young soldiers strolled by
in their fancy uniforms.

Simon supplied the towns
with food and protection
and was famous everywhere.

He brought peace
and great joy to Israel.

Everyone rested unafraid
beneath their own grapevines
and fig trees;

troublemakers and enemy kings
had been crushed.

Simon helped the poor
and obeyed the Law of God
by destroying outlaws
and rebellious people.

He gave gifts to the temple
and made it more glorious.
Cities as far away as Rome and Sparta mourned at the news of Jonathan's death.
But they were pleased that Jonathan's brother Simon had taken his place as high priest and ruler of Judea.
<sup>ⓗ</sup> The Romans and Spartans wanted Simon to be their friend and ally, just as his brothers had been, so they wrote him letters on sheets of bronze.
The Jews then read these letters during a meeting in Jerusalem.
The letter from the Spartans said: The city of Sparta and its leaders send greetings to Simon the high priest, to the other leaders and priests, and to our relatives, the Jews.
Your messengers made us very happy when they told us how famous you are.
The details of their visit are in our record books, which say: “The Jews sent Numenius and Antipater<sup>[153]</sup> to us as messengers to make sure that we were on friendly terms.

We Spartans gladly welcomed these men and honored them. Moreover, we placed a copy of their message in the public building where all our record books are kept. We have also sent a copy to Simon the high priest, telling what we have done.”

After the Jews had finished their meeting, Simon sent Numenius to Rome to make certain that the Romans were still their allies. Numenius took them a heavy gold shield that weighed almost 570 kilograms.<sup>[154]</sup>
When the people found out what Simon was doing, they said, “How can we repay Simon and his descendants?

He and his brothers and the rest of his father's family have been strong; they have defeated our enemies and set us free.” The people wrote on sheets of bronze the things Simon had done, then they fastened the sheets to stone columns on Mount Zion.

This is what they wrote: After Simon the great high priest had ruled for three years in Asaramel,<sup>[155]</sup> our priests, rulers, and leaders held an important meeting on the eighteenth day of the month of Elul<sup>[156]</sup> in the year 172<sup>[157]</sup> of the Syrian Kingdom. This is what we were told:

“Simon the son of Mattathias was a priest from Joarib's family.<sup>[158]</sup> He and his brothers risked their lives and fought back whenever our enemies attacked us. They protected our temple and the Law of Moses, and they made us famous.
“Simon's brother Jonathan united our people, and we chose him to be our high priest. But after he died,
our enemies prepared to invade Judea, because they wanted to attack our temple and destroy the country.<sup>[159]</sup>
“Simon took command of our army. He spent a lot of his own money to pay our soldiers and to buy weapons and armor for us.
He put up strong walls and towers in the towns of Judea, as well as in the border town of Beth-Zur, where the enemy used to store weapons. Then he stationed Jewish soldiers at Beth-Zur.

“Simon built a fortress in the coastal town of Joppa as well as in the town of Gazara, because it was close to Azotus, which had been a stronghold for our enemies. Simon settled Jews in Gazara, and he gave everyone in these towns whatever they needed to make the towns fit to live in.
“Simon was a dependable man who had high hopes for our country and did all he could to make our nation glorious. So we chose him to be our ruler and high priest.

“The Gentiles had built a fortress in Jerusalem and had stationed some soldiers there, who then attacked the rest of us and made the temple and everything else unclean. But Simon successfully forced the Gentiles out of Judea; he got rid of the troops in the fortress and was in full control of everything.
“Simon strengthened the walls of the Jerusalem fortress and stationed soldiers there to guard the country and city. He also made the walls around Jerusalem higher.
“Simon did everything well, so King Demetrius accepted him as our high priest.
Demetrius called Simon his trusted friend<sup>[160]</sup> and gave him many other honors.
He did this because he knew that the Romans had welcomed Simon's messengers and considered Jews their friends, allies, and relatives.
“Our people and priests gladly chose Simon and his descendants<sup>[161]</sup> to be our rulers and high priests forever, or until God sends a true prophet.
“Simon will rule over us and care for our temple, our country, our weapons, and our fortresses.
Everyone must obey his orders and write his name on all official documents in Judea. Simon has permission to wear purple clothes and gold jewelry, just like a king.

“Our people and our priests must never change any of these orders. They must obey Simon and never hold meetings in the country without first asking him. And none of them may wear purple clothes and a gold buckle, as though they were kings.
Anyone who disobeys or rejects these orders will be punished.”
The people agreed with these decisions that Simon should be high priest, commander, and ruler of the nation and its priests. Simon was glad to do all this, and he promised to protect them.
The agreement was written on sheets of bronze, then put in the temple for everyone to see.
Copies were also stored in the treasury for Simon and his family.
Antiochus the Seventh,<sup>[162]</sup> the son of Demetrius the Second,<sup>[163]</sup> sent a letter from the Greek islands to the Jews and to Simon the high priest and ruler.
It said: King Antiochus sends greetings to the Jewish people and to Simon their high priest and ruler.
Some rebels have taken control of my ancestors' kingdom. I want it back so I can make it a great kingdom again. I have hired a large army and navy,
and I am ready to land on the coast. I am going to punish everyone who has destroyed my country and ruined so many of its towns.
I will follow the example of other kings and excuse you from paying some taxes and fees.
I will let you make your own coins
